description:
Been here twice and I love it. Their meat is fresh and delicious, side dishes (vegetables, etc) are portioned just enough, and the soup makes all the textures and flavors come alive together. 

The best part is at the end of your meal, when they make rice porridge from the leftover soup soaked in all the meat and vegetable. I can just imagine it rn and it's making my mouth water! Adds a very warm touch to make your dinner feel complete. 

Wait isn't very long and the servers are really nice and patient. The only thing I disliked about it is how stuffy it gets inside, so be prepared to smell like hot pot when you leave.
author: Elle T.

description:
I ordered the sukiyaki with wagyu beef. The beef here is pretty good though still sightly too tough for my liking. I also tried the a5 (small) and it actually came out to a decent portion. The taste was great and something I would consider ordering again, as the cut is not as thin as other places. 

Choya plum wine is worth ordering again!

Porridge at the end is yummy but a bit too salty, probably worth taking home and fixing it up.
author: Ariel Z.

description:
$28 for a large platter of meat - 8oz 
$24 for a small platter of meat - 6oz

this place is a more upscale shabu restaurant

3 stars because I still left hungry
author: Yeanne L.

description:
Nabe is Japanese hot pot place in Inner sunset that is not an AYCE!

I love their modern ambiance, decent food and quality of the meat! I got regular size sukiyaki ($25) and kimchi+kurobuta pork belly ($25) each time. Sukiyaki broth was more on the sweeter side but it was good. Their wagyu beef were fresh and really good!
As a Korean myself, I enjoyed kimchi broth more. It was not spicy but broth was flavorful and delicious! It had lots of veggies, tofu and kimchi with pork belly! Highly recommend this one!

My favorite part of this meal was that they make you rice soup (porridge or korean Juk) with leftover broth which was unexpectedly good! We chose Kimchi broth for porridge and that was the best part of the meal. We were so full before we had that porridge, but we had to finish it because it was sooooo good! It got little saltier later but still good. The service was outstanding and server was very attentive.

Nabe's hot pot definitely warms your soul on a cold night!! Definitely coming back here for another great experience!
author: Clare L.

description:
Quick Summary:
- Not All-You-Can-Eat
- After ordering a nabe style, extras are ordered Al La Carte Style
- Not enough for a glutton, even after ordering two large nabes. 
- If you're a glutton, enter with 50% full (drink coffee before entering) and you will leave moderately full
- Recommend to set up a reservation. I did it online.

The only reason, and it was a large reason for my case, why I decided to lower the star from 5 to 4 is the portions. 

First off, the food was very delicious. We ordered two large nabe styles: shabu shabu (ordered the beef) and the kinoko (mushroom and vegetables). The shabu shabu came with a plate of vegetables (carrot, tofu, spinach, enoki mushrooms, shiitake mushroom, daikon radish, udon, etc.). On the other hand, most of the stated vegetables were already placed in the kinoko nabe (the ramen came as a separate plate), so there was fewer preparations for that dish. 
I ordered the konbu dashi for the shabu shabu because I wanted to try the shabu shabu that focuses on the meat's flavor. Also, we ordered the kinoko dish, and that is already made in a miso broth, so it was great to try two different soups. In the end, we selected the rice porridge to be made in the kinoko broth. I do have to add, the miso broth was lacking the dashi taste (lacking konbu, katsuo bushi, or shiitake). 

At first glance, I can tell, I can easily eat one of these large nabe and one regular nabe portion all by myself, if I were to arrive at the restaurant hungry with a 90% or higher empty stomach. Even my other family members could have eaten at least one large nabe on their own.

We cleared the dishes and ate the rice porridge - and I have arrived drinking 1 1/2 cups of coffee an hour or so earlier - and I was 75% full. 

I do also recommend setting up a reservation. It takes at least 2 hours for a guest to eat, minus the conversational chatter time duration, so if all seats are full, you might have to wait an hour or longer.
author: Mito I.

description:
Absolutely loved this place. The experience here is so relaxing, it feels like a spa.

The atmosphere is kind of dark and modern. I noticed their music selection here is very feelsy. This is definitely the place where you want to take your best friend or someone close and talk about the good and the bad. It's a very cozy rainy day vibe.

The food itself was amazing. We ordered the ishikari nabe, and it was honestly my favorite. The broth is super buttery and has such a subtle but beautiful flavor to it. I found myself just drinking the broth because it was soooo good. We also ordered the shabu shabu with spicy miso, which was super flavorful and moderately spicy. We loved the wagyu beef! Also, the zosui at the end was perfect. I loved to watch it being made at our own table, and to finish it all off with the chewy and crunchy mochi cake was awesome! The meal was super satisfying.

They have great drinks also! If sake is your thing, there's plenty of that. I opted for the choya plum wine, which was super sweet with just a hint of tartness. We also ordered a pot of the genmaicha tea, which was smoky and savory. I loved both! Honestly, the meal wouldnt have been complete without some wine and hot tea.
author: Claire C.

description:
Ok, I recently discovered this place and I've already been back 3 times. I've come with a friend each time and we've split a Shabu Shabu between the both of us! The wagyu beef is pretty amazing and they give you plenty of veggies to eat with. There are side dishes you can order, with an extra cost of course. 
At the end, they do make you porridge from the remaining soup, as well as egg, seaweed, and green onions. Super simple, but so good! I typically take it home and eat it the next day. I've had this amazing waitress help us each time and I hope she's the manager, because it's incredible the amount of attention she gives each party especially when people get miffed that they aren't seated right away.
author: Julia T.

description: Solid 4, I preferred the Sukiyaki over the Shabu Shabu, however both were good.  Service was exceptional.
author: Kelly C.

description:
I was pretty disappointed with the service here. Throughout the evening, I had to constantly flag down the waitresses to make sure my a la carte orders had been taken. My friends and I also weren't receiving much attention compared to other tables. The menu specifically stated that each set came with rice. But it took us more than 30 minutes (with constant reminding) to get our two bowls of rice sent to our table. In contrast, I noticed that the other parties sitting right next to us got their rice and meat plates much sooner than we were, despite having been seated much later. By the end of the meal, I noticed that the waitresses seemed tired with my constant calling them for attention, but from a customer's perspective, It's frustrating when I feel like I'm not being heard.

Otherwise, the food was great. I'm a smaller eater, so portions were perfect, but if you have a larger appetite. you might have to order a few more dishes a la carte. Be mindful when ordering the seafood and duck sets. The meats are placed in the broth as the broth heats up on the hot plate, so make sure to take the meats out as soon as they're done. The worst thing that can happen is to be left with rubbery, overcooked meat.
author: Connie X.

description: Hotpot sets to warm your tummy. Had the Kamonanban and Ishikari Nabe. Both delicious. Also great service!
author: Bessie L.

description:
Nabe was an awesome experience on a cold foggy evening in the Sunset district. 

Traditional Japanese hot pot or Shubu Shabu. So good they had to name it twice!!

The three of us got the Waygu beef and pork belly sets with some edamame and gyoza to start. 

The sets come with mushrooms, spinach, tofu, and kimchi. Rice and a couple glasses of wine round out the experience.

For bases, got miso and hot chili oil. 

The shabu shabu we made was fantastic!!  Flavorful, piping hot 

Your server finishes the meal with an egg, rice infused porridge. 

Awesome meal!!  A wonderful bonding experience with friends and family.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I took my girlfriend here for her birthday dinner since neither of us have eaten here before and our friend recommended it. Also, we both like Shabu House, and thought this would be a nice place to try out to see if it is just as good. Here's what we got:

Edamame with savory garlic soy - big enjoyable portion, lots of garlic!

Sukiyaki with wagyu beef - first time ordering this, so I didn't know what to expect. It's like Shabu, except all the veggies are in the broth already. The warishita broth however is kind of sweet which I do not like.

Shabu Shabu with wagyu beef - was mostly excited for this, something I am accustomed to eating often. After cooking the meat in the spicy miso broth, I dipped it in the small bowl of their provided house sauce, and... meh, It was disappointedly bland, not flavorful at all.

Before we got the check, the waitress made rice porridge for us with the leftover spicy miso broth to take home! I haven't seen any shabu restaurant do this before, and thought it was very nice of them.

Overall, I thought this place was pretty nice, but I wouldn't come back here if I wanted to eat shabu shabu again. I'd rather choose Shabu House or Shabu Club.
author: Wesley S.

description:
The good: Cool decor, good blend of ingredients (I was surprised to see konnyaku, which seems to be a pretty "exotic" item to serve), helpful wait staff. 

The bad: Super small space (I was afraid someone was going to knock over hot soup), portion/cost ratio

Perhaps, as a tourist from Texas, I'm not used to the prices here in SF, but I did feel the food was overpriced in addition to being small portions. The ingredients used were great though, but I can't justify paying $30 and needing to go out and find dinner #2. 

I do like how they would use the remaining broth at the end of the meal to make a porridge. The broth has soaked up all the goodness of the veggies, meats, and other ingredients so it's pretty great!

TL;DR - Decent food, decent wait staff, pricey for what you're getting.
author: Camilla Y.

description:
Nancy is so amazing. She makes my experience so seamless and relaxing and enjoyable! She anticipates anything and everything. 
I love the food here, especially the rice at the end. SO AMAZING

Every time I come I have to get the pork belly, but I snag a few pieces of the beef from family! The beef has recently changed into a different cut and the pieces are big but dang is it tender! Yummm
author: Marisa W.

description:
Came to Nabe because I had lunch and couldn't do AYCE shabu shabu for dinner so I thought I'd try quality over quantity for once. Little did I know, I wasn't getting quality nor quantity.

Nabe is priced at around $25/pp. This is only $10 cheaper than an AYCE place, but the meat quality isn't that much better, if at all. Plus, you only get 1 serving of vegetables, and that's not enough spinach and udon. The portions are not filling at all and the flavors were unimpressive.

The kamonanban (duck breast) seemed interesting but wasn't very good. 

Lastly, the rice porridge at the end seemed like a cunning ploy to fill our stomachs before we realize we overpaid for dinner and need a second dinner before bed. I get they're trying to be unique and not be wasteful, but the porridge wasn't very tasty and was an awkward finale for a mediocre race.
author: Sally L.

description:
Usually go to the Marina location which is a little more spacious.. but due to a screw up they didn't get our reservations so we ended up at the Sunset location instead.

The space is very narrow, felt a little claustrophobic but I really liked the wall decor..  When we went it was really cold and as a result, the glass windows were very very steamy.  The table we were seated at was right by the door and kind of cramped. 

 While the food was delicious as usual... the service was pretty slow since they only had a 3 servers for the entire restaurant. That coupled with the small cramped space made the dining experience a little less pleasant than what I'm used to at the Marina location. 

We ordered the Shabu Shabu with Wagyu Beefa and added the duck on the side with Spicy Miso Broth..

Beggers can't be choosers, but if I had a choice, I would go to the Marina location as I've had a better dining experience there.
author: Milton F.

description:
I am debating...three stars, four stars, three stars, four stars...

Why 3 stars?
I thought the food was a bit overpriced, though good quality.  The meals start at about $23 for the smaller portion, but for $27 you get an extra row of meat (about 4 extra pieces).

The veggies included some cabbage, spinach, shitake and enoki mushrooms, carrots, and tofu.  Portion size of each was pretty small (two small pieces of tofu, a few thin slices of carrots, one small bunch of enoki mushrooms, etc...).

Portion size was good for a somewhat normal size meal, but if you are hungry, this may not be the best value.  As you can see, i am not impressed with their cost/portion size.

Why 4 stars?
The wait staff was awesome and incredibly friendly.  The miso broth was tasty and doesn't have any MSG or other things, so it also healthier than most other broths you will have with hot-pot style dinners.

The soy dipping sauce in combination with the kobe style beef was pretty fantastic...i probably haven't had a better combination at a hot-pot style place...simple and delicious.

At the end of the meal, they use the broth, reduce it down, and make a rice porridge type dish to end the meal.  I would have to say that this was the best part of the meal and something i am definitely not used to...but probably the main thing worth going back for.

So...three stars or four stars?  Three stars or four stars?

Happy Eating!
author: Bradley H.

description:
Been wanting to come to Nabe for a while after my bf moved to inner sunset since a friend said it's her fave restaurant. I think Nabe is so yummy, kinda pricey, but every time I come I leave happy. 

My bf and I have now been here multiple times, and we usually always make a reservation an hour or two in advance just incase they're busy, thus we've never had to wait more than about 5 minutes. Every time we come we get the large beef wagyu shabushabu since it already comes with udon, and I'm an udon LOVER! We have tried both the miso and spicy miso, and enjoy both, but as people who like da spice, we usually go for spicy miso =). We also like to get an add on of mochi, even though its $4 for 6 tiny pieces...I LOVE MOCHI, and mochi wrapped in wagyu beef is so so good (also a couple of times they gave us 7 pieces, twas magical)!!! At the end they make a yummy zosui (rice porridge) with your leftover broth, and mmm it is so good, both my bf and I love porridge, so we are always happy for it at the end. Once they accidentally burned it, but we got extra for the inconvenience, which was very nice of the staff. On days where we are too full, we bring it home and eat it for lunch the next day, and mm it taste just as good! For dessert, we have only tried the butter mochi with ice cream, which is definitely worth it in my opinion. 

I definitely recommend Nabe, and maybe someday we will venture out and try out something besides our usual shabu shabu. Also just a warning, they don't have very good ventilation, so it gets quite warm inside.
author: Nina W.

description:
Meh. Average quality meats, decent broths, great service.

Pros:
+ Servers are very kind and patient
+ Sukiyaki broth is decent
+ Veggies were great
+ Interior is beautifully designed

Cons:
- Odd seating system
- Small restaurant means slightly cramped seating

Pro Tip:
+ Try ride sharing apps or muni since parking is limited and troublesome here
+ Make your life easier. Make reservations

Gripes:
On my most recent visit, I showed up at 6:30PM on a Thursday. There were 3 parties seated, so the restaurant was ~75% empty. Unfortunately, I could not be seated because they had multiple 7PM reservations, so I was informed I'd be seated at 7:15PM should the rezzies flake. My friend showed up several minutes later and was equally perplexed by the system. I don't blame the girl, she was kind. It just seemed kind of silly. She did eventually seat us 5-10 minutes later, maybe because she could sense our internalized annoyance at the system.

At the mid $20s price range, I'd expect better quality meats, especially since so many of the AYCE hot pot spots serve what appear to be tastier meats. The wagyu beef for my sukiyaki had a tougher texture than what I'm used to. I've also done the rice porridge each time with hopes that it'll be tastier next time. Yea, not happening. It's just too salty. The concept is nice though, and I can appreciate it.

I've tried this spot 3 times now. I'm good. Will stick to the other shabu and AYCE places.
author: Fanny W.

description: They sell breakfast and I think it's a fairly new thing! These Chinese Egg Crepes are so delicious! Below are the Tuna Rousong one and BBQ one! There's only three options. Original for $9.50, Tuna was $11 and BBQ was $13 (I'm not 100% sure of those prices but around that.) It's so good, but so expensive for what it is, so if you really want it, I highly recommend it, but it's not necessary to try.
author: Caitlyn S.

description:
Steam billows throughout the dining room, fogging up the floor-to-ceiling glass windows, as expectant diners line up out the door. Nabe is clean, trendy, and offers up high-quality Japanese hot pot. The service is attentive and the broths delicious. Arriving early on a Friday evening, my group was seated right away, but by the time we left, the place was packed and people were waiting out the door!

I tried the seafood yosenabe, which came with tons of seafood--shrimp, salmon, scallops, clams, and harusame (cellophane) noodles and tons of veggies like napa cabbage, mushrooms, pumpkin, and spinach. I also had the shabu shabu pot with a spicy miso broth and thin slices of tender Kurobuta pork, udon, and more veggies--both of these were fantastic, and though the portion sizes weren't huge, I found them to be just enough, and the quality of the ingredients was great! Each diner also had a little bowl of dipping sauce for the meats, which was the perfect complement. My only complaint was that the broths tended to be a little on the salty side (which is not too atypical). After the meal is done, you select one of the broths, and the server uses it to make a complementary rice porridge with egg and dressed with scallions on top--delicious!

Overall, Nabe was a fantastic Japanese hot pot restaurant--though the prices are by no means cheap, I'd definitely recommend giving this place a try. Come early or make a reservation to avoid the waits!
author: David K.

description:
Very pretty decor, light, furniture.  Like the clean open look with pleasant ambiance.

Service is slow.  One person ran around constantly.

The broth is too plain for hot pot.  Food portion is small and nothing special, except for the rice porridge cooking at the end.

Probably I would not return again.
author: Ivory B.

description:
The hot pot was pretty good. The dashi broth wasn't too flavorful or strong, but it was still yummy. 

The rice dish they make in the end though - BOMB!!! I give this porridge 5 stars lol. Can I come back just for the porridge tho?
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Really nice spot for hot pot. As far as I can tell, they do not have all you can eat. But honestly that's ok. It was nice to have a hot pot experience that I didn't walk away from completely incapacitated. At the end they make you a savory porridge from the rest of one of the broths at the table.

Feels slightly upclassed from your typical hot pot spots. You'll still leave with the smell of food pungent on your clothes, but you'll also feel kinda good about it. Would come back here
author: Andrew C.

description: Upscale hot pot restaurant, no AYCE option. Price for one pot is 23- 29 not including add on.... We got 3 people with orders of duck breast pot, shabu shabu pot and 2 appetizers! Complimentary porridge is definitely an A plus for this place! It tastes good with seaweed! Yummmm
author: Jenny N.

description: Really nice staff and tasty Japanese hot pot! The sukiyaki was beautifully presented and so good! I liked the large cuts of wagyu that came with it. They were really thinly sliced, but cut in giant squares. We also tried the spicy miso Shabu shabu, but I didn't really like that broth as much. It was just regular miso with a handful of dried chili pepper flakes in it. At the end the waiters come out and make a 'rice finisher' porridge from your leftover broth with rice, egg, green onions, and nori flakes on it. Tasty!
author: Alice L.

description:
Hubs & I made some reservations for us and some friends, before a concert, one evening. The place its self was small. There were quite a few people waiting. I would definitely recommend reservations to avoid a long wait. The line went outside and down the way. 

   We were seated fairly quickly. We were still waiting for our friends. We ordered some appetizers & sake to get started. Hubs got a glass of plum wine. 

   Our appetizers were good, no complaints, as was the sake and wine. Our friends arrived we all split a few things. 

   I shared double portion of Seafood Yasenabe with a friend. My husband shared a double portion of Sukiyaki with another friend. Everything was very visually pleasing, very appetizing presentation.

   In all honestly my Seafood Yasenabe wasn't super flavorful. I was a bit let down. I had higher hopes. It was just decent. The broth just wasn't super flavorful to me. 

   My husband and our other guest enjoyed their SukiYaki. They ordered an extra plate of Wagyu and a plate of Miyazaki. Both beef plates were splendid. 

   I'm torn on weather we would give this place a shot again or go elsewhere. They do offer to make your leftovers into a porridge to take one. We unfortunately were unable to take it because we were not going home. I heard it's fabulous though! 

   I would say 3-3.5 stars
author: Krista B.

description:
Lately I have been obsessed with this place. I always get the shabu shabu with spicy miso broth and wagyu beef. The quality of the beef is just so good and you can definitely tell when you eat it (but only if you cook it to be a nice medium rare aka don't leave each slice in there for more than a couple seconds). 

They make the rice porridge thing for you at the end of your meal. The waiter will come over and ask which broth you want to use and cook it all up with rice egg, seaweed, and other stuff, in the same pot you were eating from.

Others I've gone with get the sukiyaki, which is v good too. Haven't tried the sake but it's probs bomb with your meal. I will say tho that if you have a large appetite, you may want to grab a quick snack before you go!
author: Stephanie K.

description: Overall my experience at Nabe was good, and I did like the food. I came on a Sunday and the wait was pretty long, and it did get really steamy and hot inside. However, the staff was really helpful. I really liked how they made our shabu shabu into a kanji at the end of the meal. The experience was great. If you are hungry, definitely go for a large, and then maybe get a few sides too if you are a big guy. Nabe is not the best shabu shabu in town, but it is a solid spot to check out!
author: Ross S.

description:
Nabe has and will always hold a special place in my heart - whenever I want a meal that won't ever disappoint, Nabe never fails me. 

Service 5/5: The service at Nabe is always great, the waitresses are attentive and quick. They're really nice people with a common goal to make your meal an enjoyable experience.

Food 5/5: The food here never disappoints me, make sure you try the different options here. The duck shabu is a new one for me, I really enjoyed that one. I personally took out the duck meat before the soup cooked it entirely or else it would kill the flavor. My SO enjoys the Sukiyaki set, which offers a sweeter broth. The porridge at the end nicely complements the overall meal :-)

5/5 Come here for your next shabu meal, you won't regret it!
author: Nicholas H.

description: Not too bad not too dope! The porridge in the end is the hightligt! Must try Sesame ice cream and the crispy mochi cake! I will just go there for the desert.
author: Ying L.

description:
I've always wanted to try out this restaurant as this is one of the only few restaurants I found in CA that serves fresh raw egg for dipping with their sukiyaki. (Due to Salmonella concerns, most restaurants in CA don't serve raw eggs). 

We ordered their Sukiyaki and Kamonanban. Food is average and the broth needs a little more flavor and more noodles in my opinion. The wagyu meat + the raw egg combination was heavenly though! It's how a sukiyaki should be.  

Servers are friendly and helpful and very knowledgeable of the menu. Place is a little tight though with not enough room to move around. Parking is difficult for the day we went (Sunday night) however we were seated fairly quickly. Price is reasonable. I would come back to try their sake flight.
author: Christian Darren B.

description: Amazing hot pot, great meat!! try their kimchi soup base, we loved it! The vegetarian option was good too! Will recommend this place for hot pot.
author: Roma M.

description:
3 stars for the nabe set but +1 for the rice porridge at the end

Normally I'm not a big hotpot/shabu/nabe person, but given all the cold and rainy weather we've been experiencing in SF recently, I find myself craving more of these hot and soupy meals.

I heard from a friend about how Nabe makes zosui (or rice porridge) for you at the end of your meal and was highly intrigued by this idea, so I hightailed it over here to check it out.

The two of us arrived a little after they opened at 5 on a Saturday, and it was mostly empty. However, it turns out all tables but two were already reserved, so I highly recommend making reservations. We were sitting near the door, and we saw a lot of people walk-in and get discouraged by the long wait time and leave.

My friend and I opted to share a regular Kamonanban ($25), which is duck breast, leeks and soba in dashi broth. We also ordered some additional sides of shirataki (the thin clear yam noodles), the assorted mushrooms, and an extra order of enoki. Yes we really love our mushrooms! 

The way it works here is, instead of cooking each item separately in the nabe pot as you would at a hotpot place, each nabemono set already has all of the ingredients in it (but raw) when it is brought to your table. Once you place the nabe pot on the stove, it'll slowly start simmering and gradually the ingredients inside will cook. Any additional add-on items will be brought on the side and those you can add at your leisure.

The quality of the duck meat was fine, but some pieces had a lot of fat that I ended up taking off. We left the soba in the boiling dashi broth for too long and they started breaking apart, so I'd recommend eating those early on. 

I didn't like the fact that there was only one dipping sauce that I thought might've been ponzu sauce. I wasn't a big fan of it, and that dampened my enjoyment of the meal a little bit. 

My favorite part of the meal came at the end, when the server dumped some extra rice into our leftover broth and made a nice thick rice porridge from it. I was already stuffed from the meal, but somehow my friend and I managed to scarf it all down.

I would love to come back and try another nabe set and eat their yummy rice porridge again!

We paid about $25 pp after tax and tip.

Parking in this area is all street parking. I had a pretty easy time finding parking on the same block as the restaurant, perhaps because it was still a little early for dinner (around 5) when I parked.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Things to do in/near Golden Gate Park: EAT AT NABE (after exploring the park, of course).

My boyfriend and I went to Golden Gate Park in the early afternoon to visit the De Young Museum and Japanese Tea Garden. We spent ~4 hours there...so we were pretty exhausted and hungry. I wanted to try Nabe since my friend recommended it, so we came right when the restaurant opened. We were seated immediately - because we came on a Wednesday at 5p - and the restaurant was almost half-full by the time we left at 6p. 

The interior of the restaurant is very modern yet cozy. The lights are a little dim, but I guess that makes the setting more calm and romantic. There's also 1 stove for every 2 people - so you can choose to share (max 2 people per pot), or if you don't share, they will split the pot in half.

For starters, we ordered PORK SAUSAGE which came with mustard aioli. The sauce just tasted like Japanese mayo to me, but we both really liked the sausage. The dish came with 4 decently sized sausages, and they were very juicy and flavorful. I also really liked the texture of the outside skin since it had a slight crispiness to contrast the juicy meat.

We shared a LARGE SUKIYAKI pot. It came with a nice assortment of veggies, 1 egg (we ordered another egg add-on so each of us would get one), some kind of vermicelli, 1 bowl of rice (we ordered another as add-on), sweet broth, and beef. The overall experience was very fun - we got to watch the soup heat to a boil, crack our egg inside, and add the pieces of beef.  Then we got to ladle food from the pot into our bowl to eat with rice. Everything tasted fresh and the beef was good quality. My boyfriend thought the broth was too sweet for his liking, but it was fine for me (with a sweet tooth).

At the end, the server made a porridge by combining rice, egg, and green onion with our leftover broth. Since I ate a lot of broth earlier, I thought the porridge pretty much tasted the same as my main meal - but the nori topping gave my taste buds something salty to contrast with everything I ate thus far.  

In conclusion, we left with very very full and satisfied bellies. The service was excellent too. And a funny thing we noticed was that the windows get really really foggy because the restaurant turns into a sauna compared to the cold outdoors. I'm definitely bringing my friends and family here again!
author: Sarina C.

description: I came with my friend and we both decided to get the large spicy miso broth. One of us got the beef while the other got pork. The food came pretty quickly and it all looked very fresh. When we cooked our udon and vegetables, everything cooked faster than we expected. The broth was good, not too spicy but a good amount. The napa cabbage cooked in the broth was pretty spicy though since it soaked up the broth. The meats were nice and tender! When you're done eating, the servers will offer to make porridge out of the remaining broth. It was entertaining to watch them make it, and it looked really weird, but the porridge was actually really good! The porridge part seemed so unique to me, and it was very tasty.
author: Lauren L.

description: Ordered the seafood pot and added additional beef. The beef is very satisfying, large and little chewy. The price is good as well. This is the restaurant if I don't eat it for a month, I would miss it! The seaweed soup is the best. I can say that this restaurant could be my top 3 restaurant which makes me most satisfied under $30 in the Bay.
author: Kelvin Y.

description:
SO GOOD!! I really loved the food here and the service was great too. Each person got their own pot and I ordered the duck - it comes with a lottttt of duck! Broth was delicious too and it also includes veggies and soba noodles. My friend got the wagyu and upgraded that - in my opinion it's worth the upgrade if you've never tried it before, but in the future I'll just stick with the regular wagyu since that was yummy enough. The beef upgrade was more soft and melt in your melt, but the wagyu was a little chewier/tougher which I also liked. That pot also came with udon noodles and veggies. 

Then... you get a rice porridge (complimentary) to end your meal so save a little room for that!! Also because you should get dessert there too:) the green tea cheesecake with sesame ice cream was a great ending. I was stuffed. Will be back!
author: Caley Z.

description: I seem to always be craving shabu shabu and theres no better place I've been to than Nabe. Its a small intimate little place with delicious options and friendly staff. I get the wagyu beef and spicy miso. Tried the traditional broth last time I was there but there wasn't a whole lot of flavor. My friends have tried the miso and liked it though so there is other options if you aren't a fan of spicy.  Their large platter is pretty big so I'd recommend sharing with one other person. Make sure to save room at the end because they use the both to make a savory porridge which is amazing. The prices are reasonable and they do have appetizer options along with a pretty big list of alcoholic drinks. So far during the week it doesn't seem too busy and you might get away with not having a reservation.  I recently went on a Saturday night and wasn't smart enough to have a reservation.  Luckily the lady waiting on tables was super patient and polite and took my name down while making sure to explain that it might be a 45min-1hour wait. My friend and I used the extra time to explore a bit and came back. There is a small bench outside but otherwise no real space to wait. Lesson learned though, reservations always especially with a place like this that is gaining popularity and gets pretty full.
author: Angela D.

description:
Always make a reservation or call in before coming in! It's usually packed on Friday and Saturday nights. I called last minute in on a Friday night and the employee immediately reserved a table for us! We got there in about 10min and we were able to be seated right away. 
I've only tried the wagyu beef shabu shabu with spicy miso. The shabu broth options are spicy miso, miso, and kombu. You get to choose one type of broth per set so if you have a party of two, you get a pot with a divider in the middle. They still give you a divider even if you get two of the same broths, which is really convenient if you have dietary restrictions or if you're sick and you don't want to share broths!
The spicy miso broth was pretty good. I love spicy food and the spiciness level is pretty mild. I like that they use wagyu beef instead of the usual kobe beef. I thought the meat quality was good but it was a little too tough and chewy. It's also served with udon, tofu, 3 types of mushrooms, napa cabbage, spinach, and carrots. They gave a sesame sauce and ponzu sauce, and I typically only like to use the ponzu at any hot pot place. I thought the ponzu was pretty salty, but it was good when I dilute it with a little broth. I love the porridge at the end! They add rice, egg and green onions to one of the broths. They also top it with seaweed but I opt for no seaweed. The porridge is so good but we were really full and just brought the rest home!
There's no AYCE options. They definitely chose quality over quantity. The prices recently increased to $22 for regular and $26 for large! I think it's slightly more expensive than average but you pay for quality!
Also, one major downside is that it was so hot and stuffy in there when it was packed. The glass walls in the front even start fogging up! They have ventilation but it's not nearly strong enough.
author: Emily L.

description: Says Japanese Miyazaki A5 wagyu beef but it tastes like A4. Here's a picture of what A5 looks like. I went to japan I know how it looks and taste like. Felt like I got rip off!
author: Phi S.

description:
Good service, like the ambience, though very loud and could use better spot lighting at night.

The ingredients are tasty and interesting, however the broth was bland.  We ordered the spicy miso with our shabu shabu and it tasted pretty watered down.  The soy based dipping sauce had more flavor.  The tea needs to be served hot as well, instead of heating it on the same range as the hotpot.  Our main set came out pretty quickly after the tea so there was no time for it to even warm. Portions of meat we're just right, but the portions of veggies we're on the skimpy side. Sake was delicious.

Overall pretty nice experience, albeit nosy and over priced.  One set,  small sake, tea, one starter,  two extra ingredients, and tax was more than $100
author: Andrea B.

description: I love their sukiyaki! It's a little bit pricey I'd have to admit, but the quality of meat you get here is really good. I like how they make the rice soup thing towards the end of your meal. It's a great finish. Giving a 4 star because this place gets a little stuffy inside with all the heat from the boiling pot. Other than that, no complaints.
author: jessica t.

description:
Really wanted to like this place as I've heard great reviews but my experience was only mediocre. Arrived on a weekday at 7pm and was seated immediately since we made a reservation. It's great that they take reservations cause the restaurant is small and I can imagine it filling up quite quickly. One of the servers' breath reeked of cigarettes which was such a turn off! I understand that individuals need to take smoke breaks during work but please chew some gum before speaking to your customers! 

As for the food, it was really nothing special in my opinion. My boyfriend and I decided to share the duck soup and the wagyu beef soup (can't seem to remember the names). Both were nothing special and lacked flavor. The only thing I really enjoyed was the rice porridge they made with your leftover broth in the end. 

I wouldn't mind giving this place another try but only if I'm in the area.
author: Lushi Z.

description:
With the mostly unpredictable (and mostly chilly) weather, I'm always in the mood for soups and broths. The obvious answer is hot pot! Which in this case, is shabu shabu. Not that I'm an expert in the difference, but I think it's the sauces and portions of the two that differ.

In this case, the boyfriend and I ordered a regular Sukiyaki and a regular shabu shabu. ($20 each). It came with two sauces: a soy sauce/ponzu flavored one and a sesame one. Both were great but the ponzu one could be stronger. Good portions surprisingly. We thought it wouldn't be enough, but ended up being very full! The veggies were mostly identical in both sets. The beef was good as well.

Absolutely loved the end of the meal! This part is dinner only: If you ordered the sets, the server will make a rice soup with the rest of your broth. The broth is heated, then a bowl of Zosui rice is added. Stirred for a few mins, then a raw egg is cracked in the mixture. Stir some more, add green onions, and it's finished. Topped with seaweed! It's so freakin' good. I would have bowls of this just by itself. This isn't offered for lunch, so if you're curious, definitely come for dinner!

Shout-out to the service. Came by at 8:45 PM on a Sunday night and the place was packed. Two (or three) servers took care of the whole restaurant and were really friendly/attentive. We never felt rushed (they close at 10 PM) or neglected.

Space is limited so make a reservation just in case. Est. $50 for two people.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Came here last night with two other people and I was really impressed!

We ordered two large pots. One Sukiyaki pot and another Shabu Shabu plate. The service was good, as our food came out fairly quickly. We ordered pork and beef respectively for our meats. The pots both came with an assortments of vegetables. 

The meats tasted good and the broths were good as well! The entire Shabu experience was really good here!

Plus at the end of the meal they make this rice porridge for you which is amazing! We all split the billl and it came out to about $20 a person.
author: James D.

description:
Hot pot is one of my favorites to eat whether it's hot or cold! This is definitely different from shabu or hot pot. The pot comes with the broth you choose and all the ingredients inside except for the meat. The meat comes out on a plate so you can cook it at your own pace. My friend got the kimchi pot and wow that flavor was spicy bit so tasty! I kind of regretted not getting it! I ended up with mushroom pot and added a side of beef. It was a simple broth that wasn't bland but had a good umami flavor to it. I really enjoyed this style of Japanese hot pot. 

At the end they make zosu with one of the broths at the end which was really good! We chose the kimchi pot, It was flavorful and the rice had a slight crunch to it. Definitely a place to come back again! The only thing I don't like about this place is the parking situation, it gets insane on weekends! But thankfully this place also takes reservations so you don't need to wait of you are able to secure one!

Total for 2: $50
author: Stella J.

description: Nabe is one of my favorite restaurants in SF :) I especially love the porridge thing they would do at the end with your leftover broth. I went here with a friend at 6:30pm on a weekend. I strongly recommend you to call ahead and make a reservation. I called around 5:50 to snatch the 6:30 table, so don't need to call too early either unless you have a large party. Service was good and very attentive. We ordered the Kimchi Pork broth and Shabu Shabu, both turned out to be amazing. We decided to use the kimchi broth for the porridge and that was probably the best part of the entire dinner. We spent about $30 after tax and tip which is a little on the expensive side but I think it's totally worth it for occasional enjoyments!
author: Angel C.

description:
In our group of 6 we shared two pots, each with 2 of its own soups.

I feel like for the most part this place was just okay. I'd rather get individual, pre fixed hot pot at tasty pot than come to Nabe. Everything was good and tasted great but I just didn't think the portion size was very good. It cost a little over $20 and it's not AYCE so i didn't feel like it was really worth it but I have no complaints about quality of food.
author: Mimi T.

description:
If you are craving for spicy miso then this place isn't it. Their spicy miso doesn't have a lot of flavor and wasn't spicy. I do recommend the **Kamonanban, its served with duck breast, leek, soba with dashi broth. $29 dollars for the large. The broth was very good and especially great with the porridge they make for you with the remaining of the broth. Good flavor and very tasty. The duck was very soft and tender. Leave room for the free (duck) porridge. It was delicious! 

We also started with some appetizers. **Kimchi Hiyayakko Cold Tofu. Refreshing and spicy. 
**Kurobuta Gyoza With Chili Ponzu - They were tiny. Came with 6 of them. It wasn't bad. 

You are able to make reservations over the phone. Services was good. The staff was friendly. Small restaurant. Will come back for the duck but everything else was just okay. Everything else was kinda pricey.
author: Sandy B.

description: My boyfriend and I don't roam around a lot in the City and I realized that I will be visiting SF more often I decided to check on yelp some hot pot locations near his area. Nabe popped up on my feed after a few searches... I'll say this.......... this is by far the best restaurant for hot pot I have ever been to. It is very typical for me to say this but it is seriously so good! If i could i would honor 15 stars! The staff is friendly, the food is great, quick and fresh! I would stay here and write a long review but i would be coming back often that I know there will be 100 great things to say about Nabe! Wagyu beef is my favorite! I will be back! I am a returning customer and I recommend others to come and try NABE!
author: Sheryl H.

description:
Pros: food is delicious, service is good
Cons: store is crowded and it feels like there is no ventilation system whatsoever, lots of smoke and it gets super warm inside. Also the portion is relatively small.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Floor-to-ceiling glass windows.
Pinterest-worthy wall decor of sake in wooden case dispensers.
Water served in pink and blue frosted sake bottles.
Sleek modern furniture.
Wooden utensils.
The classiness of not smelling like kBBQ.
Enter Nabe, Inner Sunset's suave shabu shabu place.

It's a cool ambiance with a general bouge feel, but overall I found it lacking flavor and more pricey for what it's worth. Yes it's locally sourced organic etc., which unfortunately doesn't translate to tasty. The broths were mediocre, and the portions were tiny (meat was sliced *paper-thin*!) I think we ordered a beef and a pork thing and added some noodles and mochi, but I don't remember exactly because it wasn't all too memorable. The redemption factor was the yummy rice broth at the end that everyone raves about. Overall though, $20 later, we were all still hungry :(

I think Nabe would be the best for a girl's night out (or maybe a date to impress a girl who really like ambiancey places). The food is nothing mind-blowing, but you feel so SF eating overpriced organic shabu and sitting in a pretty restaurant with a crowd outside waiting for your table.
author: Edna C.

description: Great Japanese Dinner experience tonight at Nobe. Thank you for tasty fresh food and cooking experience. Now, thanks to pleasant Nobe staff, I feel I can cook Japanese dishes as a professional cook :)
author: Gregory F.

description:
Upon entering this quaint restaurant, the sweet aroma just fills you up. I already fell in love with the flavors of the restaurant just from its scent. The four of us were seated in about half an hour even after we called in over an hour earlier to put our name down. The wonderful thing about this place is that the pot is great for two with an additional order of meat as my friend recommended. We ordered the Spicy Miso Shabu Shabu set ($20 regular/$24 large) and the Sukiyaki set ($20 regular/$24 large). Each of those came with assorted vegetables and an order of Wagyu beef. We ordered another two plates of Wagyu beef ($12 each regular) and Duck Breasts ($16 regular) as an add-on. First of all, this place is pretty pricey, but the flavor and quality is absolutely worth the splurge.

Although I had the Spicy Miso pot, I also tried the Sukiyaki and absolutely fell in love with it. The sweet and salty flavor was unique and tasteful. I kept refilling my bowl with the soup to drink, yum. In the end, you also get to choose one of your soups to make into a porridge and of course we chose the Sukiyaki flavor. The porridge is mixed with rice, green onions, egg, and seaweed. I never knew it could taste so delicious! The food here is definitely something I'd be back for, but the service not so much. It took forever for us to be seated, forever to order, forever to get our checks so that's where they lose a star. Also, it's a very cramped and tiny restaurant, so not much moving room.
author: Cindy Z.

description: The food was awesome but the stars really go to the service; Anna was such a kick ass waitress, she was so patient and explained everything to us. She took such great care of us, what an awesome lady. Will be back if she's still around!!
author: Valerie H.

description: We ordered the tako su octopus salad, the shabu shabu, and the seafood yosenabe. The spicy miso broth for the shabu shabu was spicy/savory and the dashi broth for the seafood yosenabe was sweet/savory. The wagyu beef that came with the set was not fatty at all (which we like) and of good quality and the seafood that came with the other set was of wide variety too! We really enjoyed the porridge at the end of the meal as well. Also, their service was great! They were able to sit us super fast on a Friday night even after we were told that the wait would be about 30 minutes!
author: Grace M.

description:
My friend and I decided to come try this place out after a night out. We both ordered the large plate of meat with veggies. I have to say I really like the meat and how thinly sliced it was. I would have to say its like your typical shabu place but the only difference is that you order by plate, and at the end they make this porriage out of your left over soup. The porriage was pretty amazing, and flavorful. 

Overall service was great, the only thing I didn't like was that the place is pretty small, so it does get stuffy and you see the doors steamed up. And also call ahead of time, because they are always packed even on a weekday.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Terrific food at every turn. 

Soy edamame were savory and topped with copious amounts of garlic. I ended up spooning some of it into the broth. Spicy miso broth was robust and just the right spice for me (3/5). 

Veggie assortment was on par with other places but a surprise squash added unexpected pizzaz.

End of meal porridge was actually just as good as the meal itself and I was scrapping the pot for every last drizzle. 

Impeccable service for such an affordable spot. Will be returning again and again.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Nabe is definitely more expensive than AYCE chinese hot pot, but I think much like KBBQ, what you lose in quantity you gain in quality for about the same price. I think considering that I'm not a very big eater anyway, it ends up working out about the same for me. 

Both times I've been here, I've split the large Kamonanban with my boyfriend. The first time we came here, it was fairly late and I remember the presentation of the hot pot was beautiful! The second time we were here it was around normal dinner hours and they were obviously much busier, and the presentation wasn't as visually stunning. Luckily though both times tasted just as great. I really like how flavorful and rich their broth is. I always die a little on the inside when they scoop out the excess when making the final porridge at the end...haha! Anyway the Kamonanban is extremely satisfying. It won't leave you totally stuffed, which is kind of a nice thing because then you can get dessert! The mochi cake with ice cream is simple but very satisfying. Definitely try it, especially if you've never tried mochi cake before!
author: Stephany L.

description: Excellent service, good food and respectful staff. This place is a must try. We went to this place just 20 minutes prior to closing on a Sunday evening and they were gracious to let us in. It was my first time having hot pot and they took extra care to help us enjoy the meal.
author: John S.

description: We had Wagyu and Duck hot pot order.  This is the best in ambiance, flavor, quality of ingredients, service and sake options of all hot pot in California.  Hard to top this level of all around quality.  Be prepared to afford.
author: Eddie T.

description:
Japanese hotpot spot. The appetizers were fairly good, we ordered the gyoza, which was crispy, and the filling was tasty, perfect amount of meat, lightly seasoned so as to not over power the flavor of the meat. The sausage we had was sweet and the aioli sauce complimented it very well.  The disappointed came in the broths for the main, which was the hotpot. Since that was the whole premise of that restaurant, it was a little important that the base broth is good...in my opinion, the broth for the duck combination was quite tasty and flavorful but the other broths that my friends ordered were a little bitter or stale tasting. So it was hard to enjoy their meal with an off tasting broth. 

Despite the great décor and presentation of the food, not overly impressed with the food.
author: Irene H.

description:
Came for dinner on Friday night.  The place is small so we had to wait a bit even with a reservation.

Overall the hot pot was good but a little more than one should pay for hot pot.  We ordered a cucumber salad to begin with and it was served in a tiny bowl ($7). 

We ordered 2 hot pots (liked the option with duck) and 2 sides of extra veggies (also a little overpriced for a side of veggies).  Since two of us had already eaten lots of snacks beforehand, we weren't too hungry but the servers kept making comments about why we weren't ordering more or ordering larger sizes.

Overall the hot pot was good but very salty which I really felt the next day. 

Would likely go elsewhere for hot pot.
author: Siv L.

description:
Came here on a weekday with two friends. We waited roughly 10-15 mins for a table to open up and the staff was kind. 

We ordered a large shabu shabu and the Kinoko Nabe split. It came with side of beef, veggies, spinach, and tofu. We also ordered a side of pork belly as well. 

Overall, service and food was good. For SF price ranges, it's pretty typical but for three people with 3 different sets our bill came out to $100 after tip. For the price, I didn't think the food was worth it. There are other AYCE hot pot places and even KBBQ places that are from the 24.99-29.99 price range, and thats AYCE!

The rice porridge at the end of the meal was nice, but I don't think I would come back. There are other places I rather go out on a nice dinner than here. You get full from eating the carbs (rice, noodles, udon) rather than the meat and veggies. There are better hot pot places for a better value else where.
author: Brian L.

description: After a sunny afternoon stroll along Ocean Beach in San Francisco, sharing the shabu shabu with Waygu beef was delicious and satisfying!  Restaurant was cleanly designed, unpretentious, and the service was impeccable. Would definitely return!
author: Evelyn C.

description:
The service is really great and attentive. I like that they make you this little hearty porridge with the remaining broth and egg at the end. The restaurant is small but nicely decorated.

The food is average though. Broths are okay and I wish they gave me more green onions in my sauce. 

I probably wouldn't go back since it's so far from where we live. The four stars is for the service. The ladies are really nice!
author: T L.

description:
Nabe is authentic Japanese Hot pot. This is my favorite hot pot place in the city. Its usually pretty easy to get seated here, just call maybe 20-30 minutes ahead of time to check.

My favorite stock is the Seafood and the Kimchee. Seafood is totally worth it, you get a good size portion of food, and the broth from the Seafood is the best in my opinion. At the end they turn your broth into a porridge, which is nice.
author: Jess Y.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend on a Tuesday around 7 PM and there was literally no wait. We both decided to share a Sukiyaki large pot. Granted, it was not a lot of food, but this was expected and we both weren't too hungry. It was absolutely delicious! The soup was so flavorful, the wagyu beef was tender, and the veggies had good variety. The ponzu sauce was okay in my opinion, and we both preferred to use the raw egg dipping sauce. My favorite part of the meal was the complementary rice porridge at the end. It was honestly a great way to use the rest of the soup (the soup is so good, I was prepared to finish it regardless!).  

Our servers were extremely attentive and polite, and the restaurant had a classy, but casual atmosphere. I would most definitely come again! Nabe is easily now one my top 5 favorite restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Vivian L.

description: My favorite hot pot place. Great quality and nice selection of sake ( expect to pay more tho). I always go back when I don't feel like eating AYCE. This is the only place that I can share the pot with my bf who is not a fan of hot pot and don't eat much. Really love the porridge at the end! I admit there are times I dine there just for the porridge haha
author: Ada L.

description: I have dinner here with my roomies. Nothing but hot pot can warm u up in the rainy days. One shubashuba pot and one kimchi pot. Both are delicious in their own flavor.  I love the pumpkin and high-quality beef best. Also the broth tastes a little bit like Thai food. Although the dishes doesn't look much, we are all very full and satisfied.
author: Tianlu W.

description: Nice service and the hot pot was so delicious. She was so nice alway come and check on us. The price of the foods was reasonable. It was worth it! I recommend and for sure go back there soon!
author: Ploypailin A.

description: Great services and delicious food. Surprisingly my jacket didn't smell bad after the dinner
author: Hoang L.

description: We are so lucky that Nabe is our neighborhood shabu place!  The food is delicious and very good quality.  The beef has nice marbling and is very tasty.  Veggie plate has a good assortment and is fresh.  I recently came here for a girls night out.  Nancy, our server, was the best!  She provided timely and excellent service.  And, she made the best rice porridge!  We will definitely be back.
author: Doris W.

description:
Finally a hot pot restaurant that uses high quality meats!! Thank goodness!  Most hot pot is all about quantity and uses the cheapest possible mean and seafood, with slimy veggies of dubious freshness.  This place breaks the mold with organic and grass fed slices of beef.  

A few things they could do better:

- open during lunch!  Yes, people eat hot pot as lunch
- offer a spicy Szechuan broth and a spicy Mongolian broth (I know the theme is Japanese but it would not take much to offer those broths)
-expand the menu.  They obviously have a full kitchen.  They should use it.
author: M S.

description: This place is one of my favorite hot pots in the bay area. They do variety of different Japanese hot pots. Most other Japanese hot pot places only do shabu. I like the different choices of hot pots to choose from. Their menu is simple and quality is great. Very clean and friendly. Felt like being in an establishment in Japan. I recommend this place to all my friends that enjoy hot pot. The wagyu is delicious and they cut it at the right thickness. Some places cut it paper thin. Give Nabe a try!
author: James P.

description:
This place is great, and I am very grateful to have it in our neighborhood.
The real deal as far as Shabu Shabu is concerned.
author: Ken M.

description:
For a place as popular as this, you would think they wouldn't take reservations, but they do! This is great because both times I've been here, there's been a line, and the restaurant is pretty small/narrow and has limited tables/seating available. They recently opened a second location in Marina/Cow Hollow though, and I think that location is bigger.

This place has replaced Shabu House as my favorite shabu restaurant! The different options they have all sound so appealing it was hard to pick one. We got a split pot of the seafood shabu and the mushrooms one (vegetarian, but has four different kinds of mushrooms). Both were quite good, although we enjoyed the seafood a little more. The clams I ate (about six in the large seafood shabu) had sand in them though. We also ordered a side of wagyu beef that was EXCELLENT. Such good meat. 

The coolest thing about this place is that they make you a complimentary porridge at the end of your meal to top it off (and is great if you don't quite get full off of shabu)! They use the leftover broth (if you have multiple, you pick the one you want them to use) and put some rice, egg, green onion, seaweed. Sooo yummy. I'm usually pretty full by then, so I take it to go and then I have another meal :)
author: Josephine L.

description:
I am still confused why they did not serve saseme sauce.......
There was only one sauce served-Ponzu sauce. I had two others friends who didn't care much about food, so I didn't question them about this. One sauce is the biggest flaw to me, it made the Shabu less complicated. 
Meat is good, broth is standard. They made savory rice pudding using the left over broth in the end. This idea is new and creative, but the leftover broth is too salty which made the pudding not very tasty. 
Service was standard, nothing to complain about.

I saw the reviews of the newly opened one is better than this one, so I might give that one another shot. I am not coming back to this one for sure.
author: Pink M.

description:
Yummy shabu shabu place!
I ordered extra toppings because I didn't know how much vegetables come with the basic sukiyaki pot. They turned out to have plenty of mushrooms, tofu, and cabbage to begin with, so I recommend getting toppings after you see what comes with the pot. Me and my girlfriend gobbled everything up. The broth and the meat were so good. And they have cool servers.
author: Haein K.

description:
Nabe on Lombard is one half of a two store chain run by a brother and sister team. Extremely popular with Millennials and Young families . Clean , minimalist lines in the decor ,food features Shabu Shabu and Sukiyaki hot pots . Gyoza is above average and a good prelude to the main courses. Rice tends to be tough , possible arefact of sitting around too long in the rice cooker .
The broth is a bit sweet , possibly as a concession to most customers who like their food to be sweet .
The A5 beef is definitely worth a splurge , the Wagyu is wonderfully marbled and Flavorful especially when washed down with Ice cold Asahi  super dry.  The service is efficient and welcoming .
The wait out front even on a Monday night is a testimonial to the pleasing decor , good food and fine hospitality .
author: Shariq Y.

description:
Excellent service and a dark, intimate ambiance. Would be cute for a higher end hot pot date night! 

They do split pot on one stove per two people. 
I usually go with the sukiyaki with their wagyu beef. The sukiyaki broth is a little on the sweet side, but it makes for a delicious congee combo when they add rice to the leftover broth and reduce it to a tasty treat. It makes for AMAZING leftovers. The congee is their house special and included in the price for the shabu sets (why it's more expensive than other places). 
The shabu shabu broth is good too, very traditional. And the spicy shabu is really spicy so make sure you can handle it. 
The veggies and sides that come with the sets are fresh (comes with napa cabbage, mushrooms, tofu, carrot slices, kabocha slices, and either udon or clear Soba noodles). Rice provided upon request too. As for meat portions, the large set is enough for me to finish on my own if I'm hungry (which is every time I come here) and the regular set is only a few pieces less.
author: Audrey D.

description:
Nabe is the standard by which I rate all the hot pot places I go to.  I guess what they say is true--there's no love like the first. I'm fairly new to hot pot, so I don't know much, but this place is untouchable compared to all the other hot pot joints I've been to since. Although I know east coast hot pot (specifically in the south) is child's play compared to west coast hot pot joints, Nabe still sets the bar. 

I can only dream of the Wagyu beef that we had with our Sukiyaki Nabemono until we visit SF again. And that won't be soon enough.
author: Carlyne M.

description:
A really nice addition to the neighborhood, especially since Hotei is no longer in business.  It's a shabu shabu place rather than a noodle shop but either way it's nice to have a local option for hot Japanese soup.

This place gets pretty crowded but my wife and I were fortunate enough to get seated within 10 minutes of showing up.  They have a nice selection of different broths and food items to cook in it.  We got the mushroom platter which comes with miso broth... ordered a side of fish cake for extra protein.  I'll say that the miso was nice if not great...a bit on the bland side but I tend to like strong flavors so your mileage may vary.  It's not clear from the menu but there exists an option for "spicy miso broth" so if you want miso with a bit more kick be sure to tell your server, we had some of that and I found it much more to my liking, The mushrooms and other veggies themselves were very nice, especially the trumpet mushrooms.

I would be remiss if I did not comment on the specialty sake flight I had.  WOW!  Definitely a stand out.  I don't know how it compares to the similarly priced premium sake flight or the cheaper standard flight but the unfiltered and pearled sake on offer with this flight were top notch, definitely a nice experience for $20 and reasonably generous (albeit still small) pours for each.
author: Alan S.

description:
I would've to say that Nabe is the only Shabu Shabu restaurant that makes me want to come back over over and over again, I can have their hot pot 3 days in a row i would say, not only Nabe has the best authentic Japanese hot pot taste to me, but it also very creative in the way they use the left over broth to make rice porridge in no time (isn't it sound great!!). Not to mention their special desserts, that no restaurants can imitate- green tea cheescake and the homemade mochi cake(served hot with ice cream, which is a must try). 
Also, the staffs are really really sweet, I love them all
author: Kerry P.

description: Perfect for a midweek date night where it's not crowded. We shared the sukiyaki with extra egg, large plate of meat, ramen, and 2 rice bowls. It was more than plenty, probably should not have gotten the rice bowls. We ended up taking the rice porridge to go and ate it the next morning, it was delicious. Smart to do the porridge so the yummy broth doesn't go to waste.
author: Mary L.

description:
Was roaming the streets in SF one Sunday morning after a long night spent on Polk St. and was in serious need of hot soup. I'm not a personal lover of hot pot, but Erick is hot pot's #1 fan. Hot pot and shabu together?? You can guess why we ended up at Nabe - it's like a dream come true.

The place is fairly small, and we ended up waiting for 15 min. to be seated. We had the Sukiyaki and Spicy Miso broth. Sukiyaki wins hands down, but it became sort of salty toward the end of the meal. The Spicy Miso didn't have much flavor and also wasn't that spicy. This clearly disappointed Erick, since he loooves his spicy food. 

The meat was pretty good quality, in comparison to many other hot pot/shabu restaurants I've been to. +1 for that.

Everything was tasty, service was great, but I just wouldn't recommend it if you're looking for something spicy!
author: Christina L.

description:
Nabe is the perfect meal to have especially in the Sunset where it is normally cold.  When I got there on a weeknight, there were already people waiting.  Ideally it would be nice to wait inside, but there is limited waiting space inside.  Use caution if you do wait inside as the door swings inward ( I think this might be a fire code violation).   Seating inside is tight and not ideal for large groups, unless you come right at opening.

I ordered the nabemono sukiyaki set, which is wagyu beef, shirataki (noodles) with warishita  broth. The set comes with assorted vegetables and rice.  Also got the spicy miso broth with an extra add on of pork and shrimp.  The warishita broth was better than the spicy miso.  The spicy miso was bland.   I finished off my meal with the zosui.  The zosui is like a rice porridge similar to Chinese jook.  It's packed with flavors since you are using the same soup base and all the ingredients that were cooked into your broth. 

Service was excellent.  The servers were attentive and kept our broth filled.  To me that's pretty important when having nabe or shabu.
author: Peter C.

description: Came here right after visiting the California academy of sciences. Best timing since Nabe opens at 5 and the science center closes at 5. We were the first to arrive, first to leave. Was a good idea since it got packed 30 mins after it opened. Had great quick service and bomb shabu shabu.
author: Christian P.

description: Haven't eaten here yet but Nancy was super helpful when picking up the phone and working with us when we were trying to find dinner!
author: Patricia P.

description:
My friends and I came to Nabe on a cold Saturday night at 7:30 PM. The wait was approximately 1.5 hrs, and after much deliberation and checking out other restaurants while the blisteringly chilly winds were fixated on making our toes and feet numb and our hungry stomachs even hungrier, we decided to just wait it out and finally got in ~ 9 PM. 

The restaurant was pretty small, but I really liked the interior. My friend and I got the beef suyaki (regular is $20), and my other friend got the spicy miso pork (~$24??). We also decided to get a 20 oz carafe of the first sake on the menu and it was around $40 :( The meal ended up being around $40 which... I mean... hot pot is kinda pricey to begin with but man, idk if I would do this again just because:

1. The wait is extremely long on the weekends (not sure about weekdays though).
2. Nabe is on the more pricier $$ than other $$ restaurants on Yelp.
3. The waiters didn't refill our water until the end when I had to ask them to. The restaurant is pretty dang small, so I don't get how they couldn't at least offer to refill the water ONCE. Our main waiter was kind of cool towards us and hardly smiled, but another waiter who made our rice thingy at the end was awesome and really friendly! So I'm conflicted with how I feel about the waiters/service lol. 

Other than all that, the food was really good and I thoroughly enjoyed the beef suyaki! My friends spicy miso pork was really intensely-feel-it-in-your-nostrils spicy haha, and I like spicy, but once you cooked the pork in it the broth at the end of the meal became less intensely spicy and was really yummy. I like how they added rice at the end too, that was a nice touch-- but the food and service better be AWESOME if we have to wait 1.5 hrs in the cold outside -_- The sake was good too, but I'm not a sake connoisseur so I don't think that prices going all the way up to $80 for a bottle is worth it. 

I'd give this place a 4 star if their service and prices had been better (as wait time can't be helped).

If you wanna check out a solid hot pot place I'd come back here for their lunch menu when it's probably less crowded and cheaper!
author: Joy K.

description: Hate to see another sellout in the City. Most places after they opened at more locations the overall experience declines to all degrees and it is no exception at Nabe. I cannot say it will be our last time since our 8 years old loves it there but I have to say we are not going return as often as we used to be (and no more large party with kids). This place is not kids friendly anymore and the newer waitresses does not give us the warmth that we once experienced. I do not want to share my experience in detail but if you have 9 year old and under do not go there. End of story. By the way, the definition of a yelp 2 stars reads "Meh. I've experienced better." and that place was Nabe. RIP "5 Stars Nabe" 2015 - 2016.
author: Wai C.

description: Their hot pots come out pretty much ready to eat--visually very inviting. The broths are flavorful--I personally prefer the savory broth of the duck nabe. The sukiyaki broth is a bit sweeter for anyone who's in the mood for something comforting and sweet. The porridge at the end is a very nice touch. Definitely worth going out to the Sunset for. Especially on a cold, foggy day when warm food is best!
author: Yad L.

description:
I was visiting SF for a week and I told my best friend to choose a place to eat for Christmas. She drools over my shabu shabu pictures in LA so she asked me to find a good shabu place in SF. Nabe is new and came highly recommended so we made reservations. MAKE RESERVATIONS, it's tiny!

Ambiance could be better... There's a loooooooooooong communal table in the middle and a few tables on the side. LUCKILY my bestie and I got our own table to the side. I would've hated to catch up in between a bunch of strangers. They use the space to the fullest extent... like there's barely any room for the waiters to move around AND it's a fucking sauna in there. It's so funny cuz the glass windows literally steam up and you can't see anything outside. Ok on the important part... the food.

You order a set of broth and meat and choose regular or large. The sets come with the items listed plus assorted veggies, noodles, and rice. You can also add veggies and more meat for an additional fee. I thought that the sets provided more than enough. For a party of 2, order these two sets to share... perfect combination!

+ Sukiyaki (wagyu beef and shirataki in warishita broth) - I liked their sukiyaki. Sometimes it can be TOO sweet or salty, but theirs is just right. Wagyu beef is super on point... really great quality. I highly recommend this set.

+ Shabu shabu (wagyu beef/kurobuta pork and udon in radition konbu, miso, or spicy miso) - get this with wagyu beef and SPICY MISO. I've had spicy miso at other locations and this one is by far the best spicy miso shabu I've ever had. I HIGHLY recommend. Again the wagyu beef is great and I don't think I'd ever stray from beef with shabu. 

+ porridge - What's different about Nabe that I really enjoyed was the porridge they make for you at the end of your meal. They simply ask you to choose a broth, add rice and condiments, and voila... delicious. 

Ask for their ponzu and goma sauce because I don't think they don't serve it automatically with your set. AND be sure to ask for garlic, green onions, daikon, and chili oil/powder (if you like spice) to add to each sauce. 

Nabe is missing one important ingredient - hot drops to add to the sauce. Every shabu spot in SoCal has this and it is a key component. LUCKILY we brought our own so the lack of it didn't kill our experience lol. Nabe, I suggest looking into it. 

I'm hoping they expand in the near future. This spot has so much potential.
author: Elysse P.

description:
My friend & I came to Nabe to try their shabu shabu. I ordered the regular sized ($19) shabu shabu with kurobuta pork with spicy miso broth. The order came with napa cabbage, spinach, pumpkin, shiitake mushrooms, tofu, udon, shimeji mushrooms, carrots, and a plate of kurobuta pork. The only difference between the regular and large size shabu is the amount of meat that is provided. 

The shabu shabu itself was average. I have had much better shabu elsewhere. However, after our meal, we were offered to have porridge with the leftover spicy miso broth and it was amazing. The waitress put in two bowls of rice into the leftover broth, turned the heat up, let it cook for a couple minutes, and slowly started taking some of the broth out so it wouldn't be soupy. She also added a scrambled egg, green onions and seaweed. My friend & I were pleasantly surprised at how amazingly delicious this was. However, I would most likely not return to Nabe for shabu. I'd return to try the sukiyaki and to have the porridge, but that's it.
author: Victoria H.

description:
My friend really likes this place so I decided to give it another try (this will be my second time coming here). My first time was okay - I didn't think it was anything special and I like Shabu House more. Second time - I still thought the same thing. The seaseme sauce is more watery than I like it to be. The beef wasn't as tender although it's supposed to be kobe beef. The sauce and meat at Shabu House is a lot better. The vegertable assortment is similar to Shabu House, except they have pumpkin at Nabe and you have to order it as a side at Shabu House so that's a plus for Nabe. The spicy miso broth is not that flavorful, I feel like all I tasted was spicyness whereas at Shabu House it was spicy and flavorful. 

The next time I'm craving shabu, I'll most likely go to Shabu House and not this place.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I love soup. Hot pot, shabu, noodle soup (minus the noodles). Yes I love broth, meat and veggies! When Nabe opened up a couple years ago, I had to check them out.

*Gyoza ($5) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#yFeasyDbFqzXYzuYTWne5A
*Scallop salad ($8.50) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#o19-3OcHNL50FMRUHo9jOg

*Split pot: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#uGiW6Ob3-RsSeoF7B5Yv8g

Shabu reg beef spicy miso ($18)
*Beef for Shabu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#_YK3hWKXJkY9en-F-lLshw
*Veggies for Shabu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#YgBeGcj5jGPvWpSJVYGONw
*Sauces for Shabu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#384LvXK6aGCglTBrzd54sw

Sukiyaki reg beef ($18)
*Beef for Sukiyaki http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#VwVoKhsKluQjV6nFm8lT_A
*Sauce for Sukiyaki http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#NfTF1sRtSTCmYILO9ATZow

*Topping for Zosui http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#B5nK2X3Aaeodu3DNpyqE0g
*Zosui with spicy miso broth http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3#2o0QZncvMPy1_30f793TiQ

I loved my shabu set. The broth was savory and spicy. The meat was tender. The veggies fresh. I didn't care for the roommate's sukiyaki set as it was overly sweet. So much so, that we stopped eating out of that side of the pot. I don't mind a hint of sweetness with my meat, but this was too much.

The porridge was a good way to end the meal, but by then, I was super full. Had a couple bites and I was done.

If the sukiyaki set wasn't so sweet, this would have easily been a 4-5 star review. But since we could barely eat it, 3 stars it is!
author: Elena N.

description:
Great service - the girls are super friendly, sweet, and helpful when I had questions with my order.

Yummy food - I've only tried the kimchi broth and it was not bad. I think it could definitely be spicier since we asked for extra chili oil and it did nothing. However, the pork belly and wagyu are good in addition to all the side veggies. Dipping sauces are yummy as well. Also, I love that they make porridge for you with your leftovers so save a little meat if you can and some room in your tummy for that.

Love the decor of this cute little restaurant - it's really small, but I was pleasantly pleased with the adorable wooden spoons and bowls.. I really just loved EVERYTHING about their style. It's perfect for a date or intimate dinner with friends. I recommend making reservations.
author: Jenn N.

description:
Modern decor, excellent combo of meats and broths, excellent service. 
So hard to find parking in this neighborhood!! But once we made it to the restaurant, we were rewarded with a great shabu dinner!! 
There are so many choices: wagyu beef, kurobota pork, seafood, duck... a wide selection of side items. 
This place does not offer tonkotsu broth, but a dashi broth, milder, cleaner tasting broth. The meat quality is outstanding! 
The 2 desserts that we had were so good I am tempted to come back just for the desserts alone. The matcha cheesecake was great, but the Mochi dessert was simply outstanding!!
author: lovetoeat a.

description:
Come early or make reservation (no need to be days ahead, maybe just when they open), it is a pretty small place, so it does fills up pretty quickly, and the wait is usually longer!

I like Duck and Shabu Shabu (beef), plenty of vegetables and the meat are pretty fresh. A bowl of rice comes with the pot.
