The Zosui (they use one of the soup base you have in your party to make porridge with eggs, rice, nori (seaweed) and green onions) is my absolutely favorite! I probably look forward to the zosui more than than the hotpot itself :3. If you think sharing someone else's pot base is disgusting or not sanitizing, just remember to set up rules beforehand to use extra set of chopsticks or the end of the chopsticks when putting food in/out of the pot? It is really delicious and you are missing out of not having it!!! If you just don't like porridge, nevermind then :p

Some people might think the portion is kind of small, but remember to save your stomach space for the Zosui in the end!!! Also good with big group (just reserve ahead).
author: Ya K.

description: Very good and affordable shabu shabu. Don't consume all your broth they will come at the end to make a preparation with an egg some rice and some spices! It is delicious!
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description: Mmmmm- love this place, such a treat! Both of the times I've gone I've gotten the shabu shabu wagyu beef with miso broth- so yummy dipped in the citrusy ponzu sauce. The veggies are nice but the main attraction was certainly the beef. My bf ordered the kombu broth once but we felt it was not nearly flavorful enough to spend $25 on (though I suppose it's the more traditional option). The service is also great, the women who work there are super helpful and friendly. The restaurant is quite small and the glass doors get steamy from all the hot pots but that just gives it a nice intimate aesthetic. You should expect long waits of 45 minutes (unless you call ahead) but there's a nice brewery across the street to help kill time. One of my fav places in SF!
author: Delaney B.

description: I know this place is highly reviewed on Yelp and there was a lot of promise going in, but for some reason, neither me nor my dining friends seemed to enjoy what Nabe had to offer. Personally, I had the Sukiyaki which is the wagyu with Warishita broth. While the wagyu itself was tasty, the broth simply had either too many mushrooms or some other spice that made it too herbal. It was evocative of an herbal ginseng soup that my parents would make me drink. And considering that the broth is supposed to be the star of any hotpot, I was left disappointed-the same story applied to my sister as well, who had the duck breast nabemono. We left unsatisfied and still hungry. If we're ever in the San Fran area we would maybe try again-but get something else entirely.
author: Chris H.

description:
Had such a great experience, went with my grandparents around 9:30 was able to get a reservation, while driving to the restaurant. The interior decoration was great, very japanese with an underlying  San Franciscan vibe. The location is great as well, the cool weather will always put you in a soup mood. The food was tasty, we went with the Nabe shabu shabu, and traditional kombu style. The meat was sliced perfectly, vegetables were fresh. The crowd is mostly College students, but not super rowdy, just very energetic. Will be returning try another great dinner.
And looking forward to the opening of the marina location.
author: Ari T.

description:
I made a reservation the morning of without any hassle. I'm glad I did because it was pretty packed when I came. 

My BF and I got the miso and Kim chi soups with veggies, mochi, pork belly and wagyu beef. It all tasted great! Afterwards you get to choose one soup to make into porridge for free. Also very yummy! It just sucks that you only get to choose one soup to make porridge with. We were with a group of four and we still only get one soup to make porridge. Boo.

Space wise, the restaurant is very narrow and pretty cramped so I wouldn't recommend big groups and I def recommend making a reservation. 

Tip: wear short sleeves because the poor ventilation made the hot pot experience even...hotter! The windows were so steamed up it reminded me of the scene from the titanic !
author: Elaine L.

description: Excellent service. I tried the vegetarian shabu shabu, which was delicious. They convert your leftovers into a porridge at the end too!
author: Riccha T.

description: Had a great hot pot dinner. At the end, they will add rice to your soup and make a delicious porridge. Yum.
author: Chase K.

description:
First time at Nabu ! 
Got the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU (miso) sets. Great customer service and very sweet and knowledgeable servers. Love the spicy drops that they have and the drops are NO joke. Really, you only need one or two drops in your pot (it has ghost peppers) and you're set! 

I especially love that they take your left over broth and make it into a rice porridge!
author: Karen C.

description: Service is good and the broths were tasty.  Loved the environment!  We had the sukiyaki beef and the miso broth.  I would recommend this place and visit again.
author: Corinne C.

description:
I've had my fair share of hotpot, and after coming here twice, Nabe would only hover near the middle of the list. While service is great, and the interior is classy, sophisticated, and beautiful, I always leave still feeling hungry. The first time I came, I shared a large pot with my friend, and the second time, I shared 2 pots with 3 friends. Next time, if I come back, I will get my own. 

I've tried the Sukiyaki and Shabu Shabu flavors,. Both are good but I prefer the Sukiyaki. At the end of the meal, they make a pretty good rice porridge with your leftover soup, adding egg, green onion, and rice.

Overall, good food, just pricey for the portion size.
author: Corinna T.

description: Great service, great food... The BBQ Pulled Pork Jiānbíng is the best! And their soy milk is also very delicious
author: Isabelle L.

description:
First of all, I must admit that I am not a fan of the whole idea of "hot pot".  I am not even that crazy about tabletop BBQ but the idea of boiling your own food at your own table is not my idea of dining out. If I have to cook my own food, I should get a discount. 

The place is very small and very cramped. The waitresses can barely move around. The room became quite warm and the windows were all steamed up. I was claustrophobic but maybe that was because I was up against the wall next to the kitchen.

The decor is very modern and stylish. I would say there is nothing special about the food. It is pretty standard hot pot fare - just vegetables and meat with a choice of sweet broths. The porridge made at the end is just leftover broth and rice with some added seaweed boiled for a few minutes until it is a mush. You top off your meal with the same flavors but served in porridge form. Yum. Half of our group sampled a teaspoonful. Then we left to get ice cream.
author: Fish T.

description:
Helpful tips:
1. 2 larges are WAY too much for 3 women. .We also couldn't finish the rice porridge that they make for you at the end. It was good- but it was too much and it was too hot. Think about that when you are ordering.
2. The food is really hot when you get it and it kind of ruins the enjoyment.
3. It took forever for us to eat it and we were so tired from eating/waiting for it to cool/slurping/blowing/etc that we gave up early.
author: Julianna I.

description:
Checked out Nabe with my Babe (oh, never mind, I realized that doesn't rhyme and I don't think my friend likes it when I make advances on her).

It was Saturday night and we were hungry. I wasn't in the mood to go to an ultra trendy restaurant in the Mission or wherever they are these days. Who has the time to wait in line for 2 hours? Nabe seemed like great comfort food for a cool SF evening. 

We were able to score free street parking easily and were seated right away. We thought that the free filtered water was awesome and it was brought out in pretty frosted glass bottles (I know, it's a random observation).

Anyway, I ordered the Sukiyaki with beef and my date for the evening ordered the Spicy Miso broth with Kurobuta Pork. The meat was of high quality and the portion size for the veggies was generous for a Japanese shabu shabu place. My side of the pot took quite some time to heat up since all of the veggies had already been dumped into the broth. I think the Spicy Miso broth was better tasting the Sukiyaki broth. I really enjoyed the rice porridge that was made using the leftover Spicy Miso broth at the end. That was probably the best part of the entire meal.

I also really enjoyed eavesdropping on the people behind us who were on a first date. The girl giggled so much and the guy seemed to be having a good time. I wonder if they are going on a second date.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Food: 3.5 stars
Service: 4 stars

The zosui at the end tipped my rating from 3.5 to 4 stars! The rice porridge is hot and soaked up all the flavor from our meat/spicy miso. Yum. We almost didn't try it but sooo glad we did because the nori (seaweed) they add on top make the zosui quite outstanding.

Between two of us we shared a large shabu shabu ($16) and a cold tofu appetizer ($5). The pork quality was good, and amount of veggies and noodles definitely filled us. The soup was bland in the beginning but obviously cooking the meats and veggies kicked it up a notch. The cold tofu was very refreshing but not a must-order. Overall, great place with cool decor, it's a reliable lunch/dinner place that won't disappoint!

First thing walking in we both took a step back at how stuffy and hot it was. But I asked the waiter for AC and she turned it on immediately. During the time we were there she was very responsive and friendly. Tipped her 20% and I usually don't do that :P
author: Maggie G.

description:
The GF and I came here on a Monday night.  I have passed by here before and seen it being very busy.  It was pretty late when we got here, which explains why there were only four other tables occupied.  We looked at the menu and decided to get the Sukiyaki and the Kinoko nabe.  The Sukiyaki comes with everything u would expect from shabu shabu, but with thinly sliced marbled pieces of beef.  They also supply you with an egg for dipping the meat in to make it more silky.  The Kinoko nabe comes with mushrooms and ramen.  Both broths were very flavorful.  I liked the Sukiyaki a little better though because it is more traditional.  

The vegetables and other ingredients are already placed in the pot.  This has its pros and cons.  For example, stuff that you do not like is automatically cooking inside the pot.  Although, one does not really have to worry about overcooking tofu or mushrooms, the vegetables may get soggy in this manner.  Pros are that you can get whatever you want at once because they will have all cooked at the same time!  

After you are done eating, they prepare a type of rice soup.  They ask you what type of broth you want the rice soup to be made in.  Then, they bring out green onions, egg, seaweed, and of course rice.  They add the rice into the broth.  Then they slowly drain the broth until the rice is clearly visible under the broth.  After that, the egg and green onions are stirred into the equation.  Then, this creation is put into bowls and topped with seaweed.  This was definitely my favorite part of the meal.  Dinner and a show?  Awesome.  

We were so full after the meal.  However, we had to make room for dessert.  Their special is the butter mochi, which is made in house.  I could definitely tell they were proud of it because they asked us what we thought of it.  It was really delicious.  Imagine a warm mochi that melts in your mouth.  It is served with ice cream of your choice.  The GF loves black sesame, and it paired great with the mochi.  NomZ.  

Service A 
Food A
Environment A (ventilation was very good)
author: Victor L.

description: I love the shabu shabu here. Its a step in quality and execution than the best AYCE shabu places in SF. You get what you pay for and I think prices are fair. They make a rice pourridge at the end of the meal which is very tasty. The gyoza is excellent here too. I have only positive things to say about this place and I always enjoy coming here.
author: Adam M.

description: Sukiyaki and wagyu beef 10/10. Great service and the food came quick. The waitress refilled my water and turned up or down the stove temperature accordingly. At the end of the meal she turned one of our broths into a porridge with rice and some other ingredients for free. The portion sizes are good too.
author: Bob J.

description: DELICIOUS hot pot, one the best I've had. I will be going here again.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
A different take on Shabu Shabu. Yes, its basically the same formula, thinly sliced pieces of high quality beef, served with a selection of vegetables, selection of noodles and selection of broth. Yes, they have suggested sets, but you can really customize anything and everything. 

Their claim to fame is that they use organic and locally sourced ingredients. The service was attentive and efficient. The deco is trendy, but the dining area is small. There are only 3 or 4 private tables with two long communal style tables in the middle. 

Call and make a reservation if you want to eat at a decent hour for dinner.
author: Tony L.

description:
JAPANESE SHABU SHABU
(4 stars)

Simple evening, nothing fancy, just a big ass boiling pot of goodness. Start with an appetite, leave with a mini gut. 

-FOOD, very good 
-PRICES, decent
-SERVICE, good
-AMBIANCE, small and chic

Been wanting to come here for months. Had reservations for 2 at 7pm. Packed but thank god for reservations. Make reservations or you'll be sitting outside for awhile. THE WALL OF SAKE BOTTLES amaze me, it's like a Sake fountain... It's not decor. Place is small and steams up like a sauna and the glass walls steam up. We decided to do two broths at regular size to taste as much as we can. 

HEFER STATS. 

KUROBUTA SAUSAGE ($5) - with mustard aioli. Comes with four sausages. The sausages were appetizer size, very very tasty, and it's worth getting to eat while the Shabu Shabu is warming up.

SUKIYAKI ($19/reg) - Wagyu beef, shirataki with warishita broth. They give you a raw egg and this fabulous dipping sauce for the Wagyu. Dip the raw Wagyu beef in the raw egg first, then the Shabu Shabu, then the fabulous dipping sauce... So good!!! Japanese people and their raw eggs rock my socks!!! The sukiyaki is a savory and sweet broth, gives the beef a nice coating of both. The only thing I hate toward the end of the meal all the veggies become mushy cause of the hotpot cooking all that time. 

SEAFOOD YASENABE ($19) - shrimp, salmon, scallops, and clams. Harusami with dashi broth. We chose a seafood since we already had meats. This is perfect for seafood lovers. All the seafood boiling in the broth married each item and it tasted good. I am not much of a seafood broth person, I love seafood but when seafood mix together in soup the taste then becomes too seafoodish - I'm weird. It was good but rather keep Shabu Shabu all meats/pork if possible. 

SURPRISE!!! When you think you're full, they come out asking which broth you liked more and make a porridge out of the leftover broth (trust, you will have left over broth). We chose the Sukiyaki. They mix rice and green union in the pot and explain what they are doing, then pour it in a bowl for you and top it off with seaweed garnish. So good yet so filling. You can pack it up if you like.

BUTTER CAKE AND SESAME ICECREAM - they don't feature their desserts on the menu. They have a few items and an assortment of icecream. I must always end a good meal with dessert, that's just me. Full or not!!! I got to choose so I selected the butter cake and paired it with sesame icecream because the other choices would make it sweet on top of sweet. Two lite butter cakes were the consistency of light pound cake. Ice cream taste exactly as it sounds. 

Will I be back? Yup!

Until the next review.....
author: Jane A.

description:
Nabe has several very nice, attentive, and knowledgable waitresses. Because the waitresses were so informative and helpful, our food actually came with a healthy side of knowledge. And of course, KNOWLEDGE IS POWER!

Did you know......

1) Nabe, short for Nabemono, is not exactly the same as Shabu. In Nabemono, heaps of food are already filled into the hotpot broth. In contrast, ShabuShabu comes out with only broth, and food is filled into it afterwards. If you're eating at Nabe, choosing any broth options other than 'Shabu' will get you a beautiful hot pot broth with a variety of ingredients already inside. (Don't worry, both options come with thinly slice marbled meat on the side!)

2) The meal is finished with Zosui, which is similar to a porridge, or a Japanese Risotto. A waitress comes over to your table with a plate of rice, egg, seaweed, and scallion and then proceeds to cook the rice in the leftover broth. Apparently, the rice absorbs the leftover nutrients from the veggies in the broth, thus making the Zosui a nutritious finish to the meal. My mom pointed out that there is probably a lot of fat and sodium in the broth, but she also agreed that it makes the Zosui absolutely delicious.

3) The most important thing to know for Nabe is TO GET THE MOCHI BUTTER CAKE DESSERT. They make the Mochi Cake in house, so this is the only place to taste this delightful dessert. It's served with a scoop of ice cream. Just imagine biting into a warm-buttery-chewy piece of cake with a sudden sensation of sweet-chilly ice cream sliding down your taste buds. gettttttit

My mom and my sister gave strong compliments to the stellar service. I agree, the waitstaff was top notch. Next time I'm here, I will try the Sake, because they have an impressive collection lined up on their walls. Maybe I'll learn a little something about Sake too and of course, KNOWLEDGE IS POWER.
author: Ringo M.

description: Shabu shabu on a cold San Francisco night is the best. We came on a Monday night and were seated promptly. We ordered the wagyu beef shabu shabu with traditional broth and the seafood platter.  I ordered the large plate for an extra few ounces of beef. With the vegetable plate and ramen (which we subbed for the udon), this was a huge amount of food. They have the electric stoves on the table and they were well taken care of as the broth almost immediately boiled once they brought the pots of soup to the table. Remember to keep some rice as they take the rice and make a porridge out of the leftover soup. Best part of the meal and it made a fantastic breakfast the next day as there was tons of porridge. Fantastic meal and I definitely want to come back
author: Calvin C.

description:
Shabu shabu makes the world a better place. Especially if you are sick and it is cold outside. 

SETTING
-Nabe is in a busy part of Inner Sunset - right between Irving and Judah on 9th Ave.
-Glass doors and walls so you can look right into the restaurant, unless it's around dinner when the inside is so hot that the glass gets fogged up! 
-They have a few tables for parties of 4 or smaller, and then a long table that stretches in the middle of the restaurant for pairs or larger groups. 
-If it's a full house they do have a wait list you can put your name on. You can wait inside or wander about outside and they'll give you a call. 
-Service gets a little bit slow when things get crowded.

SHABU SHABU
-We always go for the half pot Spicy Miso Broth (Shabu Shabu order) and half pot Warishita broth (Sukiyaki order)
-Meat platters come in two sizes: Regular or Large. The prices vary depending on which type of meat. For this outing we ended up ordering a large Sukiyaki wagyu beef order and a regular Shabu Shabu kurabuta pork plate.
-Each order comes with a plate of assorted vegetables and other condiments: tofu, cabbage, enoki mushroom, carrot, udon noodles, shiitake mushroom, kabocha squash, etc. 
-TIP: After you finish your shabu shabu meal, there is actually a FINISHER! The waiter will bring out rice and use your leftover broth to make a rice soup. The spicy miso broth rice soup finisher is amazing. They add an egg, green onions, and a little bit of seaweed. It takes about 10 minutes to prepare if your broth is still hot. 

PROS/TIPS
-Complimentary rice soup finisher after your Shabu Shabu meal! It always hits the spot if you're still a little hungry after your Shabu Shabu!
-Ask for iced water when you get in - most people ask for tea but after you get your Shabu Shabu... you'll want cold water.
-Keep your broth hot after you're done with your Shabu Shabu and you're ready for the finisher - otherwise it'll take extra time to reheat the broth and make the finisher. Since it's time intensive you could end up waiting for awhile. 

Overall delicious :) happy happy shabu shabu!
author: Grace J.

description:
Probably one of the more unique hotpot joints here in sf. 

For one thing, they divide the pot, so that you and a friend can share, while not really sharing.  The place is fairly big, but the seating near the glass window is weird since people could see you haha. Their decor was marvelous though, really simplistic which I like. Sake bottles all around, FTW. If you're lucky, you can come here earlier and score an individual table. Otherwise, you'll end up at the community table where you share the table with random people lol.

I came here for my 21st birthday with my cousin last year, and I recall ordering sukiyaki. The broth came out to a nice sweet tasting broth, for my big ass sweet tooth. The meats that come with it are nicely sliced and fresh, so that they cook faster. They give you a generous ass amount of veggies, which makes me uber delights. Their dipping sauces however, tasted rather unique to me. I guess it's because I really like how Shabu House makes it. 

One thing that's unique about this place compared to other Shabu joints is what they do to your rice that you have left. They add the rice into either broths and create a porridge for you. It's so yummy and filling, which is hard to down since i'm pretty sure you're hella full by then.
author: Jerianne G.

description:
The boyfriend and I swung by on a Tuesday night at 7:15-30 and were seated immediately. There were two other open tables, so I guess we came at a good time. We sat in the middle section of the long table, and though the restaurant is small, the way they have the tables set up doesn't make you feel cramped. But then again, there's only two of us. The atmosphere is very modern, with the sake bottle wall and the white tables contrasted with the grey wall paint. They also use wooden bowls and spoons, which gives the meal itself a more traditional feel I suppose. 

The menu is pretty straightforward, and we both chose the Shabu Shabu with spicy miso and Wagyu beef ($19 for the regular). If your table chooses different soups, they'll give you a split pot. The veggie plate gets bonus points from me because it had kabocha, a sort of pumpkin! The beef was beautifully cut into squares and looked very pretty. The soup was more spicy than miso, so eh. The boyfriend and I were pretty disappointed with the ponzu sauce; they give it to you already mixed with Daikon and garlic, and it's just too... Pickled tasting. We both barely touched it. They also don't offer chili oil, garlic, Daikin, or any of that at the table. 

The BEST part of the meal had to be the zotsui, rice porridge, at the end of the meal. The waitress takes your leftover soup, mixes in some rice and an egg, and let's it sit. Then she'll serve it with some green onions and seaweed. So. Damn. Good. And if you don't finish, you can take it home! Honestly, this was the main reason I wanted to come to Nabe. 

The servers were really great and friendly. When the place got packed, they slowed down a bit, but I can't blame them I guess. The waitress who made our zotsui for us explained every step, and asked to make sure it was okay to put in whatever ingredient was going next, which I think is great service. When the table next to us asked why one half of their pot wasn't boiling, she kindly told them it was because it had more stuff in it (duh). 

So what's my verdict? Nabe is probably the closest to traditional shabu shabu I've had, but the spicy miso just didn't do it for me. While I'd definitely come back purely for the zotsui (and maybe try the kimchi soup), I'm probably gunna stick with Shabu House, where I love the spicy miso and you get to mix up your own ponzu.
author: Doris K.

description:
This place a smaller that it looks but still really good. 

They do things a little different from other Hot Pot places I've been, in that the food is already in the pot when it arrives. I was kinda bummed, not just because I enjoy adding my food myself, but because you can't time the food to last as you want it. For example, we got the seafood combo and we had to make sure we ate that quickly since seafood doesn't take as long to cook. Some of it resulted in over cooked food. 

Other than that, we enjoyed our time and left full!
author: Nikki H.

description:
We went to Nabe on Sunday night around 7:30 PM.  We drove because I knew there was a small public parking lot across the street that was not likely to be full at such an hour on a Sunday night.  Sure enough we got a parking spot after a brief wait.  We walked across the street to Nabe and were confronted by a complete wall of glass that was covered over by floor to ceiling condensation so that you could only see a shadow of what was going on inside.  I opened the glass door with interpretation.

Once inside the place was buzzing but not noisy or sauna like I'd expected.  There is waiting space for only about two but we were quickly greeted by a waitstaff and told it'd be about a five minute wait.  Another couple entered soon after us but were quickly seated at the one visibly open table so obviously Nabe does take reservations.

The interior of Nabe would be what I'd describe as Norwegian/Japanese chic with a tight but clean communal dinning sort of arrangement.  The table tops are inset with slick modern glass induction cooktops. No overhanging exhaust fans in sight as everything is neatly hidden behind a high ceiling blond wood grid.

The food: We started with the edamame w/ sea salt and both the Wagu and the Vegetable gyoza (six pcs each). They were out of the Wagu gyoza but the vegetable ones were delicious although small.  When my Japanese wife noted their size I told her they most likely were made in house.  The edamame were pan seared instead of the traditional steamed but interestingly delicious.

The main dish for us was the Vegetable Nabe with a caveat we added a side of Wagu beef!  Yep, the maximum amount premium vegetables with a single side of meat.  They brought an iron pot filled with beautiful mushrooms, vegetables and a couple slices of Kabocha and the boiling started pronto.  The Wagu beef showed up at the table beautifully sliced thin on a side plate.  Add to the beef to the vegetables as you wish. Individual bowls of a light traditional dipping sauce were provided along with small wooden "cooling" bowls as I like to call them.

Once at the bottom of the Nabe pot we ladled out the smooth flavorful broth and drank it from our "cooling" bowls as the crèchendo to a simple but delicious fully shared meal.  The wait staff wanted to bring us rice to add to the broth but we were too stuffed to add anything more.
author: d h.

description: Food great , server was the best I have seen in a very very long time. Atmosphere was great happy people not to loud could still talk and hear each other. I can't wait to go back even though I live in San Jose. I ordered the spice soup with beef 5.. this is a must try place
author: Thomas F.

description:
My goodness this place is wonderful! came here because the restaurant we were going to go to was closed on Mondays. Amazing service, great food, inspiring atmosphere, decent price. 


Full 750ml Nigori Sake 
2 entree dishes
Extra udon noodles 
Extra side of pork
80$ 
Comes with amazing rice porridge and they package noodles separate from broth if you need to take a doggy bag. Love it, will be back!
author: Heather H.

description:
My boyfriend and I were craving shabu but with not very many shabu places opened for lunch yelp led us to Nabe.  I had heard a lot of good things about this place and always wanted to try it for their "after meal" where at the end they add rice and egg into your shabu broth and you get a rice porridge.  

We came about an hour before they closed and there was still quite a few people there.  My boyfriend got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef and spicy miso and I got the sukiyaki with wagyu beef.  Out of the two I personally liked the sukiyaki better. The broth itself was sweet and tasted amazing after dipping your beef in it and then the raw egg they give you. Portion wise they could have been more generous but I understand since it's lunch time their portions are probably smaller than a dinner plate.  We both finished our meat in no time at all and had to order an additional plate of meat because we were still hungry. The meat was good, soft and not frozen like many other places, and I loved the vegetable assortment, especially the variety if mushrooms and kabocha squash!

When we were all done the waitress have us the bill and I was thinking... "We don't get the rice and egg add ins?" So my boyfriend asked our waitress and she told us it was only during dinner that they do that.   Seeing the disappointment on my face the waitress was sooo kind and said she could bring us a bowl of rice and I could make it myself since my meal already came with a raw egg.  She ended up making the whole thing for us, adding the rice, taking out excess soup to make the rice to soup ratio even, stirring in the raw egg, and she went above and beyond and brought us the green onion and seaweed garnishes to put on top.  The customer service that we experienced was AMAZING and our waitress was really sweet.  And I'm glad we got to try the rice porridge because it was delicious!! 

I wouldn't mind coming back again but I prefer AYCE when doing hot pot or shabu.
author: Linz C.

description:
Japanese hot pot that fully warms you up, especially on the rainy days!

Pro:
-Generous portions
-Fresh ingredients in Sukiyaki 

Con:
-Understaffed and slow service
-Easy to burn your tongue so be careful!
author: Linda K.

description:
Came here twice so far and both times i thought the food was good. Not alot of hot pot places offer sukiyaki flavor so i really liked coming here for their sukiyaki broth. First time I came here me and my boo got our own pots and it was plenty but second time i came here with my friends and ordered 2 pots for 3 of us and we were all still hungry when we finished lol even after the porridge too!! and nooooo we are not a bunch of fatasses. It was such a small portion to share and costs around 20 dollar per pot! Wow i am soo surprised we were still hungry after cuz we just tiny asian chicks lol 

Anyway this place is on the pricier side and not something I'll go to often, oh and ur clothes and hair smell like food after too lol sooo think wiselyyyy!
author: Debbie D.

description:
Considering where it is (9th Ave), how long they've been open (it's been a while), the food (it's pretty good), and the fact that it's shabu (shabu!), I'm really surprised Nabe only has 109 reviews.  I mean, TPumps probably had that many after two weeks and they aren't nearly as good!  Granted, there's a slight difference in what they serve, but still!

Unlike other shabu joints, Nabe doesn't offer an AYCE option (which might be why they get less traffic).  However, the menu does offer several appetizers and Nabemono sets, which each include a plate of meat and vegetables (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#jAuLiyN-WUPGbLsAKTkbbA).  To start our meal, the three of us shared an order of the KUROBUTA GYOZA ($7).  The filling was pretty tasty and I liked the accompanying chili sauce, but I thought the skin could have used a harder crust (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#S79V2u3V_0n3JhZSB02q6A).

For our dinner set, we decided to share a large 50/50 pot ($24) of Sukiyaki and Shabu Shabu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#MhOerOo7cXe4vkZrU31rww).  The SUKIYAKI side came with a Warishita broth and a plate of Wagyu Beef.  Although it was a little light and sweeter than what I would normally go for, it balanced out the rest of the meal pretty well.  Not mind blowing, but solid.

On the SHABU SHABU side, we went with the Spicy Miso broth over their traditional Kombu and opted for the Kurobuta Pork over getting more beef.  Between its more savory flavor and slight kick, I thought the Spicy Miso was the better of the two we had.  Can't argue with the Kurobuta Pork either!  So good (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#J3qUCdFHz-k2gbf5qREluw).

To cap off the meal, we were served Nabe's signature Zosui rice soup (I don't know of any other place in SF that does it).  Utilizing the remainder of our Spicy Miso broth, our server mixed in an egg, rice, green onions, and nori to create a delicious jook-like soup.  Although it was a little salty, it was delicious!  Almost made us wish we had left more of the meat and veggies in the pot (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#Xy2B_bzJWTb2zn2AVA2bLw).

Despite the fact they won't replace Shabu House as my favorite spot for shabu in SF (or anywhere), Nabe is more than a sufficient alternative to mix things up a bit.  Not I hope Nabe doesn't get TOO busy in the future...
author: Mike L.

description: I came to this location with my boyfriend as we were craving some shabu shabu. Luckily there was parking right outside the restaurant and it was a minute away from the location. When we walked into the location it was very stuffy and there were a few tables occupied. There were three servers that were very friendly and helpful. We looked at the menu and ordered a set which included Wagyu beef. We added a couple of additional items as we were sharing these the set together. We got the spicy miso soup- I suggest ordering the regular miso soup instead of the spicy as you can always add spicy and not the other way around. The set comes with a vegetable plate that includes some udon, mushroom, spinach, squash etc. The service was okay, when we got there, the employees were eating their dinner too. They failed to tell us it was last call time, so we ended up not being able to order anything. Instead we just ordered this mochi cake with ice cream. The waitress suggest that we order the roasted black sesame ice cream. It was good to try but I wouldn't say that I crave their ice cream or shabu. I suggest trying this shabu place as the decor and utensils are fun, and it could be a nice fun first date, but I don't think this is my go to. The mochi cake was not very tasty, there was definitely a lack of sugar and butter. It needs to be softer, more moist, and definitely sweeter.
author: Amy Y.

description: As a vegetarian, it's very hard for me to find hot pot places with actual vegetarian broth. Nabe has a great vegetarian broth, though there is only one vegetarian set option. I am a spice devil and thus asked for some spicy sauce/powders to add to my broth so that I could kick up the heat. I also really love udon so I tend to get a portion of that to add to my veggies as well. The staff was really attentive and accommodating when it came down to getting some spicy additions. I was pleasantly surprised by the rice porridge that they served at the end of the meal and would go back just for that. Prices are somewhat steep, but not unreasonable for what you get. The place can get crowded at times so I would say that you should get there close to opening time. Overall, a great place for vegetarians and meat eaters alike.
author: Lakshmi M.

description: One of the best hot pot restaurants in the Sunset.  Good food, good service, and reasonable prices.
author: Randy L.

description:
Nabe is Japanese style shabu shabu, so don't come here if you're expecting Taiwanese hot pot. It's different! 

This is a pretty small and cozy joint so I would recommend making reservations like we did. The decor is cool with the sake bottles hanging on the walls. I looooove shabu shabu and I think Nabe does a pretty good job. They offer nabemono sets that come with your choice of a broth and a predetermined set of veggies. You can go ala carte too but I think the sets are where it's at. I got the sukiyaki broth and my friends got the miso. I love sukiyaki and this was exactly what I was craving... it's on the sweeter side. Don't forget to dip your meat in the raw egg! Their ponzu sauce and sesame sauce are also AMAZING. I started to just eat then on their own with my rice. The Wagyu beef it came with was thinly sliced, very good quality and it was accompanied with assorted veggies + shirataki (yam) noodles. Our meal was ended with the zosui (rice porridge) made from the miso broth + green onions and nori (seaweed). It was really flavorful because the broth was so concentrated at that point so it could've been overpowering to some, but I enjoyed it. 

It came out to around $20/person without tax or tip so it is a little more expensive. That was with each of us ordering our own regular order and that was more than enough for me. You could try to order a large and share with 2 people if you have a smaller appetite. I just think shabu is less salty than hot pot which I like, but if you want AYCE or more options, you should probably look elsewhere. 

 I really have no qualms about this place, so 5 stars it is!
author: Sara S.

description:
One of the more hip, fun hot pot places. Pricey...yes, but worth a visit or two. The food is good and the atmosphere is one of the best. They even take the time to make you a porridge after you've finished your meal. 

5 stars for the customer service
5 for the atmosphere
3.5 for price
4.5 for the food
4.5 for the broth
author: Joshua F.

description: Great service! Amazing shabu shabu and love the interior as well! Will come back for sure!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Sometimes its best to come to a place without any expectations.  I didn't have any expectations for this place because i normally don't even like ShabuShabu . So i was surprised by how much I ended up loving this place.  

I didn't have to wait for a table, then again it was a weekday night.  They didn't have much options for their soup base, which made me to end up picking Sukiyaki base. My friend picked the kimchi soup base. I think out of the two, the sukiyaki was the best.  It was sweet and had flavors to it. The kimchi base was ok, it wasn't spicy enough.  They recommend that with the sukiyaki base that you dip your meat into a raw egg after cooking it.  And wow was I impressed.  The meat was cooked in the perfect booth and when you dip it in the egg, it gave it such a smooth taste.  

The meats and other ingredients here are really fresh. And at the end of the dinner, they will ask you which of the two soup base you want to make the  Zosui  or maybe it's spelled shime rice soup.  What is that you ask? it's actually a lot like "jook" aka Rice Porridge.  They take your leftover soup base (we picked the sukiyaki) and add rice to it and cook it. I'm not really sure what they added to it besides seaweed, but it turned out to be delicious. It actually fills you up, and it's hard for you to finish it after eating so much.  I enjoyed my experience here and will be back for more!.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Modern and clean for a shabu shabu restaurant, which is probably why it's slightly pricier than your usual AYCE hotpot joint in the city.

My go-to: Wagu Beef with spicy miso soup.  

Pro tip: Save room for the grand finale! At the end of your meal, your waitress will bring over a bowl of rice, eggs, shredded seaweed and make congee (Asian rice porridge) with your leftover soup. If you didn't feel quite full before the congee, I guarantee you will be afterwards.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Cool Sunset nights were made for this place.  
After reading Cherylynn N.'s review (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg), this was an automatic bookmark.  It's been over two years since and this visit was long time coming.  Let me preface that I am biased towards that place on Ocean Avenue near Stonestown for my Saturday lunch.  I was supposed to meet a friend for dinner here, but he flaked due to a family dinner and left me on a solo trip here.  
With the dining room half full, my greeter brought me to a middle table next to a young couple.  The menu has a decently wide selection so my dilemma was sukiyaki or shabu.  After a few questions, I ordered the shabu shabu, regular set with spicy miso broth (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=rfP3qj44WmhPJR6DYWIQ2g), $19.00.  Given a choice of Wagyu bed or Kurabota pork, I asked Kevin for a special accommodation of half and half (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=58S7Wi_JmCTRedpeNopCqQ).  Starting with the veggies, which take longer to cook, I filled my pot as gradually got to my proteins.  The meat qjuality was not quite as good as that other place.  Not that it was bad, but wasn't as tasty.  The soup was tangy spicy and lacked the umami of the other place's deep flavored spicy miso.  Also, the one dipping sauce offered is a bit monotone.
What really boosted this from a three to a four star review were the Zosui (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=DT_Clm3Lj3f7ObJLDHlzdg) (plus half) and Kevin's attentiveness to details (plus half).  As mentioned by Cherlynn, the Zosui is a rice porridge similar to Chinese jook that mixes egg, rice, and scallion slices with your remaining Shabu broth.  Mine was expertly cooked by Kevin who then topped my bowl with small nori strips.  Fortunately, I opted for the regular instead of their larger set (more meat), as the porridge put me over the top; in fact, there was porridge to go.
The dining room was about 60% full during my meal on a Monday night.  Everyone seemed to enjoy their meals.  If you'd like a more intimate meal, you may need to request for a wall side table as the middle ones are very close together.
Yes, I will be back and the meal was good with excellent service.  
It just wasn't quite, "as good as it gets", in my book.
author: Mike C.

description: Came here as a team, was quite a small place. The tl:dr is that it's expensive, the quality of the food was better than most places. So I would say, if you don't mind blowing money and don't want to be super full go here (or if someone else is paying for it). Otherwise, I thought it was more fun to go to other hot pot places because there is no worry about price since they are all you can eat. You could see the marbling of the wagyu though, and that's kind of rare for hot pot places.
author: Victor D.

description: I and my friends went there about 9:30 which will be closed at 10pm. They're still happy to served us. The food was yummy and smells good. Also after we finished they made the porridge in our left over pot which is Free! I gave 4 Stars for Food! The service was good and I gave 5 stars to the waitress:)
author: Originalall S.

description:
I'll admit, I was a huge skeptic of this place until I actually ate here. Nabe is still a relatively new genre in Japanese cuisine in the US. Of course there are "shabu shabu" places, but rarely do you get the genuinely authentic flavors as nabe is supposed to be in Japan.

We got two large ones to share between 3 people, even though the waitress tried to convince us to get 3. Really, there's no need for that. There are plenty of add-ons for you to, well, add on, to your order. I think you should get as many individual nabe as you want to taste different flavors.

We got the sukiyaki and seafood yosenabe. Both had different broths. And then we got a bunch of add-ons: veggie plate, shiitake mushrooms, tofu, shungiku. You can also get additional meat and seafood, but I think veggies are essential to nabe, because they impart so much flavor to nabe.

So the way you're supposed to do this is let the nabe boil. Then start eating the meat. For sukiyaki, they give you a raw egg as a "wash" after you cook the meat in the nabe. Since the meat is cut so thinly, you only really need to put it in the boiling broth for a few seconds. And because it's so hot, you dip it in the egg wash and then eat. Let me tell you, the egg makes a world of difference - not only to calm the temperature down, but all add flavor and texture. The meat tastes so much better with the egg.

As you continue to eat, you might want to bring down the temperature of the heating pad a little if you're not eating meat. Add some veggies and wait for them to be ready. Eat the veggies and then eat more meat. Repeat until you don't have anything but broth.

Signal your server and she'll bring rice over to make zosui. This is an amazing end of the meal extra. Because you've added so much meat and veggies to the broth, the broth is rich with extra flavor that it didn't start with. When you add the rice, it becomes a heavenly porridge. No need to get noodles or other carbs as an add-on. The end of the meal zosui comes with your meal already. It's so much better than noodles because the rice absorbs the broth and all that good flavor.

Hot pots are one of my favorite food genres because it can be so flavorful... and FUN TO EAT! Definitely come to Nabe if you like hot pots. You'll be in for an adventure!
author: Sherry L.

description:
I was here with a pretty large group for a friend's birthday. We ended up having three separate pots and each pot, we got two different broths. The shabu shabu meat was pretty decent. We didn't upgrade to the A5 waygu beef, as it was pretty expensive to upgrade. 

The service was great. My pot had the duck and the shabu shabu. The shabu meat quality was quite good. And the duck broth was very savory. I liked the amount of vegetables that came with our orders, but I just wish there was more meat, though we could always add meat. We were a bit disappointed when we added tofu to our order and there weren't that many pieces. 

At the end of our meal, the staff told us to choose two different broths to make the congee from. We chose a spicy miso broth and the duck broth. The rice wasn't cooked as long in the spicy miso broth so it was more chunky. The one made from the duck broth was the best. The rice was nice and soft. It was so flavorful and I didn't think it was too salty. The rice and other ingredients put inside made the congee so good.
author: Jay L.

description: Get some really decent hot pot at Nabe, but you'll feel like sardines in a can.  The meat and broth was delicious, but navigating the dishes around made me feel like I was playing tetris again.  The kurobuta pork and the sukiyaki were the standout items.  While we had four pots total, I did not relish that we were only allowed to make rice porridge using our choice of one of the broths.
author: David C.

description:
LOVE the service here! The food is great as well!!!
I have to say the restaurant is so cute and intimate, definitely makes me want to sit in there when it is rainy and cold outside. 
My first experience here was great, came early before the place was even opened so we can get first dibs on the seats. Once the place was set up, the waitress approaches us and asked us if we wanted to sit down. We got the corner table of the restaurant and the waitress explained the menu and gave us advice on the food. Also letting us know they do make the signature porridge at the end of the meal. 
So we ordered one big Shabu shabu and shared btwn my Bf and I. It was a good portion to be shared and eventually we thought we could order another set of shabu shabu but it was just too much, too full. But I have to say the meals look fresh, meats were well-cut and displayed wonderfully. And I have to say I loved the whole meal and I had a wonderful waitress who guided us along the way since it was our first time at the restaurant. 
The only downside of the shabu shabu experience was the sauce. I missed the yellow paste sauce that usually comes with the soy sauce. But if Nabe had that, it would the most awesome experience ever!!
Overall I loved the restaurant, decor was great, the waitress was awesome and the place is clean! Nothing is better than enjoy a pot of hot soup and delicious meal and veggies on a cold day! Go check it out!
author: Joanne C.

description: I would give this place 3.5 stars. The meat was good quality and the broths were good not great. The decor of the place was really cute but it seemed like they had no vents in this restaurant. The glass window/door were fogged up and it felt like a mild steam room. I really like they had duck hotpot and sukiyaki which is a nice change from the normal average hot pot places.
author: Eileen H.

description:
I would first like to point out that the service here is great! I came here on a Monday night around 9:30pm and they close at 10pm, so I called to see if it was inconvenient if I came in near closing but the girl that answered the phone was super sweet and said that it would be okay! When I walked in around 9:30, I was actually shocked that I had a table for two already set up when I never asked for a reservation.

I must say that I had a really good experience here, quite different compared to many other hot pot places. The interior is so nice! I love that they decorated the whole restaurant with different types of Japanese sake. The ambiance of this place is so cozy with dim lighting, it's perfect for any occasion, whether it's a date, catching up with friends, or just casually getting some hot pot. 

I had the large Sukiyaki, which included Wagyu beef, vegetables, and a side of rice shared between a friend and I. The broth was sweet, but overall it was flavorful and unique. My only complaint is that I wish they had more vegetables and sides in it! But overall, it was good and you can always have more broth filled if you need more! After finishing, our server offered to make us Zosui, which is a porridge. At this point I was just really fascinated because she came back with a tray of broth, an egg, rice, some seaweed flakes, and some scallions. After that, she basically gave us a show, and made us porridge on our table. This was definitely something that I never experienced before at a hot pot place, or basically in general! It was awesome and the porridge was great! Who knew that those little ingredients she brought out would make the broth taste different(in a good way) and delicious!?!

This is such a great place to go to on a cold night to get some hot pot AND porridge! Overall, I had a really good experience from the service to the food! I can't wait to try the other items on the menu!
author: Jane N.

description:
Really good food and experience. The staff is very pleasant and the food was very tasty. For apps we got pork gyozas that were really really good.

For entrees we ordered the two miso broths and the kimchi broth. For meats we got the pork belly and shoulder and the kobe beef. 

The shoulder tasted a bit too pork-y for me but all the meat overall was very tasty.

Loved the rice pudding at the end with shallots and nori. 100% recommended, I will go back.
author: Flora F.

description:
The menu is a little confusing but the waitressess were great at explaining the menu and making recommendations. Basically, you pick a meat and a matching broth set.

At other shabu shabu places, you customize your hot pot and dipping sauces. Here since it's nabemono style, each broth pot comes to the table already filled with stuff.  They use local and organic ingredients, and you can taste the difference in quality. 

We ordered a half and half; Sukiyaki with beef and Spicy kimchee with Berkshire pork. $19/regular, $24/large. 
Very good, liked the kimchee and pork combo. The sukiyaki was a little sweet.
*Get the regular, the large only adds a few more slices of meat. 
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=mwEcB8tYHMFlBgcXeK0QrQ#mwEcB8tYHMFlBgcXeK0QrQ)

It's a fun place, at the end of the meal, the waitress comes by and does a "finisher" by having you pick one of your leftover broths to make a porridge using rice, eggs, scallions, and seaweed. She mentioned it's "very Japanese" and that most people, full more dinner, take it to go. It was like Japanese jook/congee for me. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=0LQT7HaFVDUlLukG63s1pQ#0LQT7HaFVDUlLukG63s1pQ)

Notes 

*For Nabe having a great modern design, it gets hot and steamy inside. 
*They should play some music, Japanese jazz? Nujabes anyone? 
*The place is a little tight, some lady walked by and almost knocked over my full plate of meat!?!?! Groups of 4 work, any bigger is 
*No all you can eat / drink option (yet?)
*I wonder if modern places like this are going to start the next trend in Shabu? 

Overall, the place was a lot of fun to try and I'd recommend checking it out but since it always takes about 20-30 minutes just to find parking in this area not sure if we'll be back. 
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=kk7emiwjVIIp_EOgBK_l9A#kk7emiwjVIIp_EOgBK_l9A)
author: Earl G.

description: Servers are very friendly. Potions are generous and the porridge finisher is very delicious. I highly recommend to make a reservation as it's a very small place.
author: Ron A.

description:
Nabe is the new, popular Japanese hot pot restaurant in the Inner Sunset. They have an inadequate ventilation system, so the front windows are usually covered with steam; it's no surprise if you overlook this restaurant while walking along 9th Avenue. However, the restaurant's name, displayed cleverly with a bold, blue neon lighting against the black exterior, is easily seen across the street, up to half a block away. It's like your calling to come in on a cold day for some yummy Japanese-style comfort food.

We tried Nabe a few Saturdays ago for an early dinner around 6PM. As newbies, the menu was a little confusing at first. But our server, Nhu, was very helpful explaining how everything worked. Basically, the nabemono sets are portioned per person. They come with the meat, noodles, and vegetables in the broth, all already in a large pot. That pot is brought to your table stove to cook. However, there is one shabu shabu set (beef or pork for choice of meat), which is the only nabemono set that doesn't have the ingredients already in the pot. In other words, you cook it yourself at the table.

We shared the beef and pork shabu shabu and opted for one regular miso broth and one spicy miso broth (traditional kombu (kelp) in water was the other option for shabu shabu broth). I definitely preferred the beef over the pork. Both meats were very fresh and delicious, but the beef was flavorful on its own that sauce wasn't necessary. Vegetables were fresh and abundant. You're given a generous helping of spinach, cabbage, shiitake and enoki mushrooms, carrots, tofu and kabocha squash. The miso broth was very mild, and the spicy miso definitely had some heat.

I love the idea of using leftover broth for rice porridge, so you're not wasting the broth. The waitress comes over to make it for you. That Saturday night we went, there were only three waitresses in the restaurant, so I give our server credit for doing so much, shuffling back and forth to other tables but still tending to ours. The broth is usually concentrated after your meal, so you can ask for them to dilute it. The rice porridge is a perfect compliment at the end of our meal, keeping us warm before we leave the restaurant and endure the cold night.

Nabe is a relatively small restaurant. There's two long communal tables and three smaller 4-person tables. Not a lot of walking room either. Without a reservation, come in by or before 6PM on weekends to guarantee no lines.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
I couldn't resist the thought of hot pot on a cold San Francisco afternoon, so after going to the farmers market across the street I stopped in to grab a lunch.  The interior of the restaurant is nice and clean with modern twist.  The service was prompt.  

Not a huge menu, but really, I was looking for shabu-shabu.  The meat selection was between beef and pork.  I asked the waitress about the marbling on wagyu, and she said she could get me more marbled meat than not, so I went for it with the traditional konbu broth.  

The cooking surface is the magnetic kind that heats the pot up.  The pot is nice and heavy. The veggies and meat came out quickly.  Veggie had a nice selection with generous amount of shitake, enoki and some shimeji mushrooms as well as nappa cabbage, spinach, carrots, and kabocha with tofu and udon.  Kabocha is a bit strange for the hot pot, but oh well.  The waitress only gave me ponzu sauce, so I asked for the sesame sauce in addition. The sauce had a nice flavor, ponzu a bit acidic than I like, but it was good.  Sesame sauce wasn't too thin, but a bit on a sweeter side for my taste, but not bad.  The quality of the meat was a bit disappointing -- rather chewy, even with some marbling.  I'd have to give them 3 stars due to the quality of the meat.  Otherwise, everything else was very good including the service.  I may go back and try their sukiyaki to see how it is...
author: Yoshiko D.

description: Ordered a large Sukiyaki for two, which left both of us feeling content but not completely full. One 'pot' of broth is considered one 'set' - having two sets is "recommended" as is written on the menu (they divide the pot in half to put in your two sets of broth separately). One 'set' of the broth could cost up $20, meaning that ordering two sets would put you at a base of ~$40 without any additional add-ons (you could order more meat, for example). The sukiyaki that we ordered was one set (but in a large size instead of regular). The flavors were enjoyable and the complimentary rice "porridge" they create using the leftovers of your broth at the end of your meal was tasty as well (available upon request or waitstaff will ask if you would like them to do this for you). The only downside is how much you're paying for the meal - most of the sets felt overpriced given that most of it is broth mainly filled with vegetables and tofu.
author: David Y.

description: The broth and sauce were very flavorful! I came here in a party of 4 around 6PM and had to wait almost 20 minutes. Tip: If you have more than 2 people, make a reservation or call ahead. They are really big on that. They have a huge selection of sake--watch out if you're a lightweight like me! We got a large shabu shabu and the platter of beef was huge! Its not AYCE but a fixed menu. I also tried their mochi cake for dessert and it was divine. I haven't found any kind of mochi bread since visiting SoCal! Overall, it was shareable and worth the price. The decor is modern and pleasant but the space is small and fills up quickly!
author: Leanna C.

description:
4.5 STARS

The Winter Blues.

For 60 hours, I didn't leave the house much less leave my bed (too bad it wasn't one of those "marathon" sessions). I don't/can't sleep so all I did was watch awesomely terrible Lifetime movies and eat Tyson buffalo wings and Kimchi ramen bowls.

Nothing was going to get me to leave the house. Nothing.

That was until I heard there was a new shabu joint that opened in The Sets.

*Furiously grabs baby wipes and sprays dry shampoo all over*

Hey, don't judge. 

My friends and I came to Nabe on Friday night with reservations. Thankfully, we made reservations because it was packed.

F O O D
Nabe offers Nabemono shabu set meals with additional a la carte meat and seafood options. No AYCE is available. All ingredients are organic and locally sourced. No MSG is used in any of the broths.

Each shabu set is paired with a specific broth that will best complement the type of meat. 

*Sukiyaki: Washugyu Beef with Warishita Broth
*Kinaka Nabe: Assorted Japanese Mushrooms in Miso Broth
*Kimchi & Kurobuta Pork Belly: Pork Belly with Kimchi Miso Broth
*Shabu Shabu with Traditional Konbu or Spicy Miso Broth
*Seafood Yosenabe: Shrimp, Salmon, Scallops, and Asari Clams in Dashi Broth

You have a choice of Regular ($18 for 8oz) or Large ($22 for 12oz); more for the seafood option. A veggie platter with udon noodles is included with each set.

Our group's Nabemono Sukiyaki & Shabu Shabu Sets: http://bit.ly/UEmCVg

My pick was the traditional konbu which is clear broth with seaweed (http://bit.ly/UEmQvI). There's not much flavoring to it but it allows you to enjoy the natural beefiness of the well-marbled washugyu beef (http://bit.ly/UEmZz3). The accompanying sesame paste with bonito and ponzu sauce were deliciously mouth-watering and full of umami flavors (http://bit.ly/UEn7yK).

However, when I got a taste of Mr. NSS' Warishita broth (Sukiyaki set), I was in shabu heaven (http://bit.ly/UEndGE). The delicious broth imparted a savory sweetness into the beef that was addicting that I abandoned my own pot. I loved the accompanying raw egg that added a layer of creaminess.

Saving the best for last is the Zosui. After your broth has been well-seasoned from the meat swishing, they add, rice, egg, nori and green onions to your broth to make a Japanese porridge (http://bit.ly/UEnh9o). The Zosui using the Warishita broth was so comforting and oh so good.

S E R V I C E
Friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable. Wendy, our waitress always had a smile on her face and did a good job explaining the Nabemono shabu concept to us thoroughly since it was new to us. I appreciated that they asked for feedback at the end of our meal. Always a good sign from new business owner(s). 

Service was a tad slow and it took awhile to get our broth pots but it was opening week and all.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
The swankiest shabu place in the city with minimalist black walls lined with wooden sake dispensers (http://bit.ly/UEnqcX). My only gripe is the place is small and tight (formerly Good Earth Cuisine) with just 2 communal tables and 3 small tables.

P A R K I N G
Good luck. Your best bet finding street parking is 2 blocks down on Lincoln near GG park.

With soul warmed and my tummy filled (ok, busting out from my spanx), I was glad I finally left the house to shabu my winter blues away!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Nabe is one of my favorite spots in SF for Shabu! There was one week that I went here 3 times. I have tried the spicy miso, miso and sukiyaki broths. My favorite broth has to be the spicy miso! Everything is super fresh and high quality! The beef is very nicely marbled. My first time here, I made a big mistake with my cousin by over ordering and not saving any room for the rice porridge at the end. The duck breast is good to try but I am Not used to eating that for hot pot. By the way, they do take reservations for a party of any size so if you do not want to wait, make a reservation!!
author: Janet Z.

description:
I love Shabu, and I really like their duck Shabu which you don't find it anywhere else in San Francisco. The broth is awesome and flavorful. the only down-side about this place is by the end of the meal, the waitress or waiter will pour rice into your left over broth and boil it into porridge, unfortunately, due to the laziness of the worker, the portion, taste, and texture  of the porridge is always always very inconsistent. The worker will disregard how much broth you have left in the pot, they will just pour a bowl of rice in there even the broth became very concentrated already, which make the porridge very salty. Sometimes, it would be very watery. I would prefer the perridge to be more consistent. 

Overall, I do enjoy eating here, just have to take control of the way they make the porridge.
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
Good Food and great Atmosphere.

The food isnt too sweet neitgher too hot & ingredients of Sukiyaki or Shyabu is fresh and good.
author: Yoona S.

description:
Heard there was a new hot pot/shabu place around so I wasted no time and paid Nabe a visit that same day. 

Immediately, I was impressed by the decor-- sleek, modern, dark-- not something you find at a typical Japanese/shabu/hot pot joint.  That's just it, Nabe is not your typical hot pot/shabu spot. I can't say that I know how people shabu in Japan but if I had a guess it would probably be close to how we did at Nabe.

Nabe had a few Nabemono set meals to choose from but Mr. Dubs and I both ended up with the Sukiyaki and an order of the gyoza. We had originally wanted to try the sausages but they ran out of it. (minus a star. They also didn't have a beer that was on the menu... something that is very typical too) But to redeem themselves... the homemade gyozas were bomb(dot)com for sure! 

If you're the AYCE type of person and won't leave without devouring at least 4 plates of meat a la Hulk style, then Nabe is likely not for you. You would appreciate Nabe if you appreciated organic and locally sourced ingredients as well as top quality meat.

I could hardly wait for my water to boil when our pot arrived. It was filled with tofu, mushroom, veggies, carrots and noodles all in a sweet sukiyaki broth. At the end of the meal, our server took out some rice, egg and seaweed and mixed it into our broth for our Zosui. To be honest, I thought that was just ok. I probably would've preferred having a bowl of rice during my meal instead.

I'll be back at Nabe for sure. Though there isn't an AYCE option, you will definitely walk out feeling full. The restaurant itself is tiny, so I'd definitely recommend making a reservation ahead of time.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
2 regular nabemono shabu sets shared among 3 people is more than enough, mostly due to the Zosui rice that they add to your broth after your hot-potting is done. It's like two meals in one!

A new hotpot restaurant in Inner Sunset that opened only 3 weeks ago? Hot damn! Cherylynn's review is so thorough that I don't need to bother with all the details. I just want to note that the nabemono sets include meat/seafood, noodles, and assorted vegetables paired with a broth. Your meal ends with a Zosui rice soup using the flavored broth from the cooking. Pricing is $18 per person for a regular portion, $22 per person for a large portion.

They also have a seasonal nabemono winter set called Kamonanban, which includes duck breast and Tokyo negi with Dashi broth, regular $23 and large $28.

Our group of 9 entered the restaurant around 5:30 PM without a reservation, and we were lucky to nab the long communal table in the back. The restaurant can only seat 32, so I would definitely recommend a reservation during normal dining hours. Service is good, with multiple waitresses running around checking on things, refilling water, and asking if the group is ready for the Zosui rice. However, the entire endeavor is a bit time-consuming given the ingredient preparation, table stove heating, and rice porridge finale. Our group was there for TWO HOURS. Crazy.

My PDC family ordered 2 regular sets: the SUKIYAKI (Washugyu beef with a sweet Warishita broth) and the SHABU SHABU (Washugyu beef or Kurobuta pork with either traditional konbu or spicy miso broth). Our order came with 3 plates, one for each of the meats (15 slices of thinly sliced, beautifully marbled beef: http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZwBukC0KhMXJKbmaNfKPFw/l.jpg, forgot to take a picture of the pork, oops) and another for the combined vegetables and udon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oENOdFCIcUrOqzm1cSXdgg/l.jpg). The vegetable/udon plate came with chopped cabbage, baby spinach leaves, a few slices of squash, two slabs of tofu, enoki mushrooms, a quartered shiitake mushroom, a few carrot pieces in cute shapes, and udon noodles. To be honest, I wish they gave more vegetables because spinach severely shrinks :(

Since the sukiyaki set came with Washugyu beef, we opted for the Kurobota pork in spicy miso broth, per my big's recommendation. When our pot came to our table, the vegetables were already swimming in it (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9Zp7qpP_MynVcMIw3wA0TQ/l.jpg). This gave the scallions, mushrooms, tofu, cabbage, carrots, chrysanthemum leaves, and these spotted, slightly-crunchy, translucent noodles more time to cook. We added the meats on par with our consumption; I enjoyed the beef and pork equally :)

Regarding the broths, I definitely preferred the sukiyaki's Warishita. The sweetened soy base adds subtle undertones to the hot pot ingredients, although the spicy miso adds that kick most people enjoy with their meat. The sukiyaki also comes with a raw egg that you crack into a bowl and dip your meat and vegetables in. So strange! I loved the added creaminess hehe. Screw Salmonella.

After all is eaten, a waitress scoops out some of your broth and adds in some rice to make this delicious porridge chock full of hot pot flavor. You can choose to split your rice between the two broths or have it half-half. We asked for half-half, and she let the rice sit for 5 or so minutes before returning to stir in the beaten egg, nori, and green onions. I definitely would vouch for the Warishita broth over the spicy miso broth because at the end of the stewing, the savoriness of the boiled ingredients blends harmoniously with the innate sweetness of the broth.

Max 4-way credit card split, and make sure to let them know before the ring things up. Also, they have one bathroom hidden behind a curtain. It has a weird sliding door...

All in all, I would recommend 2 regular nabemono sets to be shared among 3 people. Both the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU sets were fantastic, although I have a preference for the sukiyaki's broth and raw egg dip. I liked both the beef and the pork, and the beef is exceptionally marbled. And don't forget the Zosui rice porridge at the end! You're getting a real bang for your buck here ;)

Also, shout-out to the best family out there!
author: Adele F.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend and the food was very tasty.

Ordered:
- Kurobuta pork & wagyu beef sets (large for both) - sets came with veggies as well
- Soup bases: Sukiyaki & spicy miso

Overall, the food was good and the meat quality was very tasty as well. Both kinds of meat had just the right amount of marbling (meat vs. fat), so when you cooked it in the broth, it wasn't too dry and not too fatty. 

Unique element:
After you've devoured your meat, veggies, and noodles, they make this rice porridge for you with the broth of your choice. We chose to do it with our spicy miso broth. The server came to the table and combined the following with the broth:
- egg
- rice
- green onions
- seaweed

This porridge was very hearty and a great way to end your meal. My boyfriend and I were already really full, but couldn't get enough of this.

The only downside about this place is that it gets super steamy and it'll make the restaurant pretty warm inside, so don't wear anything that'll make you hot easily.

Service:
They were very attentive and this alone would encourage me to come back to this restaurant again.
author: Denise K.

description:
YUM. I've recently taken a liking to Japanese Hot Pot/Shabu Shabu and this place is really really good!  So happy it's nearby. 

They have some AWESOME flavors for different broths or soups as well as a huge variety of veggies to add.  I got the Kimchi soup with Kurobuta Pork - so so good. Really flavorful broth and the pork was really good quality. They also do a cool rice soup at the end with the leftover broth if you want something else after you're done ... if you have room. 

Overall, I loved this place. Small, steamy, but super yummy if you're craving soup on a cold day :)
author: Steph S.

description:
Decided to come here for lunch time since my brother was craving for shabu after hanging out at the beach. Plus it closes at 3 pm which give more time to eat for lunch.

When you walk inside this place, it looks very clean and modern. It was cool seeing all the wine/alcohol bottles on the wall. But this place is small.

As for the menu, they don't offer AYCE option. Its mostly set plate either regular or large. And have a lot of appetizer options. I decided to get large beef shabu shabu with spicy miso soup base which cause $16. To me, the food was average. Spicy miso has a little of the spicy taste and has a lot of flavor. And decent price

Friendly service.

Parking suck around here. Can be difficult to find parking
author: Julie N.

description:
Great place for shabu shabu. I'm in love. I usually order the miso. 

MY FAVORITE PART- the congee (porridge) that they make from the broth after your meal is the best comfort food. 

The prices are much better for lunch but they don't make the porridge so just a heads up! 

You need a reservation if you are going on a weekend night because this place is pretty popular.
author: Ashley P.

description:
Came here for the sukiyaki because I have yet to find a sukiyaki place in the bay area and was excited to see that they offered it here.

It was good but it wasn't what I was looking for. I was looking for the sukiyaki that Yojie's in SoCal offers.

Expensive for what it is. 

Won't be back.
author: Lena V.

description: Spicy miso is a little salty for my taste, I've had some at Shabuway and I liked theirs more. When I saw ramen, I was picturing the kind of ramen noodles that we go to a ramen restaurant for. However, the one they served were very thin and not as great. My husband and I really enjoyed their duck breast meat though. It's something different than other shabu shabus since they would usually serve beef, chicken, or pork. Here they have duck breast and we love it! Customer service is good, we only saw one person working when we came and she's quick on her feet.
author: Lynn T.

description: Love this place when I crave shabu shabu but place is cramped. Don't forget to save your appetite for rice mix afterwards.
author: Jin N.

description:
I came to Nabe with reservations for my bff and I on a Saturday evening. We were a little late to our reservation at 6:30, but the waiter understood how terrible parking is around here (forrreal lol) and gave us the next available table. 

After yelping around I already knew I wanted the sukiyaki. I love sukiyaki broth because it's so sweet! My friend ended up going with miso broth shabu shabu (the waitress let us know they not only had spicy miso, but just miso as well). Our pot came and the sukiyaki vegetables and noodles were already in the soup pot that was being boiled. I didn't really mind, but it was definitely unconventional for me haha. The waitress came by and gave us our dipping sauce, and a raw egg for my sukiyaki. The dipping sauce (ponzu) here isn't really my taste.. It's too sour for me. My friend and I ended up asking for sesame/peanut sauce and thankfully, they had some! The only thing I didn't like about this place was that they don't give you a bowl of rice, and also I wish that the sukiyaki had the choice of the veggies already being in the pot, or given to you on a separate plate. The veggies were good though, they included lettuce, mushrooms, shirataki noodles, carrots, some greens I don't know the name of (looked like part of a spring mix lol) and pumpkin which I had never seen before at a shabu plate haha. 

The meat came out fairly quickly and it was very neat, cut into little squares. The meat portion is okay, but for $18 I would expect a little more. The meat was delicious though!!! Good quality and super tender. I've seen on different yelp reviews that you're supposed to dip the meat into the broth and cook it, then into the raw egg mix, and then into a dipping sauce of your choice. I did just that and o m g I fell in love!!! I've never had it like that before, but now I want to order a raw egg at every shabu/hot pot place i'm at haha. 

At the end of the meal we were told to pick one broth for the zosui, which is a "meal finisher" containing rice, egg, seaweed, and scallions. The waitress boiled our rice in the sukiyaki broth and took out some of the broth to even the ratio. Afterwards, she added in the scallions and poured the raw egg on top, and then finished it with the seaweed. My friend and I were really happy with the zosui!! Too bad we were so full that we couldn't finish it all.

I will definitely be back!! I'm not sure about dinner because of the hefty price tag, but lunch is very reasonable at $12/16 for regular/large! Although I know lunch doesn't include the zosui at the end. :(
author: Tara A.

description:
This place is pretty good, kind of pricey but acceptable.
Service is good and the place is clean, very good reviews on their end of the meal porridge and it is GOOD.
Go give it a try :)
author: Michael K.

description:
Nabe may be a little understaffed and the service is slow, but it's well worth the wait for the shabu. The ingredients are fresh and they give just the right amount -- there was no fighting over the food and not too much left over vegetables. The meat was visibly fresh and easy to pick up to throw into the pot. 

I liked the choice of broth and echo everyone else's excitement over the porridge they make out of your left over broth. For me, the porridge was good, but not amazing (probably because I've been spoiled by overwhelmingly mouthwatering porridge as a child).
author: Cat B.

description:
My friend introduced me and now I can't stop going back. Nabe isn't an AYCE hot pot place but it does offer high quality meats and delicious soup bases for the same price. Unlike many of the Chinese hot pot restaurants in the area, Nabe serves Japanese-style shabu shabu. I love their spicy miso soup base and their wagyu beef is just amazing. I find their regular shabu shabu soup base a bit plain, but it could be just right for those who like a more clear broth with their hot pot. The porridge at the end is also quite awesome. They take the leftover soup and mix it with rice to give you a rice porridge. It tastes better with the more savory soup base so be sure to choose the soup of the friend with the more flavourful soup (it's one bowl per 2 people and the kimchi based soup base tastes best with the rice in my opinion). The only problem my friends and I have is that sometimes there's barely enough soup to mix with the rice cause we've used up so much of the soup to cook....

It does get quite cramped in the restaurant and you're relegated to waiting outside (even in the cold) for a table. The wait can be insane at times by the way,so be prepared.

Some might find this expensive compared to the AYCE hot pots in the area. However, for the food quality, I personally think that it's totally worth it and it's all based on your preference of volume or quality.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
A friend brought me here for my birthday, and I've been back twice since then. The sukiyaki is my favorite and I would highly recommend their yam noodles. Their veggies are fresh and the meat looks relatively lean, and even though their portions don't look huge it's a lot of food. 

At the end of the hot pot there's a rice finisher that's really interesting. It involves slightly more than just dumping a bowl of rice into the left over soup. They let the rice simmer down into a porridge and then add some toppings. A little too salty with a sukiyaki base but it's better with shabu shabu.
