For dessert their most popular seems to be the mochi cake which is what it sounds like, a blend of mochi into a piece of cake. You can choose your own ice cream on the side. I've tried the green tea and black sesame and both were really good. 

Only downside to Nabe is that the service is a little slow. It was fine when we came for an early dinner but after 7pm it seems to fill up and it's difficult to catch the servers' attention. When you do have their attention though, you have their full attention and they are very pleasant. 

Overall Nabe is awesome for a cold SF day-- the food is really great and absolutely worth a try. Will definitely be back!
author: Catherine C.

description:
Note that the Health Score is missing for some reason. It is something you will want to note: 77 with multiple violations that include high, medium and low risks.

Don't eat anywhere with a score below 80!
author: R. P.

description:
My bf and I came here on a rainy day, wanting some nice hot soup to warm us up. While Nabe did just that, it really was pretty average and honestly not making a special trip back.

First things first, Nabe is not AYCE shabu, which is why my bf and I came here in the first place. However, I'd say that going for AYCE shabu would probably be a better bet moneywise. All in all, after tax and tip, a large serving of shabu was at least $20. AYCE is not too much more than that, and you would get way more food.

That being said, the food was satisfying but nothing special. I was definitely disappointed with the serving size. My bf and I were ravenous, and I think without the bowl of rice and gyoza we ordered, we would have been hungry after. The meat itself looked like it was a good quality and the soup was tasty. The shabu shabu also comes with veggies such as napa cabbage, spinach, mushrooms, squash, and udon noodles.

Service was a little on the slow side considering how slow it was in the restaurant (we were one of two parties dining during lunch). However, there was only one waitress, so I guess I could understand. She was nice, but could have been a bit more attentive given the relative slowness of the time (she was in the back most of the time).

If you're from the city, you know how crazy parking can get around this area. Be prepared to round the block a few times and pull out a bunch of quarters.

Overall, not a bad place to eat, but not memorable either. I'd probably suggest an AYCE shabu place if a friend wanted to eat here.
author: Denise C.

description:
Overall: 4/5 
What can I say, I love my shabu shabu and this place really is delicious. The staff is attentive and friendly despite the fact of how busy it gets. What caught my eye is the special porridge that they make at the end with the leftovers from your broth. However, what wowed me was the sesame sauce that they had, it was perfection. I would definitely come back again, Nabe's porridge and sesame sauce has a place in my heart! 

I came here after I called in asking if there was a wait. Shabu house had over a hour wait and luckily, Nabe said they had a table for two! Unfortunately when we arrived, the table that they thought would leave was still sitting there and ordered another plate... So we had to wait for around 15 minutes before we could get seated. It wasn't the servers fault since we did only call in and of course no promises were made without an reservation. 

Once inside, the restaurant was TINY! There was a long table that ran down the middle of the restaurant with just a few tables on the side. I would've hated having to sit in the middle tables with a bunch of strangers all cramped up. Fortunately, my friend and I were seated in the tables on the side. But let's talk about the space (reason I took off a star)! There was barely any room for anyone to walk through and the servers had a hard time squeezing in between everyone as well. Also, I know the decor is simple and they want to keep it to a minimal given the size of the restaurant but I found it a by weird how no condiments were offered or set on the table.... 

I ordered the Shabu Shabu with the regular size Washugyu beef $19 (large $24.00) with traditional konbu (comes with a plate of veggies and udon). The traditional konbu is just water with seaweed so don't order it if you don't like a plain base! I like my broth plain so I could taste the real flavor of my beef and this was just right up my ally. But what came next was the sesame sauce and this was THE real game changer! I added this to my broth along with garlic and ahh, I was so in love!!! This sauce alone will make me come back and regarding the garlic, don't forget to ask for it or condiments because they don't have it set out nor do they mention it unless asked! 

Let's talk about that porridge though, so on point! Towards the end of the meal, a server will ask if you're ready for their porridge that is whipped up on the spot from one of your leftover broths. From there, the server will add a bowl of rice and set the heat to high. After a while, they will add some green onions, turn off the heat, and immediately mix it in with an egg. The end result is a nice, thick creamy consistency topped off with some shredded seaweed and voila, porridge is served! What an AMAZING and smart way to use up the remainder of the pot. Thank you Nabe for giving me such an amazing experience!
author: Abby C.

description:
The Nabe staff are the best. Yes, the food is delicious, the quality of the ingredients high, and the ambiance warm (sometimes literally - it gets steamy inside), but the service and care that the staff show make this place five star. They're usually very busy on weekend nights, but will try to accommodate walk-ins if they can. 

They have five (or six?) options for meals. You pick a type of broth, and then you pick the meat. The different broths come with pre-picked veggies. My favorite dish is the Shabu Shabu spicy miso soup. The Shabu Shabu option means the veggies come on the side, and the diner places the veggies in the broth when desired. You can order extra meat or veggies (I sometimes get extra mushrooms or udon noodles for my Shabu Shabu) for extra. 

Each diner will pay approximately $19-24 for their meal, however, you can choose to order one broth with one set of meat and it will come to $19-24 for the table. If you choose to order two different meals/broths - and remember each comes with their own meat/veggies, each diner is charged for the meal. They have big pots that the broths come in, and they can split a pot to accommodate two orders if needed. At the end, the servers have the table choose a broth; the server adds rice, one egg, and green onions to the broth, and serve it to each diner with a small amount of seaweed on top. Delicious, and very filling.

The sake menu is extensive, though I stick with the Asahi 33 ounce beer (more than enough for two people). They also have appetizers, but having Shabu Shabu with the finishing rice bowl is more than enough. Enjoy!
author: S O.

description:
Nabe is a healthier version of shabu shabu in San Francisco compared to other alternatives. Dinner prices are a few dollars higher than their lunch equivalent, but they have the option of doing a split pot. So if you're here with a group of friends you can choose to do both shabu shabu and sukiyaki, or some other combination. 

The meats were definitely not as fatty and therefore not as juicy and tender as the meat they serve at shabu house. But at the same time, this means they also have a lesser chance of giving you a heart attack later on in life. Their non-spicy soup is the traditional kombu soup. This soup is very very light. It is often mistaken for water with a piece of seaweed. Definitely a healthier, less-sodium alternative to the ginger chicken they have at Shabu house. At the end of the meal, the kombu soup will still taste amazing from all the beef you cooked in it. 

Nabe's shabu dinner is $3 more expensive than shabu house's and the portions are a bit smaller, but instead of the ice cream they will make your soup into a zosui rice porridge at the end by adding rice, egg, and scallions. Definitely another nice traditional touch at the end.

tip: Since the meats here are more lean, make sure you don't over cook it! You only need to dip the wagyu beef into the hot water for about 2 seconds. It's okay if parts of the meat are still slightly pink. Im sure most of you prefer your steaks medium rare-- it's a similar concept. if you cook it fully through it will definitely not taste as great. (you should do this at any shabu joint but it's especially important with leaner meats)
author: Annie Z.

description: Nabe is an upscale hot pot restaurant and its food definitely matches. I came here with my dad and brother and we ordered the sukiyaki and the spicy miso shabu. The meat tastes really good and they give the perfect amount of food. The sukiyaki had a good variety of vegetables and noodles and both broths were really tasty. One part I liked the most about this place is the porridge they make after your done with one of the leftover broths. We got there when it opened at 5 and it was not crowded at all. Will definitely be back here soon.
author: Nathan J.

description:
One of the better shabu shabu places in the bay.
It's hard to find a shabu place that doesn't fuse with Chinese hot pot.

They don't have all you can eat.
Got the ordinary shabu shabu with beef and the traditional broth and miso broth. you can also choose from spicy miso broth as well.  The miso broth is like the miso soup you have at Japanese restaurants. 

I prefer the traditional water with konbu.  The vegetables seemed fresh and the meat quality wasn't the best but it was decent enough.

Service was attentive.
I like the option of the zosui at the end which is similar to porridge but more watery.  They make it out of the broth you used.  They put egg and garnish with green onions and seaweed.

Place is small and looks modern.
author: Heejin L.

description:
I now look at Shabu dining with a whole different perspective!  I absolutely loved our first time experience here.  

The dining space is small with a simple, clean decor; sake bottles adorn one big wall of the restaurant.  The wait time could be long due to limited seating.  I would recommend making reservations in advance or at least calling ahead to be put on the wait list.

I ordered a Nabemono Set:  Sukiyaki.  This set contained Wagyu beef sliced thinly, assorted vegetables and shirataki noodles in a Warishita broth.  I substituted the noodles for, mochi (rice cakes).  The added mochi reminded me of the Japanese New Year, where this would be commonplace for the Japanese.  The broth had a sweet soy sauce flavor; it was delicious!

Accompanying my meal was a glass of cold sake, Konteki, "Tears of Dawn":  sweet rice & banana.  Instead of being an anticipated sweet sake, it was more in the lines of a Margarita, where it was salty.  As I drank it along with my meal and as the alcohol slowly took effect, it no longer tasted so salty.  

The big surprise of the evening was what they call the "final course", the zosui.  With the remaining broth in your hot pot, your waitress will add a bowl of rice, a raw egg, nori and green onions.  Stirring it all up results in a delicious porridge-like dish.  Too bad I was absolutely satiated, or else I would've enjoyed the zosui a little more; that ended up being the Togo dish.

I enjoyed both my meal and the new experience here.  This is my new Shabu-go-to spot!
author: Jeanie L.

description:
I'm not a shabu shabu person since I don't like beef. However, I liked the fact that Nabe has a variety of options and not just catered toward beef eaters!

The menu was a bit confusing, but our waitress was great at explaining the menu.  I ordered the Kimchi + Kurobata Pork Belly and the hubby ordered the Shabu Shabu.  The food was a solid 4 stars, but I wish the broth was a bit spicier.  I get hesitant to cook/order pork sometimes since it has to be cooked through if you don't want to get sick.  I liked that the pork belly are cut thinly so it's easy to cook.  My favorite part of the meal was  the Zosui rice soup served at the end of the meal.  They basically take out all the leftovers you have in your pot, then add in the rice, egg, seaweed, and green onions.  It's very unique!  Save your stomach for this part of the meal!

Pros:
- Service is excellent 
- Selection
- Decor is modern and simple
- Clean
- Great date spot
- Food is fresh, organic, & presentable

Cons:
-Parking can be difficult
-Clothes smell afterwards
author: Candice H.

description: REALLY good. I'll be back. Got a large shabu shabu with extras of egg and shrimp. The place is small but well decorated and cozy.
author: Jack D.

description:
We were 10 minutes late and our reservation was given away.  We had to wait 20 minutes.  Ain't too mad since it's our fault we late, but 15 minutes usually is the norm.

Didn't like the community table.  We had 7 people and there was a couple at the end.  We felt bad for them since we were loud drinking and eating.  

Japanese style with good ingredients.  Nothing too special for me.  I would say a lot better than the basic boring shabu house locations as this is Japanese style hot pot.

Servers didn't know about where the meat is from.  At one point, they showed me a card that they will be getting wagyu from Kyushu.  I'm not sure that will happen.  

Good sake choices.  No nama biru.

Great service from Kevin.
author: Kevin L.

description:
When Kathleen W. wanted to come by and get a mani pedi together, I said yes, of course! Afterwards, we decided to grab some dinner together..well because we wanted catch up a little. 

We ordered two "small" pots of the Kimchi and the Sukiyaki to try together. The pork belly is so good with the spicy kimchi and the beef with the sweet sukiyaki was great as well. The vegetables were amazing and a great addition to each of the hot pots. 

It's just reminiscent of hot pot at home with my parents. Lots of food in a pot cooking and amazing food. I do wish they had those fish balls or those other familiar hot pot items, but it was great for the most part. 

At the end, after you're all done with your food, they add rice and make it into a porridge. I think the porridge that they made for us was a bit too watery - needed a little less liquid, but so flavorful after we had cooked all our food. I think that was my favorite part. 

I'll definitely be back!
author: Nina Y.

description:
What's really unique about this place is that you can mix and match various styles of asian hot pot which makes complete sense because it's usually made in the same kind of pot. Most other hot pot restaurants only serve one style of hot pot (just sukiyaki etc).

Parking around the area can be hard some times. There's usually a wait if you go around dinner hours and they don't really have waiting space so you kind of have to stand outside or just wander around the area. They will call you if you leave your number on the wait list.

This is really my go-to place if I crave generic hot-pot. I get a nabemono set every time I go. I'm a fan of their Kimchi  Kurobata pork belly and shabu shabu sets. I'm not a huge fan of their seafood yosenabe mostly because everything just ends up tasting fishy in it...

When you're done with your hot pot, they'll bring a bowl of rice and eggs to mix into your left over soup and make zosui rice which is really tasty. This will definitely fill you up if you're still hungry.
author: Lily L.

description:
My new go to spot for Japanese Shabu! No only are the ingredients fresh, but there are enough options without the menu being too overwhelming. That's definitely a plus IMO! And if you want to add items, you can customize it to include exactly what you want. I typically order an extra side of mochi and mushrooms! 

The best part is at the end of the meal when they make the rice porridge with your left over soup. Unfortunately you can only choose one soup broth to make it with, but it's damn good. Trust. 

Prices are fairly reasonable. The first time I ate here, I thought it was a bit on the smaller side for a regular, but I was fooled because I found myself beyond full at the end.

It does get crowded especially on a cold SF day, so be prepared for a wait or make a ressie ahead of time. 

TIP: If you still have room after the meal, Eazy Breezy is just up the street. It's a win/win!
author: Kristen C.

description:
service was one of the best, very polite and professional. We were also able to make a reservation with no trouble, thumbs up for that! 

Food did not seem to be authentic shabu shabu, but good quality and taste! meat was a lot better quality than the other shabu shabu/hot places I have been to and the broth was very flavorful(we got the sukiyaki and the kimchi). 

Perfect for a rainy day and ask for different sauces(no extra charge)
author: Shelly L.

description:
Very impressed with this unique take on shabu shabu! I love how their sets come with different ingredients, switching up the vegetables and starches to complement the broth of your choosing. 

The sukiyaki broth is unique for shabu but Nabe does it well! I'm always skeptical of sukiyaki because often times it can be too sweet. Nabe achieved the perfect balance of sweet and savory. Ingredients were very fresh - the mushrooms, sliced tofu were my favorite and love that they give you an egg to crack into the soup. Despite all of the ingredients in the broth upon serving, nothing was overcooked as the servers were attentive and made sure to turn the heat down several times for us throughout the meal. We also had the spicy miso shabu at our table and were very pleased with that as well. 

As for meat quality, the wagyu beef was not as good as I've had at other shabu places (a little lacking in the fatty marbling) but the pork belly was delicious. 

Make sure to save room for the Zosui finisher where they create a porridge-like soup for you at the table using one of your leftover broths! The server brought out rice, egg, and nori and we chose to have it mixed into our sukiyaki broth. Yum! 

We also tried the wagyu and kimchi dumplings but they were nothing to write home about. We'll just stick to the shabu sets next time we come as it is more than enough to fill you up.

Service was very attentive and the waiter made helpful beer recommendations. The menu stated maximum of 2 credit cards to split bill per table but our waiter told us we could split the bill as many ways as as wanted before we even had to ask! Awesome service, food, and decore. Will be back!
author: Helen L.

description:
Came here recently with my dad since we've been trying to try out all the hot pot places in the city. After looking through the pictures of the place on Yelp, we decided to make a reservation which turned out to be a good idea because right when we got to the place there was already a table waiting for us. The staff were very friendly and nice and answered all our questions regarding the menu.

The food was really good in my opinion. My dad got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef with miso (not spicy) broth and I got the kimchi hot pot with kurobuta pork belly and mochi. We also got a side of rice (one split between the two of us), harusame noodles, tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and duck (the side order of duck which was $16 isn't listed on the menu). They also have the sesame dipping sauce, which we also asked for as well as it isn't automatically given to you. The ponzu sauce was more tart than other places I've been too but I thought it was great. I really liked the flavors of both broths and the pork and the beef portions were pretty decently sized. Though neither of us thought the side order of duck was worth it, it was an interesting try. 

The best part of the meal for me was the zosui rice soup. They take rice, a beaten egg, and green onions and throw it into your broth that you cooked all your food in (in this case we had a choice between miso and kimchi, and we chose miso). They serve it in your individual bowls and top it with nori strips. I didn't really know what to expect but it ended up being very flavorful (even though it was the miso broth and not the kimchi broth) and I ate the whole bowl even though I was pretty full from the main meal. When you get the soup it is BLAZING HOT so take your time eating it... and don't worry if you don't finish everything in the pot! They'll give you the rest in a take-out container.

The atmosphere of the place is what's bringing down the rating to 4 stars. It's a small place and everyone is having hot pot, so of course it was hot and a bit stuffy. When we walked in my dad mentioned that his glasses fogged up, and maybe it's better right when they open, but I thought it smelled kind of sweaty. It was great that we made a reservation because we had a table for two in the corner of the restaurant (I'm not a fan of sharing my space and sitting next to strangers).

Their bathroom is pretty nice inside. The door is a sliding door which even though I thought was pretty cool, was pretty embarrassing when I was standing outside the bathroom door for longer than 15 seconds trying to figure to whether there was someone in there or not.

Overall our meals ended up being pretty pricey (no thanks to the side of duck) but I'd come back again.
author: Jennifer J.

description: This shabu shabu place is super legit! I'd make a reservation if you could. Make sure to get rice and have them make congee at the end with the left over broth - that was my favorite part! We got the seafood and the traditional shabu shabu pork and beef. The seafood had a lot of variety and the meat came out in super thin pieces on an entire plate. The total quality wasn't that much but it cooked super fast with how nice and thin it was. I would definitely come back when in the mood for something hot and steamy!
author: Wendy C.

description: Sukiyaki is a bit too sweet, but it was pretty great over all. Would definitely recommend this place for Japanese hot pot. The rice dish in the end is the best! So flavorful and delicious
author: Mandy Z.

description: What a great way to celebrate my birthday! Dinner at Nabe in Inner Sunset exceeded our expectations! This is the best experience we have had at a restaurant since arriving in California. The venue: Conveniently located in busy 9th avenue. Adequate seating, although it can get pretty busy so you might want to call ahead to reserve a table. Incredibly simple and sophisticated decor, with a Japanese feel to it. The various bottles of sake in wooden cases is an interesting addition. The food: Delicious, great quantity and quality. Tasty broth, various options to please meat and meat-free patrons alike. Dessert was an absolute win and the zosui/ rice soup which we received at the end of our meal just tied it all together for me. Service: Absolutely great! Staff is methodical, friendly and competent. Especially our male waiter. He was sweet and attentive without over-crowding. Our male waiter (we had more than one) prepared the zosui right at our table after our hot pot meal and we were truly enchanted whilst watching him work his magic as if he was creating art in a bowl.  It felt somewhat theatrical and we lived it! Definitely going back as soon as possible!
author: Zoe P.

description: Very nice place, and food is awesome. At the last, they will use the soup to make porridge for you. it is worthy to come back.
author: 知涵

description:
Absolutely loved this place! It's perfect for a cold & foggy San Franciscan evening. I have been to many shabu/hot pot places in the city and this is definitely in my top 3. If you're in the area, I highly recommend you to stop by here. 

Tips: 
-They take reservations, so call in advance as I have walked by this place numerous times and it was always packed
-Huge parking lot across the street and a "secret" lot just two blocks away on 7th and Irving
-If you're getting the hot pot dish, ask for the special rice dish they create after you're done eating. I've never had this dish before and absolutely loved it. Leave a little room in your tummy for this (or take it to go and enjoy it for lunch). 
-Get the sukiyaki (I'm butchering the spelling, I'm sure) broth. It's 10 times better than the miso (I tasted both before ordering). 

The service was outstanding. Thank you Kevin and the lovely girl (I forget your name) that took care of my party. Both were extremely attentive and so friendly. 

Only thing I didn't like is the fact that their sake was $11 for a large hot sake, when it's normally $6-7 elsewhere. It tasted exactly the same as every other shabu/hot pot spot.
author: Anastasia N.

description:
I'm so happy my friend recommended this place to me! 

If you are craving shabu but want to be more adventurous ... then this is the place to go! Nabe is a small and modern. We came here on a Sunday night and didn't have to wait! We were greeted and seated immediately. Our waitress was very helpful. She explained the menu gave us some suggestions. 

After we ordered, our food came out pretty quickly. Our waitress explained what each dish was.

We got the Kimchi broth with kurobuta pork, large side of beef, garlic soy edamame, and extra mushrooms. Everything was very good and fresh! The broth had just the right amount of spiciness. 

After we finished, our waitress came to make the zosui (japanese rice porridge) with our leftover broth. They can take out your chunks of vegetables and meat or leave them in. We chose to leave them in. You can tell them how thick you want it! They add egg and other different ingredients such as, green onions. You have the option to choose from the selection they have! You would think that it would be awkward with your waitress stirring for 5 minutes at your table but it wasn't. Our waitress was friendly and nice! 

Overall, I had a great experience here. This has become one of my favorite shabu places in the city! 

I want to come back to try their different broths!
author: Thatcher H.

description: Nabe is my absolute favorite restaurant in the city. Best shabu shabu ever. Period. They really know what they are doing here. All ingredients are organic and the freshest. Been going here for years since they opened and going at least once a week since. Miso shabu shabu and the sukiyaki are the go-to's. Eat the GOUMA sauce over rice!!! Hilwin and her staff do a top-notch job. You will have the best hot pot experience of your life!!!!!
author: Samantha S.

description: We ordered the shabu shabu and Kamonanban. Both were delicious and had a lot of flavor. They give you a lot of veggies to add to the hot pot and they end with making a rice soup. The place is small so I would recommend making reservations.
author: Sandra S.

description:
I've been here multiple times and Nabe doesn't fail to disappoint. Their meat quality is stellar for the most part. (I think my general rule for shabu shabu restaurants is that you get there earlier for the better cuts of meat.) In comparison with lots of other shabu shabu restaurants, I'd say Nabe easily gets to be in my top 3 favorite.
Looking forward to trying their other soups, as I've only tried two kinds!

Pro-tips:
1. My most favorite thing about Nabe is the Japanese porridge. I almost always get the sukiyaki broth only for the porridge!
2. For most dinner nights, they get pretty crowded where the wait turns out to be fairly long. It's helpful to call them ahead of time, tell them you'd be there within 15-20 minutes, and Uberpool your way to the restaurant right away.
author: So C.

description:
Nabe is a classy hotpot joint - nice decor and hotpot are quite an unusual combination but Nabe does it! Walking in, you feel like you are entering a sophisticated, minimalist sushi restaurant. Despite the great decor, I think the food and the service can be improved upon a little here. 

Recommend: 
- the spicy miso broth 
- the spicy kimchee  broth (neither this nor the above is super spicy; just enough to add another dimension to the flavor!)
- thinly cut raw wagyu beef 

The dashi broth comes with duck breast laid into the soup already; once on the hot plate, we forgot about the duck, and overcooked it - definitely keep an eye on these! 

The end of the meal was the highlight where the server mixes in rice with the remainder broth, and sprinkles seaweed on top to create a very well seasoned porridge. Super tasty. 

A few comments for improvement - I wish the server had swapped our two hot pots at the halfway point of our meal - as we were a group of 6, we ordered two pots... was sad that I wasn't able to try the other pot because it was beyond my reach! Also, the meat portions seemed small for a hotpot place; in general this place is not a great value for what you get when compared to others in its category.
author: Amelia C.

description: Awesome night!  I took a group of friends out and the server was fantastic!  She explained everything and suggested some excellent sides to go along! We had Sukiyaki, Dashi and Miso dishes along with extra beef, duck (amazing) extra veggies, noodles, pork belly (incredible) and sake flights.  All was excellent- I'd order everything again but would even add more!  Fabulous!   The server made the amazing porridge at the end and it was delicious as well.  We didn't get dessert because we were stuffed.  Great CLEAN place with fantastic service.  I'll be back - soon!
author: Sandy M.

description:
Cherylynn N's 4.5 star rating for Nabe (NAH-BEH) is very spot on and I agree with 100%. Hi Cherylynn! I trust your reviews more than MBauer!

Speaking of Bauer...thanks a lot buddy for outing what was supposed to be a "secret" good spot in your blog today. And now that restaurant thanks you too for so much exposure. The unintended consequence is that now they will get a lot of "know it all's", the hipsters who got charged after watching Jiro Dreams of Sushi, will now become Hipster dreams of Douchey, bringing their Tila Tequila type Asian girlfriends to show off more sushi knowledge. If you cringed when Carrie's boyfriend in Sex and the City said "Sake to Me baby" when she ordered sake, there's more BS in the works. Bauer, why don't you all do us a favor and go to Sawa Sushi instead and stay there :-*( ? 

Anyways, I'm just going to throw it out there that maybe 85+% of Chinese and Asian Americans don't understand traditional Japanese hot pot category of food (nabemono). To them, shabu shabu particularly the all you can eat bonanza's (which I affectionately term SHA BOO), Da Been Lo, kuo guo, Little Sheep, etc etc are either all the same to them, and/ or they find shabu shabu bland as hell, and thus require spicy miso broths in their ramen...and now shabu shabu. And of course what hotpot is complete without a sucka MC remix your own jive ass sauce experience. In a world where subtle natural flavors = no flavor, variety is their spice of life, at the expense of what it should really be. Thus crap becomes the norm.

The essence of something like shabu shabu, should be an emphasis on the season, the seasonality of ingredients (as well as their quality and original taste)...plus having a cast iron hot pot of homey comforting food, to be shared with family or friends, is not just fun, but warms your heart. Spicy miso broth would in essence destroy that essence of original flavor. This is where premium quality beef, boiled in konbu broth, dipped in ponzu with scallions, momiji oroshi or ginger, is sufficient and elegant.

But not the SHA BOO BS.

So for Nabe to come in and pretty much do things right, and still give it a unique Japanese feel, right here in a city of wrong (and wrong food), is commendable. 

The interior is certainly interesting....swanky, yet very Japanese. Love the various bottles of sake plastered on the walls, and even the logo "Nabe" has that Orenchi-esque vibe to it.

But us FOB types are really here for the food.

Didn't get a chance to try the other pots yet, but I very much enjoyed the shabu shabu experience here, even though many are recommending the sukiyaki.

Here's what you can expect with a Shabu Shabu here:

If you are a traditionalist, the kelp/konbu broth is more than just "traditional water". There are humongous pieces of konbu in here. Way more than what the competition provides. Or if you have seen the version at Zabu in San Mateo, they throw in a few pieces of seaweed and call it a day, not kelp.

The plate of mixed veggies you get is of pretty good quality, but if you have more in your party you want to upgrade to extra veggies (combo platter include abura age/tofu pouches, which soaks up the broth), shimeji mushrooms (and king oyster). Ingredients are organic where possible, and this makes a huge difference in the overall experience. 

For pork there are choices of belly or shoulder.... while belly is the popular obvious choice, the shoulder cut is actually quite excellent in its own right. The beef quality here is better than Shabuway (which is better than those SHA BOO house of worship and AYCE AYCDrink excess, like a Roman orgy or Yelp Elite event from 2005).

The dip sauces have some thought put into it. The ponzu has a strong citrus accent than other places, and default one comes with momiji oroshi (minced grated daikon that has a slight spicy kick) and finely chopped scallions. Still very Japanesey. Didn't try the sesame dip, but it looked good.

Even a bowl of rice in here, tastes like a good Japanese restaurant's prep.

While I have yet to try Yosenabe, Sukiyaki, I have no doubt those will be done quite nicely too. Polite, adequate, and good solid service.

Make a reservation before coming, especially on the weekends.

If this place could do regional Japanese hotpots....ishikari nabe (Hokkaido) or even winter season kanburi (winter yellowtail) shabu shabu in soymilk broth, using organic ingredients (local if still retaining original flavor), this place would be unstoppable. As long as they don't offer ramen burgers, I will continue to come back.
author: Ken K.

description:
The menu here was a little bit counter-intuitive. There weren't any instructions and we just saw everything divided by category so my friend and I assumed you just ordered what you wanted. Turns out you actually order a broth and a meat platter to go with it in either regular or large size. The other downside here was that the waitress was somewhat inattentive. We had to ask for tea 4 times before we got it- this was on a Sunday afternoon where there were a total of 3 parties here. 

The meat and veggie platters were decent and I was surprised that we had broth choices (regular, miso, and spicy miso) as that's not something I see at a lot of shabu joints. The broth was very salty at first but as you added more meats the taste watered down to something you could sip on. If you are in any ways hungry, I recommend you order a large platter of meat. That may not even be enough. My friend and I ordered a total of 3 large and 1 regular platter of meat and I still think we left somewhat hungry.
author: Philip W.

description: A lil on the pricey side,  but definitely worth it.  Amazing ingredients and combinations. Wonderful beer and sake menu. I would even bring my Japanese parents here, and they're a tough crowd!
author: Keeks M.

description:
Nabe is my favorite Shabu place in the city! What I love about Nabe is that everything is organic- veggies, meat, eggs, etc

My favorite is the spicy miso broth and I usually get the large beef plate. It comes with side of veggies and noodles per order, and they also make porridge at the end - so save some room in your tummy.

Service is wonderful- servers are accommodating and friendly. 

Biggest con is parking.. I would def go at least 30 min earlier than reserved time!!!
author: Sarah K.

description:
Good quality shabu shabu/hot pot with a variety of soup bases that should satisfy most people in your party. 

Each person can choose a different "set" since they have split pots available. I've tried the sukiyaki, kimchi pork belly, and regular kombu pots, and enjoyed all of them. They also provide a ponzu dipping sauce with green onions and garlic. 

At the end of your meal, they'll cook a congee with the remaining soup with egg, green onions, and seaweed. You'll likely be full at this point, but it's still really tasty and great to take home as leftovers. 

Service is friendly and attentive, and very accommodating. FYI - They let me charge my iPhone 6 in the back while I was eating.

One downside is that they're a bit stingy on the sides/vegetables. I got the harusume noodles, which is basically fen si/green bean vermicelli noodle, and I felt like after only a few bites there was none left. It's also on the pricier side, expect to spend at least $25 pp here for dinner.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
This place is awesome! I took a star off because I feel their prices and portions could be better.

First off, I am a pescetarian (this means I eat fish only as well as vegetables and fruits) so I got to Yosenabe (seafood soup). I would definitely recommend calling a few days ahead for reservations because this place gets packed. The service is is 50/50. You might get someone nice and helpful or someone who is so bored with their job that they're rude to you. Anyway it's all abut the food anyway...Ha. 

Okay so my bf and I ordered the Yosenabe soup. We don't order the large because you'll want to save your appetite for the end! Please do this. Don't stuff yourself like a maniac just yet.
The ingredients are of okay-ish quality. Some of the vegetables in the soup looked a little forlorn. I like that they cut their carrots into flower shapes. That's kind of cute.  The soup also needs more noodles. There are maybe ten strands. I mean come one! If you're paying 30 for some soup throw some more noodles in there. Here's how they get you to pay more by adding sides. Don't do this again, save your appetite for the end.

The ending is delicious. Rice porridge with some egg, green onion, and flakes. I'd pay for just that!
author: Julia Q.

description:
Oh Nabe...how I love all your wonderful nabemono combinations! My go to sets are the Kamonanban (duck) and the Shabu Shabu (w/ the Wagyu beef or the Kurobuta pork belly). But you really can't go wrong with any of them! All the meats and veggies are great quality and really fresh! 

Another must is the Kurobuta Sausage starter. Great texture, nice bite of the casing and just super savory yumminess. Beware as you take your first bite as I've some across come squirters! *giggles*

And the Zosui rice finisher is a thoughtful way to end your meal. It's crazy comfort food and a wonderful way to not waste the delicious broth!

Lastly, the staff and owner round out all the reasons why this is one of favorite restaurants in SF. Courteous and attentive, while not being overbearing. 

I love introducing my friends to Nabe when they are craving shabu and are looking for something different from the usual. And everyone always walks out loving it as well!

Love you Nabe! I feel a shabu craving coming on so I will be seeing you guys soon!
author: My L.

description: This place is over rated !!! They also don't use real Kobe beef! This place lies about meat quality !!! Not ethical ! Unhappy I'll go back to shabu !
author: Jenny L.

description:
This score is based upon the average of the two visits here at Nabe.

Ever since it's opening, I've been excited to try this place because of its high reviews and the different styles of hot pot (shabu, sukiyaki, kimchi broth with pork belly, Seafood Yosenabe and Kamonanban!) that comes with Zosui at the end of the meal.
On the first visit, knowing that the place was going to be packed on a Friday night, my friend scheduled a reservation for 7:30pm for the two of us. 
Contrary to the pictures you see on the website, the restaurant looks a lot smaller and can probably fit 20 people at most. 
When we arrived for our reservation, the waitresses apologized and told us we essentially had 30 minutes to eat before a larger party of 10 came in or that we can come back in another hour.

Uh. what?

I don't think there is any possible way for anyone to leisurely finish within 30 minutes at a hot pot restaurant. 

If we had just casually walked into the restaurant and was told this, I would've thought, "Oh it's okay then. We can wait" But NO! We made a freaking reservation! It makes absolutely NO sense for us to wait another hour. 
I was pretty upset about this and seeing that we were both hungry, decided to go down the block to Ebi Sushi for dinner. :| 

A couple of weeks after, I decided to go again with a couple of my other friends, with some amount of reservation. It was a Saturday evening and was surprisingly empty. 
We decided to split between Shabu Shabu and Seafood Yosenabe with an extra order of ramen and udon on the side.  I enjoyed eating the seafood yosenabe because it has  plentiful amounts of seafood and shellfish.  One thing to note is that unlike other shabu places, you do not have rice on your side until the end when they mix it in the broth. 
By the time we finished both pots, I was pretty full and content The waitress was very nice and even offered to help take a picture of us. 

I wouldn't mind coming back again for lunch to try their other pots and hopefully, those next visits will help make me forget about that first visit...
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Love the decor and design of the place. The restroom has a sliding food behind the curtains, don't be fooled. The place is a bit smaller than I had imagined in my creative mind. The waitresses were very nice. Now onto the food. 

Sukiyaki: broth was a bit salty. 
Duck breast & leeks: my fave pot. Though still a bit too salty, it is less salty than the sukiyaki and had a slight duck flavor. 
Kimchi flavor: just got a lot of spicy notes. Kind of plain in my opinion. 

I loved the experience, as I don't believe I've had a nabemono style meal before. 

Price for 3 somewhat hungry adults 1 toddler: $150 without alcohol. A bit pricy in my book, but worth it.
author: Tina S.

description:
Nom Nom Nom, best hot pot I've had in the city so far!
I reserved a table on Open Table and it was ready and waiting for me when I walked in. :)

That place was PACKED!

We got half Sukiyaki and half Vegetarian Shabu Shabu. We liked both but because we're such meat lovers, we loved the Sukiyaki best! Go carnivores!

Anyways, food was good, service was good, and I'll definitely make a trip back.
author: Mandi W.

description:
2 problems: the portions was a complete ripoff and we got food poisoning from this restaurants. specific details about each below:

my girlfriend and i came here for date night and was extremely disappointed. we both got food poisoning and had to fight for the bathroom when we got home. i'm pretty sure none of the food was undercooked. we have hot pot all the time. the portions were terrible. they mark up their prices approximately 3 times. we ordered the seafood hot pot and it came with like 2 pieces of small frozen shrimp, 2 small scallops, a few small clams, 3 slices of salmon, barely a mouthful of noodles, and 1 shiitake mushroom. we were not full at all after that so we got the assorted mushrooms and some "wagyu" beef. the the beef wasn't very good but the mushrooms were. overall this place is a huge rip off and i would not come here again.
author: Robert L.

description:
made a reservation by phone and i'm glad i did.  pretty crowded since it's a small place for a friday night.

food - for dinner, it was $24 for a large, which was a set. and regular is $18.  each set comes with a soup base, vegetables, meat  i came with 3 friends so we ended up ordering one of each of the large sets to try all the different broths.   we ordered a kimchi broth, spicy miso and sukiyaki.   if you can, come in for lunch (which i did the first time) and it was $16 for a large. =)  the only difference is that the Lunch Set doesn't come with the meal rice finisher at the end.

also - they give you ponzu sauce for dipping, which i liked but they do not offer you garlic, orange radish, and green onions.  but if you ask, they will bring it out.  i also think they have the peanut sauce too if you prefer that over the ponzu, just ask!  friendly servers!

kimchi -   this was one of my favorite soup bases, but i would have liked it with a little more kick.  still satisfying and yummy.  

suikiyaki - not my favorite here.  i thought it just tasted like sushi bento box flavor... like teriyaki and it was a bit too sweet for my liking. it came with all the vegetables in the pot which was a bit odd, but it's just a different style.  i never had much places do this, but it would be nice if they gave the option for it to be separated. 

spicy miso - pretty yummy!!!  the flavor is soaked into each meat and vegetables and i could really taste the flavor of the broth within the meats and veggies.

veggies - came with spinach, mushrooms, cabbage, carrots and pumpkin.  all were fresh and they gave a good amount of veggies per set.

meat - the thing about this place is that each soup base comes with a specific kind of meat.  i'm not sure how lenient they are to pick and choose, but service was fantastic.  they offer pork belly, waygu beef and lamb i think.  waygu was my favorite!!  very good quality.  although very good meat, the portions were a bit small.  they cut the meat thinly, which was good, but we were all still hungry after 3 "large" plates of meat.  we had to order an extra plate of meats and veggies.  which was $4 for cabbage and $4 udon.  extra waygu - $11.  the extras came in a big plate for veggies/noodles, but $4 is a little bit much for cabbage =/

at the end, they have this rice dish mixed with the broth.  i'm not sure why people go crazy about it, but it's very satisfying and will make you full.  i would honestly prefer eating it with my meal because it's jus carbs (rice+soup), but i'm just usually too full at the end.  they mix it with broth, rice, scallions, scrambled eggs and top it off with seaweed.    it was just okay to me.

overall, i think i would just come back for lunch since it's waaaay cheaper and i can live without the rice+broth mix in the end.  service was excellent and i was very impressed by the servers.  they were very prompt and was great on checking in with my table.  i do think this place lacks ventilation and the whole place gets foggy on the windows and kind of stuffy.  

one more thing - they are using a new app called CoverApp, which lets you pay without having to get the waitress through your phone+credit card.  you just have to tell the waitress ahead of time. and since they are doing a promotion right now, they will give you an extra $10 on top of the $10 you receive when you download. awesome deal =)  thank you for the waitress who told my friend this!
author: Josie L.

description:
Oh how I love shabu...

My love for shabu is unconditional. I want it all day everyday, rain or shine, day or night... No, seriously!
Nabe is not the usual shabu shabu places you can find a dozen in the richmond district. Nabe offers the authentic nabemono shabu sets that's carefully chosen and prepared based on the soup base and the flavor of the meat.

Appetizer
Edamame with sea salt and garlic sauce - get your appetite going!
Gyoza - pan-fried dumplings with ponzu sauce
Kurobuta sausages with mustard aioli - sweet and delicious! 

Kimchi kurobuta pork belly with kimchi miso broth - if you like a spicy kick in your soup, go for it! pork belly is thin-sliced, easy to cook and very tender!
Sukiyaki with wagyu beef and warishita broth - it's a much lighter and sweeter soup with a variety of vegetables. Absolutely refreshing! 

Keep in mind, they don't offer AYCE but a set of nabe or shabu shabu is more than enough for my tummy, and trust me, I have a big appetite for a girl! (And I'm not ashamed of it!)

Don't order rice with your shabu set because at the end of your meal you will regret it! After you are finished with your meat and vegetable set, Nabe offers the zosui - they put a bowl of rice, an raw egg, nori, green onions into the flavorful soup to make rice porridge. I'm a person who loves to drink a bowl of the soup which contains all the nutrition and flavor from the vegetables and meat. I typically love to cook my udon in the soup and have that as the last bite of my shabu shabu. But after I discovered zosui, I could care less about the udon! I absolutely love zosui! The raw egg makes the soup a little creamier for the taste and you get a bowl of heaven(for me at least)! That is my favorite part of the meal! 

Never disappoint! Ok, I'm hungry now thinking about the wagyu beef, the pork belly and the zosui! Maybe I'll have that for dinner tonight! 

The service at Nabe is great! The waitresses there are attentive and friendly. :) Thanks Nabe!
Parking is tough - street parking or you can try the parking lot right across the street. It is Irving st, just be patient. Make a reservation, it'll definitely be easier!

Enjoy! xoxo
author: Mindy C.

description:
Overpriced for extremely mediocre shabu. After finishing my meal, I definitely left the place feeling very unsatisfied. I was still hungry and had waited nearly an hour just for a table. However, service was good and the waitresses informed us that they'll call us when our table is ready. So we wandered around Irving instead of waiting outside the restaurant for an hour. 

The menu was all pre-set in an odd fashion. Portions are small and the meat isn't all that mind-blowing. The broths were okay, nothing out of this world. 

Nothing really stood out to me, except when they use your leftover broth and make the porridge like concoction for you. Aside from that, I would say this place isn't really worth the time and money I spent here. Unfortunately, I will not be back.
author: Bonny C.

description: I haven't had much hot pot so my cards to compare are a bit limited. The pricing is very reasonable for the quality and quantity you get. For $21 (regular size) shabu, you get an entire plate of your choice of pork or beef and a large plate of vegetables. We opted for the spicy miso, based on other reviews, and was glad we did. For two people, we ordered two shabus, one pork and one beef option and shared. It was perfect. Not only do you have the hot pot experience, once you're finished and think your meal is over, the waitress offers you the rice portion... as this was part of the cost, we opted for it. $120 (included tip & $44 chafe of sake) later we left very full and satisfied with our hot pot meal. Definitely a place to recommend to go to as a couple or with a group of friends. Although reservations are accepted, my boyfriend and I were able to be quickly seated (~10 min wait) without one on a Friday evening.
author: Michelle V.

description: I don't really like Hot Pot, but this Japanese style hot pot is the best I've ever had. Nice, comfy atmosphere with steamed up windows make for a romantic date also!
author: Karim V.

description:
Located on the cross street of 9th and Irving is a hole in the wall shabu place. I totally didn't see this place until i pulled up google maps trying to look for the address. 

The exterior design of the place looks like a warehouse with 2 overly fogged windows. You literally cannot see inside from the outside if the temps outside is around 50F. Also the signs aren't that noticeable if you don't pay attention to the fusion Japanese style fonts. 

Interior is nicely done but very small. The walls are decored with sake/alcohol bottles. Seating is very straightforward and crowded. Feels like I didn't have enough room and the plates were all over the place. The seating next to us has their meat plate right next to mine (it's like, i should eat over). 

Meat quality was okay. Shabu Shabu order didn't have the best beef quality. Even with 5-7 seconds of quick dip, it was a little hard to bite into. Not to mention, zero marble in the meat. As far the pork belly, that was a little better, but I believe that pork slices should be a tad thicker since it can give you a little more taste (personal preference).  

As far as soup quality, nothing too special here. Kimchi bowl just had kimchi and some tofu + spices. Nothing you can't pull off at home. Miso side was just miso, bland and maybe even a little boring. 

Best part of the whole dinner was the last bowl of rice. The waitress introduced something called the zosui (but in chinese terms, it's congee). Basically they put a bowl of rice into any side of the soup you prefer. Add an egg and then sprinkle chopped green onions and some seaweed. Let it cook for a few minutes and you have a rich bowl of zosui. Super high cholesterol, but what gives... 

- too crowded, no waiting area except outside. hard to find parking as well. 
- air quality has miso smell all over. stuffy and hard to breath since there's no air condition or fans. maybe this is why the windows were all fogged up. 
+ service was excellent
author: Eric Y.

description:
My boyfriend and I admittedly came here for dinner when our original dinner plans fell through but we're glad things worked out the way they did. It was a cool enough evening for us to enjoy a little hot pot. The layout of the small restaurant is very minimalist and stylish with wooden boxes holding different bottles of sake all along the black walls. Only 2 servers were working the Tues evening we were here (though I can't see them being able to fit more), and we were promptly seated after arriving.

Our server was patient in explaining how the menu and service worked. We shared a large Shabu Shabu set with spicy miso broth and wagyu beef ($24). Each set comes with a complimentary bowl of rice, and assorted vegetable platters vary but you're free to order extra items a la carte, which we did. The broth was very good and not too spicy. If you're new to hot pot, a lot the meat and vegetables are cut in a way that don't require them to cook for very long so remember not to let them sit in there until they turn into leather or mush.

I was worried the 1 set wasn't going to be enough food but that plus the porridge they make at the end by mixing rice and egg in the remaining broth and topping it off with nori was plenty. The server warns you to leave room for it, and you should. Overall, Nabe was a great find.
author: Christina F.

description: Spicy miso shabu shabu is sooo good!! And the porridge dish after main course is especially excellent with spicy miso! Highly recommend Nabe if you love hot pot.
author: Ihsuan Y.

description: We ordered seafood Yosenabe and Shabu Shabu with wagu beef. Good quality sea food with tasty slices of salmon,  clams, scallops and prawns. Decent service and comfortable atmosphere. We also had the octopus & cucumber salad which was heavy on the cucumber with just a few very thin slices of octopus. I do not recommend it. Overall a very pleasant meal
author: theresa k.

description:
A very good Japanese hot pot restaurant. The wagyu beef is awesome, the meat is very tender. Don't cook it for too long (5 secs is about right) or the meat will become harden. Vegetable is very fresh, love the mushrooms. 

Of course hot pot is determined by the soup, and Nabe doesn't disappoint. Its taste is not as strong as Chinese hot pot, but they are quite authentic and you can have an option of 6 soups to choose from. We chose spicy miso and the sweet Warishita broth. It's a good combination, and the dip in sauce is a bit sweet and sour which complements the soup well. We ordered the gyoza as well and it was also very good. 

The interesting part is at the end. When you thought you are done, they come with additional rice and egg and they pour them on top of the soup that remains. They removed portion of the soup so what you get is a thick porridge like dish at the end which is pretty much another entree! The soup has a lot more taste at this point and I really like it!
author: Erick K.

description:
We went there for a dinner after a long day of biking in San Francisco. We were completely famished and looking for a hearty meal. Nabe was recommended by a friend who lives in the city so we gave it a try. The ambiance was modern yet warm. The service was friendly and attentive. Although the space in this restaurant is relatively limited we did not feel that our privacy was compromised.

The menu was not like a traditional Shabu menu; all the meats and broths here are already paired. We ordered the rare Duck Shabu as well as the Spicy Miso Shabu with Wagyu Beef. The Duck Shabu was very tasty. It's rare to find duck at a Shabu place. It comes already in the broth, so make sure not to leave it in too long if you like it rare or medium rare. The beef slices were thin and tender. Unlike the duck broth (which is very light), the Spicy Miso broth is flavorful enough to drink as a soup and dipping sauce optional for your meal.

The portion were average size -- if you are really hungry you might want to order additional sides. However, the good news is that at the end they will use the remainder of one of your broths to make Zosui rice soup, which resembles porridge.

Overall, good experience and food, but don't expect to pay less than $30 per person.
author: Mia N.

description:
I can not justify a pot of "hot pot food" for $120 for 4 people. My friends and I ordered 2 Large Kim Chee and 2 Large Sukiyaki portions.  The food comes out packed in a pot and you wait for the soup to boil and eat. I personally was still hungry after we ate all the meat and vegetables. The waitress did warn me that they will use the left over broth to make a porridge as a filler. Me being a germaphobe, had to share germs, since they use they same scooper to make the porridge on both sides. The rice porridge was the best part of dinner and as my friends would say "the game changer". 

Service was actually really good. Our waitress knew what she was talking about and was pretty quick in bringing what we asked for. 

If I had to share the pot with 4 people again, I would do 1 large portion on each side and two sides of meat for $11.  My bill would be about $82 for 4 people, saving $38.  

$82 for the type and amount of food I got is still a RIP OFF.  I guess the price paid, was for the Organic raw eggs I got. 

I WILL NOT BE BACK
author: Chanel L.

description:
Nabe is a welcome addition to the Inner Sunset - serving healthy hot pots with local, organic produce, non-GMO tofu, and non-drugged meats that warm the soul. They have a clean and modern interior, and friendly, knowledgeable and helpful staff.

Most of the Nabemono (hot pot) sets are priced at $18 regular / $22 large; their seafood nabe is $23 regular / $28. We tried their Kinoko Nabe (assortment of Japanese mushrooms in a miso broth) and their Sukiyaki (washyugu beef in a Warishita broth) - this comes with a raw egg which you can use as a dipping sauce, or you can cook it in the broth. Both were delicious!

Our veggies were already in the broth upon arrival. Perhaps it was the type of nabe we chose, or because their wasn't much space on our table, but I prefer to have my veggies on the side so I can cook at my own pace. I was stuffed by the time our server came to our table to make our zosui - a porridge cooked made with the leftover nabe broth. It was interesting to see the zosui right in front of us - she scooped out some of the excess broth so that the portion matched the amount of rice she was going to use. After most of the liquid cooked away, she added the egg and shredded seaweed - it was wonderful.

In terms of acoustics, it got to be pretty loud due to the hard surfaces. In case Nature calls, plan ahead - there is one beautiful uni-sex bathroom.

I agree with Cherylynn N. and give this place 4.5 stars.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Delicious food! The broth (regular) is fantastic and flavorful without being overbearing. The noodles and starch are good and the Wagyu beef is particularly good quality. Everything was priced very reasonably and it felt like the ideal confluence of price, quality, and service. Their sake flights are entertaining, and Huen was a fantastic server who even gave us recommendations for many other restaurants. Their rice dish after the meal was DELICIOUS and I wanted more space in my stomach for it. 

We had a great time and definitely will make this our neighborhood go-to!
author: River S.

description:
After numerous mediocre experiences with Shabu Shabu in San Francisco, we were excited to finally try Nabe. The steamed glass walls and crowded, vibrant atmosphere indicated that we had made the right decision - it did not disappoint. The service was slow at the beginning though it got better throughout the night.

We ordered the Sukiyaki Shabu Shabu with a side of vegetables and fried tofu skins. It came with a raw egg dip, which I've never had before, it was delicious! Everything was really fresh and the broth was tasty, wished it would have been spicier.The meat looked Will definitely try the kimchi and the spicy miso broth next time.

A quality sake selection made the meal even more enjoyable. And, the complimentary zosui, rice porridge, made with the leftover, condensed broth, topped with seaweed, was fantastic! Perfect way to end a meal; guaranteed that you will not leave hungry.
author: Elisa P.

description:
I'm debating between 3 stars and 3.5 but I'm leaning more towards 3 since I doubt I'll come back.  The style was different and unique compare to the usual hot pot and shabu I been to.  I guess it has more of a traditional feel.  I think the thing that really bothered me was that there was no lamb -__-. I think the only reason I like any form of hot pot is for the lamb!!! The fact that there was no lamb was quite disappointing.  

The rice thing they give at the end was interesting but it was a little too salty and heavy since it's cooked in the broth we had used to finish a platter of beef.  

The service was definitely great and attentive though.
author: Mimi P.

description:
My favorite place for shabu. I understand everyone is loving the all you can eat but Nabe offers more. Especially that porridge at the very end. The guy there have been so helpful and genuinely nice.l He really cares about his customers! The meat is also on point and the most important part. Consistency. Every time I go, I always feel like I got what I expected. I would like more vegetable in my kimchi soup but the balance is fantastic!

Our usual, kimchi and sukiyaki. 
We tried the duck the very last time and the duck meat was good, but it didn't hit the spot like sukiyaki. The broth for us was just not as flavorful as sukiyaki. We thought the green was a little overpowering. 

Sukiyaki makes a good savory porridge if you're not looking for a spicy porridge at the end. 

Love this place!
author: Hei Ming C.

description:
Not expensive and really yummy！

Good sevice and wonderful flavor! 

Love hotpot, and this is a very smart choice for Japanese style hot pot!! 

Lol
author: Shertam Y.

description:
Price: $$
Portion: 5/5
Selection: 4/5
Friendliness: 5/5
Convenience: 5/5

This is my man's FAVORITE spot. We always get a nabe set to share, which leaves ample room for the rice porridge at the end, and we are always full! Grab a beer and maybe a small appetizer on top and you'll definitely be good to go. The portions are not as big as some other nabe/shabu places, but I appreciate that they give you just enough. Staff is always friendly too. : )

TIPS:
- It's not downtown SF, but parking in the Sunset can be tough too, so plan accordingly.
- Make a reservation, especially if you're going on a weekend night.
- Share a nabe set with one other person so you leave room for the rice porridge at the end!
author: Tate K.

description:
Remarkable experience. Worth waiting a hot 20 minutes. 

The vegetarian udon was precisely what I had been looking for when we got here. Amazing selection of mushrooms with an incredible broth. At 12 per person it was also a reasonable dinner. Sure you can trick out the operation with swanky beef for more but my friend and i were vegetarians so no loss there.

AFterwards they convert the dregs of the soup into a thicker egg soup that somehow ratchets up a product you already thought you had figured out. I left feeling that kind of effortless, lasting stuffed that comes with eating food that your body appreciates

Also nice ambience (if a little fogged bc of the series of boiling hot pots). The shared table doesn't at all feel invasive either.
author: Houston D.

description:
Love this place!

Very clean. Awesome food. Great atmosphere. Friendly caring staff.

Try the sake sampler and the desserts! You won't be disappointed :)

10/10 would recommend checking this place out.
author: T K.

description:
Great shabushabu Japanese hot pot

First, the restaurant gets really hot so come in layers or you will regret it!
The restaurant gets so steamy that the glass wall/door gets all fogged up.

We ordered 2 large shabushabu for two people.  Had the spicy miso broth.
It's not too spicy.  The ponzu dipping sauce is really tasty.

Order the large beef platter so you get the veggies (spinach, Napa cabbage, two pcs tofu, mushrooms, squash, udon noodles) veggies may change.  But order the large meat platter because it comes with veggies and plus with the paper thin pcs of meet strips is not enough! We had to order another platter of large beef slices.  
At the end you get a porridge a sort of Asian risotto in the broth you have dipped your meat and veggies.  This is where you can taste the broth flavor sat its intensity!

You leave paying big $$ but at least you leave satisfied.
Get reservations.....
author: Jo L.

description:
Nabe is aptly named, as it lives up to its name in serving high quality Japanese style hotpot. It is very very cosy and a good place for a laidback dinner with a couple of friends. I wouldn't recommend coming with more than a group of four because this place is tiny. We waited about 40 minutes and there were only one or two groups ahead of us.

All of us ordered the shabu shabu; it comes with your choice of spicy miso, regular miso, or kombu broth. I opted for the kombu; they give a good amount of kombu whereas other places I've been will only give a tiny square to flavor the broth. The shabu shabu is $14 for lunch and $20 for dinner. It comes with your choice of wagyu beef or Kurobuta pork, udon, and an assortment of veggies, all nicely cut and of good quality. My only gripes would be that you have to ask for rice instead of it being given automatically, and that they charge for shungiku. I think for an authentic shabu shabu joint, at least a couple leaves of shungiku should be automatic. Anyways, the meat was pretty high quality, tender, and cooks very quickly. The ponzu sauce was really delicious, the sesame sauce just so-so. I like the bottled goma-shabu I can buy at the supermarket better to be honest. However, the rice finisher at the end is really a nice touch and a perfect end to the meal. The 33 oz Asahi is a perfect pairing with all of this too.

All in all I had a very good meal. I took one star off because of the above issues, and because of the lack of waiting area; the entrance door pushes inwards so it's easy to hit people who are waiting indoors. Also, the ventilation is really poor so it's just really stuffy and humid in the restaurant. However, I would definitely come back for some quality shabu shabu.
author: Elaine W.

description:
I went for dinner with a date.  Everything about this place was noteworthy.  

1.  The food was really good.  We had the sukiyaki beef and the seafood set. Then we added the pork belly. The pork belly was so good, we got another pork belly. The edamame is the best I've ever had. They do a little finale at the end with your broth -- loved it.

2.  The service is remarkably attentive. The waitresses seem not to have assigned tables. They all take care of every table. When I looked up to try to get a server's attention, she always stopped for me. A+ ladies. Very nice.

3.  The ambiance is pretty cool.  

4.  Great sake selection.  

I highly recommend this place, and I will return.
author: Michael B.

description:
Nabe, Inner Sunset's new Japanese hot-pot restaurant opened on Friday 12/21/12. Nabe is a nabemono hot-pot restaurant with a clean modern decor. They have surely drawn a crowd with their wonderful choices of broth and high quality organic, locally sourced produce.

While Nabe is a bit small on size (32 seats), it's big on "high quality" flavors. It's a must try!

Food Ordered:

- Sukiyaki - Washugyu beef with Warishita broth
- Kimchi + Kurobuta Pork Belly - Berkshire pork belly with Kimchi Aka Miso broth
* Traditional Nabe pairings, includes meat/seafood, broth, accompanied by noodles and assorted vegetables, finished with Zosui rice soup. [Reg 18., Lrg 22]

Both of the broth's were amazing! The Warishita broth had a nice sweet savory taste, while the Miso broth had a spicy kick that was just right (medium). The Washugyu beef and Kurobuta Pork belly were tasty and even came with their own dipping sauce! Be sure to save room for the Zosui rice soup at the end; it comes with an egg, seaweed, green onions, and your choose of which soup to put it in. My wife and I chose to put it in our Warishita broth which we thought came out perfect.

Quick Tips:

- For parties of 6 or more, call in for reservations.

The Good: Savory flavored soups, delicious food, and Zosui rice soup!

The Bad: Waiting 1 hour on a Friday night while watching everyone sitting at the tables eating and salivating away.
author: Matthew M.

description:
This place is the bomb! My boyfriend and I are both in college and obviously on a strict budget. We come here once a week because 1. It is affordable and 2. It is so delicious!!! This is my favorite restaurant in the world! The service is great! The good is delicious! The wait for food is surprisingly sort!!! I highly recommend this restaurant to everyone! 
Keep in mind, this restaurant is in San Francisco, and the area that it is in is very packed! So prices may seem high to others, but to locals, prices are very low!
author: Cana Y.

description:
No pictures for this lunch date with my fellow comrades but definite 5 stars for everything (except a few, no biggies though)

I called ahead of time on Saturday at roughly around 2pm because my friends and I were craving shabu and couldn't find one that was open around that time. We were stuck in traffic and was afraid that we wouldn't make it. Turns out they close at 3pm and last seating/last call is at 245pm. Made it at exactly 230pm and got seated right away. We were told that we can order anything we want up until 245pm since kitchen closes but we could stay there to finish for as long as we needed.

I got the sukiyaki broth with the wagyu beef and replaced the noodles it came with for ramen instead. It comes with a side of rice and vegetables were included inside of the broth. I can't really remember what it came with, I mean it had tofu, mushrooms, melon (or pumpkin?) Um Napa cabbage and other things but we ordered enoki and fried tofu pouches on the side.

We all ordered a large but for the beef, it didn't look like a large, rather small for a large if anything but the quality of the beef was good so I won't complain much. I loooove sukiyaki broth, you can't mess up sukiyaki otherwise you suck and they were on point with it. Their ponzu sauce, I believe was what it's suppose to be, didn't taste like what I am used to. Could be a remix of their own ponzu but I wasn't too fond of it. It was too vinegar-y or something so I didn't bother with that much.

Our waitress was extremely attentive, forgot a few things but it was no worries at all. What we all felt bad about was that they closed at 3 but we didn't end up leaving at 345pm! And for that, I WANT TO APOLOGIZE! Omg, I work at a restaurant too and I hate to be those kinds of folks who stay forever when all you wanna do is work and go home on time. But they were so nice about it, didn't rush us whatsoever, gave us A+ service with a smile and everything.

So overall, great food. Cute little place, you should probably extend your restaurant or something cause it's so small but it looks cute. Awesome service!
author: Christine N.

description: We tried the sukiyaki & the shabu shabu with wagyu beef & spicy miso broth. Personally, I liked the warishita broth that came with the sukiyaki a lot more than the spicy miso broth. However, the porridge that they made using the spicy miso broth at the end of our meal was pretty great.
author: Cici A.

description:
Shared a pot with a friend tonight. The sukiyaki beef. 

It was delicious. The broth in particular was something special. 

extras: We ordered extra wagyu beef for the pot, some of the garlic/soy edamame (best ever), and an order of gyoza (also good). 

We also had a cool Japanese soda (Ramune). The dessert was pretty good, but the rice porridge at the end really overshadowed it. If you don't see it coming it can be like a second meal. 

Service was fantastic. I have been a few times and each time they are happy to explain how things should be eaten. 


We were seated right away, but we got the last table, and most people were coming in with reservations (on a Tuesday), so I will probably start doing the same. 

This place is definitely a step above all other hot pot places. I think it warrants the extra money for the quality of the broths and the great service.
author: Griffith P.

description:
I've eaten here solo and in groups with excellent experiences. It is tight--you may have to sit next to strangers unless you sit at a table so come early.

They have decent to good sakes very expensively priced. Usually better sake is served in  a masu/box of 180 mL, here YMMV (your mileage may vary) in a shot glass with ~100 mL fill. So I usually order one or two sakes until the meal arrives and then switch to beer.

'I like the spicy miso broth the best', said Goldilocks, 'the traditional kombu broth is too light and the sukiyaki broth too sweet for me'. Servers have been friendly and attentive. As a finale, a server will prepare zosui/porridge with the broth...the perfect way to end the meal and satiate. No desert at Holy Gelato up the street.

fyi: windows get steamy. Can get noisy depending on customers. Proximity to strangers may make first dates awkward. Eating with a group has been less enjoyable than solo or +1. Maybe because of the tendency to put too much cold vegetables in the broth and stop the boiling. Maybe I just get cranky when I'm hungry.
author: YearOf M.

description:
We ordered two regular servings - one wagyu beef in spicy miso broth and one pork belly in kimchi broth. We also tried the sausage appetizer, which was actually really good. The casing was crispy and the inside hot and juicy - and the mustard aioli's kick paired really well with it. It was quite salty though, so I would have preferred to eat it over the course of the meal with my rice. 

The hot pot was good - we were both very satisfied with our meals, but honestly I think it was overpriced for the actual meat/vegetables we got in our pots. I think a big reason why we were full afterwards was the rice porridge they make after you meal from your leftover broth, which is super cute and a nice touch, but doesn't make up fully for the rest of the overpriced meal. But the flavor was very good (especially the kimchi broth), so I would have given it 3.5/4 stars based on this. But the problem was the service. The waitresses were all friendly, but they rushed us...A LOT. I understand that it was a weekend evening, but from the start of the meal until the very end, they kept trying to either push us to order or take away our food or at the very end, actually asked us to leave. I certainly felt rushed at the end when they came to make the rice porridge, but the worst part was when we had paid for our food and just wanted to sit a bit to figure out where to go next without having to navigate outside in the cold and were asked (nicely) to leave for the next customers. It just wasn't the type of customer service I was used to from a restaurant of this caliber. For that, I would probably rate this 3 stars.
author: Cissy C.

description:
Hottest pot I've been to in the Bay Area yet. 


THE POT:

Good portion size, quality flavors (spicy miso),  comes with a side dipping ponzu like sauce which was great. Kimchi was delicious, and plentiful for the price 
Meat was super tender and delicious. They finish with an excellent rice porridge which they pour into the pot, soaking up all the tasty leftovers. 

Can't wait to go back!
author: Patrick T.

description: My family and I live in the neighborhood so come to Nabe regularly. We discovered it after my husband spent some time in Japan and came back looking for the best sukiyaki in San Francisco. Lo and behold it was just down the street from us! Awesome food, great service.
author: Urban C.

description:
Overpriced... I've had better quality of meats and vegetables at AYCE places, and paid less for the experience. What you get seems skimpy for what you pay, and while it doesn't taste bad, it does little to convince you that it's worth the money. 

Cramped, poorly ventilated, close quarters. The only way to avoid feeling like you're in a sauna is to have the front door open, which ticks off the people in the room who feel cold easily. 

Strange menu. They devote a lot of effort into pushing you down set meat and broth combinations, requiring each table to lock into at least one. It's an absurd practice... just let us pick broths and order what we want off the menu. We ended up with way too few vegetables and noodles. 

Also: one of the broths (kimchee) came with its vegetables and tofu already floating in it. It was odd... I thought the point of Shabu was do-it-yourself at your own pace. 

Very understaffed. The place is small, but it was packed. There was one waiter and one food runner for about ten tables with about 30 customers. Getting our reserved table was slow. Getting the order in was slow. Everything was slow. Our dinner for four people took over 2:15. 

There were two things that kept this place from getting a 1-star review:

- While the spicy miso broth wasn't spicy at all, the kimchee broth was delicious. An unexpected and very pleasant twist. 

- At the end of the meal, you pick one of your broths and they make a rice porridge out of it at your table. We picked the kimchee broth. It was excellent. And you couldn't help but feel for the lone waiter as he made our porridge thanking us for our patience with the service. They should have more staff on the floor, but man that porridge rocked. 

It's only fair I should mention that while nobody in our party was gushingly joyful about our meal, I was the only person in the group who was this dissatisfied with the experience. 

Overall, though: you want some Shabu? Go somewhere else. These are not the droids you're looking for.
author: Walter P.

description:
A nice variety of soup bases to choose from.  Compared to other places, the portions aren't that big and it's a bit pricey.  The Zosui rice soup at the end was interesting, and it's really what filled us up.  
It's a really small place, and with the way the tables are arranged makes seating feel cramped.
author: Karen L.

description:
Had zero issues with finding a seat for two.  We ordered the Shabu Shabu w/ Waygu and the Kim Chi w/ Pork Belly.  All I got to say was this place is good!!!  My Kim Chi soup was perfect and had the right amount of spice.
