Place is small with a great customer service.  We put garlic in our soup and the aroma seas blasting in our faces...lol.  

Definitely coming back.
author: Teejay C.

description:
Love this little gem in the city! I've been here several times and the food & service never disappoints.

FOOD:
Favorites: 1. Wagyu beef + spicy miso broth and 2. pork belly + kimchi broth. Meats are always high quality and they provide a well-sized portion of veggies/additions to your meal. I normally share a large dinner order with another person, which I find to be the perfect amount of food. At the end of your meal, they give you the option of a rice finisher (a "porridge" made with your broth, rice, eggs, scallions, and seaweed). Super yummy - get this! It will definitely fill you up if you aren't full already.

Tip: you can mix and match your meat and broth combos and switch out certain items (ex. I usually switch out the mochi for udon noodles)

SERVICE:
Friendly and prompt staff. All positive experiences thus far!
author: J C.

description:
Clean, delicious food, great service, great atmosphere! Best Shabu spot in the city.

Only drawback is the difficulty finding a parking spot on weekend evenings. I'd recommend going there early (5-6pm) and hang out at Yancy's Saloon (sports bar nearby).
author: Sora L.

description:
Ate here while vacationing in the Bay Area with my big brother last Fall of 2014.  It was in the month of September, to be exact!  This is a good place to go for Shabu Shabu.  It's small, modern and semi-classy.  The meat was tasty, produce was fresh & seafood broth was good.  What I loved most about this place is the free Japanese-style rice porridge service they provide.  They use the broth that's left in the hot pot to: mix one bowl of steamed white rice, seafood and a raw egg.  It's yummy & one of the highlights of the hot pot experience...

I also dig their in-house green tea mochi cake.  It's not too sweet and perfect to share with your date, friend or anyone else you came with... :)))
author: Content O.

description: This place is great.  But the parking majorly sucks big time.  Parking is all free in the evening but we roamed around and around.  Luckily there was no wait for Nabe and they were friendly and efficient.  The sukiyaki and seafood yosenabe were amazing.  The veggies and random fish cake were good and the salmon and shrimp were delicious.  The zosui rice at the end with our yosenabe broth was the cherry on top.  Would definitely come back soon (via bus?).
author: Chris L.

description:
3.5 stars!

Nabe is a new trendy Japanese Shabu Shabu restaurant that recently opened in the Inner Sunset. It's a bit out of place, but it works - "diversity". The interior of the restaurant is simple, yet modern. It also puts the small amount of space into good use as you basically share one long table with other customers. Good for people who enjoy others' company, bad for people who like a more intimate environment.

The service is excellent. The waitresses are friendly and personable. They are also very knowledgable in the menu (though not many options). They would explain in details what is in the soup base and the idea behind it, and etc. 

The food is okay. It's like an average Shabu Shabu place. I didn't find the meat to be extremely fresh, but definitely up to par with other places. The beef is nicely marbleized. The soup bases were decent, but nothing to rave about. Though the sukiyaki broth was too overpoweringly sweet, The spicy miso was not spicy at all. The Shabu set also comes with some veggies and noodles. I would have liked more noodles and veggies, but whatever. The porridge at the end of the meal is a nice and innovative touch. They basically bring out a bowl of rice and put it in the soup base of your choice (already at your table). One of the waitress will cook the porridge for you and add toppings such as green onions and seaweed. It was quite delicious, probably my favorite part of the meal!

It is reasonably priced, but the portions are not that big. I'm usually not a big eater, but I felt that the regular portion was just almost right. It got you to a somewhat satisfied state, but not too full. But you could probably snack on a couple more things before you're full. I didn't see much of a difference between the large and regular portion, I would have liked more meat..
author: Michelle L.

description: It's really good, clean and yummy, make sure you have reservation first, fills up fast! We ordered the beef and the duck both are very good, the broth is just right, not too salty. love the little complimentary porridge afterwards. But I wish there's a little more vegetables and noodles. Overall I will go again!
author: Abby L.

description: Decided to stop by Nabe after hearing all the good words about this place. My brother suggested getting the duck set, so we ordered that and added beef Wagyu as the side dish. Boy it was by far the best duck hotpot I had. Beef Wagyu taste very good as well. Love the finale part where they added rice to the soup to make "rice soup". Minus 1 star because they don't have lamb meat.
author: Joline K.

description:
Meaning to try them ever since I saw them under construction, I finally had a chance to drop by two months ago, sharing a split pot of their kurobuta pork belly with kimchi broth, and kamonanban (duck breast with dashi broth) with a friend [ Photo: http://instagram.com/p/YhLxG9Qfrq/ ].

Nabe is a bit unlike the other hotpot places around the city, neither serving up AYCE hotpot, nor individual portions accompanied by too many side vegetables. Instead, most of what you're going to have is already in the pot, with the exception of the mochi and rice sides. And, after you're done with your meats, rather than noodles, you can have them use one of the remaining broths to make zosui (rice porridge/congee).

Okay food overall, with nothing standing out in particular. And their zosui, unfortunately, is unbearably salty, unlike other places I've been to that offer this. Your choice of broth will certainly have something to do with this, but my recommendation is to have the zosui made, and then packed to go so you can dilute it back at home with more rice and water/plain stock. Can't let that food go to waste, after all! But, while Nabe is not a bad choice, I personally will probably stick with some of the other hotpot options around the city.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Semi-accessible, from what I recall. The seats up near the entrance are somewhat accessible, but the walkways to the back are narrow enough when there aren't customers that it's near impossible when there ARE customers.

Bathroom - I didn't check them out, but given the above issue with narrow walkways, you'd have a hard time getting to them, even if they were accessible.
author: Johnny W.

description:
If you're looking for a quick, expensive place for dinner, come here!

Greeted by the sweetest lady who, I couldn't recall her name, if she even disclosed it.
Overall, my experience was extremely underwhelming for a place I had no expectations for.

- Service: 2.5/5
- Menu was difficult to read due to font choice: 0/5
- Premium Sake Flight: 4/5
- Kinoko Nabe w/ spicy Miso, added Wagyu Beef and Pork Shoulder: 3/5
**Hot pot ended up getting pretty low and the broth refill didn't arrive until everything was pretty much gone.  Meat was phenomenal though.

- Rice Porridge: 2.5/5
**The attempt at small talk was nice but was poorly executed and made me uncomfortable all around, not saying she shouldn't have attempted to make small talk, I'm saying if you're going to, be a little more comfortable.  Rice porridge itself should have came with meat and the the green onions should have been left at the table.  

- Would come back for Sake, only.
author: Noey A.

description: The food was okay. I wish they didn't put the seafood portion in the pot for us before serving it out. It just made everything look soggy and unappetizing.
author: Lana T.

description:
****Pricy But Delicious Hotpot/Shabu--Especially the Rice Porridge****

The best part of the meal here is the rice-based porridge they make out of the broth from the hotpot after its done. It's undoubtedly chock-full of sodium but also one of the tastiest things I've eaten this year. 

The place is tiny. Definitely a younger crowd--both patrons and waitresses. The food is good but pretty pricy. Maybe b/c I'm used to AYCE hotpot, but the serving of Wagyu beef with the Sukiyaki seemed minimal--the veggies/noodles that come with it are really what's filling you up. If you want to pig out on meat, this may not be the best place. The seafood pot was pretty good. 

FINAL VERDICT: Cool atmosphere and incredibly delicious rice porridge. Otherwise good but a little overpriced for how much food you get.
author: Nick S.

description: Awesome shabu spot. I highly recommend the Sukiyaki over everything. It comes with Kobe beef and the soup is just a delight. At the end they make a delicious porridge with rice, egg, green onion, and seaweed. Great for a date too!
author: Joyce M.

description:
After looking for parking for 20 minutes, our dinner at Nabe was well worth it. Service was great even when we made a mistake on ordering. At first we order a split pot with one soup base in one half and another soup base in the other. After everything came out, we changed our mind (since one was spicy). The staff was very accommodating and brought us out another whole bowl with just the non-spicy soup base we liked. 

The only down side is that dining area is pretty small, so I would suggest making an RSVP before coming here. Also, if you don't mind sharing a pot, it is cheaper to buy one set meal, then add extra meat or vegetables on the side. the portions for the side purchases are the same as the portions provided in the main meal. 

Also, don't forget to save room in your stomach for the last dish, which is basically porridge made from the remaining soup base from your meal with some extras.
author: Rex R.

description:
Hot Pot is a very confusing experience for newcomers. My friend and I dressed up to get down and were greeted by a very kind waitress who knew she had some Nabe n00bs on her hands.

They have instructions in the menu and will describe each of the broths to you thoroughly. All the meat and veggies brought out to us were very delicious, as well as the sauces. 

The Sukiyaki broth is very, very good. This is the one we opted our rice porridge to be done in. The porridge is included at the end of the meal, and was probably my favorite part. 

We also tried the sake flight and it opened my eyes to sake not being totally bitter and off-putting. I liked all three of the sakes I tried. 

Very economical for the mass amount of food you get. Two small broths is more than enough for two people.
author: Sam D.

description:
3.5 stars. The awesome manager got my family and I seated quickly, even though we didn't have any reservations! Thank you so much! 

Now we ordered 4 sets; seafood, kimchee, sukiyaki and this mushroom thing soup. I'm not going to elaborate on how each one tasted, cause my review will be too long and bore everyone to tears. Everything was good, portions were normal (had to order another plate of beef though, not very filling but was tasty). 

The place was a bit small, I disliked how everyone can hear each other's conversations. But the waitresses seemed extremely kind. Though they didn't really engage with us as much as they did to the other people surrounding us (probably cause my parents didn't understand English). 

It was awesome how they offer to make porridge with our leftover soup. Unfortunately we were too full. But I wasn't too full for dessert! 

The green tea ice cream was good. But the green tea cheesecake was too sweet and dense. I tried to finish but my throat kept closing up. Cookie was okay I guess, I had a small bite but it wad too hard for me to chew. 

Thank you to everyone who worked there. Y'all seem nice and had really fast and great service! 

Btw, it seems like everything is supposed to be organic! And cows are grass fed. (overheard that from the seat next to us).
author: linda t.

description: I think Shabu-shabu is the best choice for this restaurant. The quality of their beef is pretty good.
author: Po-Yu K.

description:
New favorite shabu place!! I like how they do the combo sets, all the ingredients in the combo set are well thought out. For example, with the "one pot" sukiyaki set, they made sure to use noodles and veggies that wouldn't disintegrate when overcooked.  

I preferred the warishita broth over the spicy miso broth. The warishita broth was on the salty side, which was excellent for seasoning the veggies and meat, but not good if you like to drink the broth on its own. We ended up using the warishita broth for our porridge at the end.  Oh, and just a tip...the porridge is HOT but don't be a rookie like me and blow on it to cool it down. The nori topping is very flakey, powder almost and I got a face-full.  At least it tasted good!

The price point is closer to what I would except from an all you can eat restaurant but the quality of meat, veggies and broth were excellent.  Next time, I think we will stick with one set and just add on additional items.
author: Phoebe L.

description: My friend and I ordered the Nabe with seared duck and it did not disappoint. One of the better shabu places in SF. They had Mochi which had perfect consistency when boiled. The beef was also perfectly sliced. And one of the best parts, at the end instead of wasting the leftover broth, the servers make a complementary porridge.
author: Fernilla S.

description: I don't actually like their shabu... but what I do like is at the end of your meal, they use your left over broth to make porridge. That stuff is delicious! I literally come here just for that.
author: Lina C.

description:
Modern and minimalist, Nabe and its steamy storefront intrigue passerbys. Contributing to Nabe's Japanese zen vibe, sake bottles line the walls, along with its chic vibe, dark walls, and hipster customers.

Nabe is a higher end shabu shabu shop in Inner Sunset. They also serve sukiyaki. Everything is kept pretty simple. The meat quality and vegetable quality is key. Spicy miso broth cannot be found here; rather it's a focus on simple kombu broth, nice quality marbled beef, simple sauce choices, locally sourced vegetables (pumpkin!), and more.

The meal concludes with a tasty rice porridge - a bit too tasty, with too much salt. All in all, a great experience, though I would have preferred to see more variety.
author: Jay C.

description:
Ok this is my new favorite place for shabu if you want quality and a little something special (the porridge meal at the end)! 

Situation: Date night last Friday night with the bf. We had a reservation and got there a bit late due the craziness of parking in the area. I walked in and BOOM my glasses immediately fogged up! It was like a hot sauna in there because there are no windows and so much hot-potting going on!  This was a terrible day to wear my glasses - I should've just gone with contacts!  Anyway, moving on - Our table wasn't ready yet, but it's such a small space, I can understand that it's hard to predict customer flow. After about 15 minutes, we were seated. By that time, my glasses had gotten accustomed to the temperature inside, so I could actually SEE across the table at my food and my date now. 

Order: I had to get the beef shabu shabu with spicy miso broth (to compare with all other shabu places, you know?).  My bf got the duck shabu in soy sauce broth.  My beef was sliced very thin and was very nicely marbled, but without any gross chewy fat. It came with a plate full of veggies and noodles.  The spicy broth was a medium spicy, something that I could handle but that my bf also felt had some kick to it.  To my surprise, the duck was also amazing. It came with everything already in the pot and I was worried that the duck was going to overcook before we could eat it all, but the last bite was just as tender as the first.  Plus, all the veggies in there were soaked with so much flavor by the end, especially the tofu! Save some room though because when you think you're done with the meal, they bring out the rice, egg, and scallions and make an amazing porridge out of your favorite broth. We chose the spicy miso and did not regret it!  I will be making this porridge at home...

Service: The staff here was super communicative during our wait, and friendly and attentive during our meal.  It was also very nice of them to make the porridge for us. 

Pro tips: Save some room for the porridge at the end!  Parking here can also be crazy so try to get here a little early. There is a small lot right across the street, but it gets filled pretty quickly.
author: Janet Z.

description:
The bae and I decided to check this place out after yelping a few hotpot/shabu spots in the sunset. I suggested that we try some place new--and so we both agreed on Nabe. 

When we arrived, we were greeted by one of the servers and he allowed us to choose our table since the restaurant wasn't too packed. After being seated, another server came by and kindly explained the menu thoroughly to us. Apparently, the restaurant serves nabemonos(aka nabe) and not your basic shabu. On their menu, there was a list of different nabe sets and our server explained that all sets but the shabu shabu set(yes, it's still an option here!) come with a pot of broth that already contains most of the paired items inside of the pot--whereas for the shabu shabu set, the meat, noodles, and veggies are all given separately. I wanted shabu at the start because I wanted to cook my own food yakno, so we ordered the shabu shabu set with beef and miso broth and the kimchi with pork belly set. Now let's break it down:

Food-Super yummy! The shabu shabu set was like other shabu I've had--but still good. The kimchi set was my fav *o* The bae also agreed that the kimchi was also his fav, hehe. The level of spiciness of the broth was perfect. I love eating spicy food even though I can't handle it well LOL, but it was still bearable. Pork belly of course was good, obvi. Best part about the kimchi set was that it came with little mochi cubes instead of noodles!! When we cooked it in the broth, it became squishy and just amazingggg. 

Best part of the meal had to be the rice finisher. When we were done eating, our server asked if we were ready for the rice finisher and I was like "Okay!", but then bae and I looked at each other like huh?? She came back with rice, egg, seaweed and green onions and explained to us that the rice finisher(zosui?) is served at the end of each meal. We chose to have it prepared in the kimchi broth and omg, it was so good. It is basically rice soup/porridge/jook/chao/whatever you wanna call it--but better. You can say that we both left with with a food baby.


Environment- The restaurant layout is really cute and compact. Not many tables and the aisles were quite small, but still walkable. Everything looks clean and simple. Although the restaurant was sort of empty when we got there, by the end of our meal, the restaurant was SUPER packed and it got pretty humid inside of the restaurant. 



Service-EXCELLENT! Although there were only 2 servers and there was a full house, both were very attentive and were super friendly. Our cups of tea were never empty and they checked up on us here and there.



Overall, I'd say my first visit to Nabe was enjoyable and will most def return!
author: Krisna T.

description: Get the Kimchi broth with a side of beef! The food here is so good every time I visit. The meat is of the highest quality and the broths are very flavorful. Not really sure if the beef is actual Wagyu but very delicious otherwise. A must if you're looking for something tasty to eat in the area.
author: Arda S.

description: It was the weekend of OSL and my friends and I wanted a substantial meal prior to the festivities. We decided on Nabe, which turned out to be an awesome choice! The decor was really nice with minimal wooden frames and metal accents. The wall of sake was a fancy touch to an already cool looking restaurant. My party and I ordered 3 shabu sets - spicy miso, sukiyaki, and kimchi broths. The spicy miso and sukiyaki were the best of the 3. The kimchi flavored broth didn't have enough of that spicy and pungent kimchi kick. Each set comes with a side of the per usual veggies you would find at shabu. I.e. Tofu, enoki mushroom, Napa cabbage, spinach, and cute little stars cutout of carrots. We ordered the wagyu beef and pork belly. Both meat selections were delicious, although, the pork belly was cut a little too thin and didn't have much texture. The beef definitely went faster than the pork, as it had a better chewy texture. What sets Nabe apart from other shabu houses was their plate presentations of the food and how extremely clean the place was. I'll definitely be coming back again for more good times!
author: Josh S.

description:
Good portion.  No wait if you go early (although you can make a reservation).  Fresh ingredients.  Love love the porridge they make for you using the leftover broth with a bowl of rice (they also add an egg and put some seaweed strips on top).  

It's a relatively small place, so make sure you either go early or make a reservation.
author: Isabella F.

description: Excellent hotpot. They send you home with rice soaked in your left over hotpot broth. They were incredibly sensitive to my friend's glutton sensitivity and the ambiance of the restaurant was very relaxing. I am excited to bring my friends back to Nabe.
author: Erik D.

description: Hot pot heaven! Had two large sukiyaki for a table of 4 (it was more than enough)- one with kimchi and one with duck and leeks. Plus side orders of udon, kabocha and mochi. Melt in your mouth wagyu beef and kurobota pork shoulder sliced paper thin to cook in rich broth with noodles, assorted mushrooms, radish and cabbage. Don't forget to save room for the rice porridge, made tableside in the leftover broth with egg, scallions and nori. I wanted to take it home and eat it for breakfast. So full, so sated!
author: Emily L.

description: I never really noticed this place until recently when my friend mentioned recently it in a conversation. That's when I decided to try it out a Sunday evening. Our group of four people got there close to opening time and the restaurant was practically empty, only one table occupied. Waiters were pretty attentive and gave us instructions on what and how to order. We ended up choosing four different soup broths: Kimchi, Shabu Shabu, Sukiyaki, and the Soup with duck/soba. Overall, I liked the sukiyaki and the duck broth the best. They were really flavorful and the sides paired really well with the complexity of the soup. Also I really enjoyed the porridge they made at the end of the dinner because it really filled us up and was a nice way to end our meal. It's really cool how there prepare the porridge in front of you! I liked the overall meal presentation, unfortunately, I would have preferred to share two broths instead of ordering four separate ones because 1) it would have been cheaper 2) I didn't really care for the other broths. With that being said, meal was sorry pricy and I would probably only come back here for the Sukiyaki and the Duck Broth.
author: Jessica E.

description:
Call in before you get there so they can put your party on the wait list!
I called in about 20-30 minutes before I got there and a waitress called me back when we were up and our table was free.
We eventually found parking in the lot across the street but that area in general is just a pain in the ass to deal with.
We arrived with the windows all fogged up and were seated shortly after.
Waitresses are very nice and attentive and let you take your time to order and will gladly explain what everything is.

Nabe's hot pot is a bit different from all the other hot pot/shabu places that you go to and that's what caught my taste buds attention.
You order a set which comes with the listed ingredients/soup flavor.
My boyfriend decided to split half half so we could try more things and went with the large beef shabu shabu with spicy miso soup and another half of the pork belly with kimchi broth.
When our pot came the kimchi broth already had all the ingredients in the pot, with a large plate of pork on the side and mochi.
With the shabu shabu you add everything into the soup yourself.
I liked the kimchi broth, the soup was very flavorful and I loved how it was filled with a lot of vegetables. The marbling on the beef for the shabu was also very nice, the meat was tender.
Their sesame sauce is also good, it's more on the watery side which I like.

We were too full to try the zosui rice at the end but will be back.
Sucks that they run out of Sprite. Who runs out of Sprite?!
author: Jenny Y.

description: This is one of my favorite Shabu Shabu places in the city. My friend and I came for lunch on a Friday. Arrived right when it opened so no wait at all. It's a little cute place for Shabu Shabu. We ordered the spicy miso broth. I've tried other place's spicy miso broth but Nabe takes the cake. My friend got the Washugyu beef while I went with the Kurobuta pork. Everything was delicious and for a great price. Wish they had spicy hot oil though. I love my sauces spicy!
author: Melanie C.

description:
The best shabu I've ever had. Also, you can get unlmited food and drink for a pretty reasonable price! Made the mistake of going here on a weekday. Definitely would get the best value by going on a Friday or Saturday and doing the unlimited deal.

Unfortunately, the service was pretty horrible. I asked for more meat at least 4 times before they finally remembered to bring it. Still giving them 5 stars though because the food made it worth it.
author: Mike W.

description: Wow! I have to say this place was really great if you're looking for a place to eat quality shabu shabu. It somewhat compares to the places in LA with its range of different broths. The place is pretty small. but it definitely beats the shabu shabu restaurant in Japantown = TERRIBLE.
author: Regina S.

description: For a girl that rarely craves shabu, I have a soft spot for Nabe.  I would definitely recommend the sukiyaki here!  The other broth I tried was the kimchi kurobuta pork belly and I wasn't as big of a fan of that one.  The sauce and all the add-ons are all pretty good too.  The waitresses are very sweet and accommodating and I love that they mix your leftover broth with rice and egg, green onion, and seaweed at the end.  This was a traditional Japanese porridge and you can even take it home if you don't finish it.  I left Nabe feeling very stuffed and happy! It is perfect for all those cold SF nights :)
author: Lily T.

description:
Came here today with a group of friends. Food was decent. However, the ventilation was so so and I felt like I was in a sweat lodge. The restaurant setup is extremely narrow so it feels a little tight at times. I will say the waitresses were extremely warm.

Unlike other shabu places, they have individual servings of shabu v family style. The meat quality was delicious but I felt like the slices were ridiculously thin and I wanted 2x the quantity that I got. The spicy miso broth was ridiculously tasty esp with the udon noodles. I love the fact that they turn the soup into porridge at the end. 

This place was tasty but a little steep compared to traditional hot pot places. I still have a soft spot in my heart/ belly for Chinese hot pot places like little sheep.
author: Grace Y.

description: Spicy miso soup is the best I've ever had; beef and pork belly are both tasty and sliced very thin; and like all the rest have said - we all loved the extra touch at the end of cooking rice in the leftover broth with egg and spring onions to make a nice bowl of delicious porridge.
author: Ni X.

description:
ZOSUI???! What the best idea ever! This ending dish that the waitress makes for you with your leftover broth is ten million times better than making udon!! I keep thinking about this rich risotto-like bowl of rice. They basically cook down the remaining broth with rice (we used the spicy miso) until it's thickened and starchy, then briefly mix a beaten egg, then add green onions and top with seaweed. Rich, fresh, flavorful... I could go on for days.

The set combos of soup base, meat, and fixings are unique. Meat options of pork belly (sliced super thin so they cook up very delicately soft and tender), duck, wagyu beef. Interesting starch options - sweet potato noodles, mochi (MOCHI?! seriously). 

This time I had the kimchi broth (it's not overly sour/tangy/fermented but still strong enough so I didn't drink the broth with each bite of food as I normally do - it imparts plenty of flavor to the food while cooking), and my bf had the spicy miso. Both solid, and I would recommend.

I honestly want to come back here to try all their flavor combinations. Very good first experience on unique food, flavor, and service. I may bump this up to 5 stars after trying a few more items.
author: Christina W.

description: Married to a hot pot fanatic, we came here for dinner on a weekday night. It was pretty empty at first but boy did it get jam pack quick. The service was quick and great however we're deducting one star for the small cramp location this place is at. Wished it wasn't in such a small place, then again some of SF best spots are in some small little hole. Had the sukiyaki. Great concept and yummy broth,  it was just a tad too sweet for my liking. My husband got the spicy miso with the beef. It was ok, nothing too special. Probably wouldn't come back again since these dishes can all easily be made at home.
author: Kaykay M.

description: Came here a month or so back with a few friends for dinner. It was pretty busy for a weeknight so there was a little wait. We got seated in the back of the restaurant and looked over the menu. We decided we were each going to get shabu. This came with a plate of meat and a plate of veggies with udon or you can opt for rice. We got the spicy miso broth and it was okay.. Needs more flavor I think. Meat was okay too, shriveled up pretty small. All in all I wanna come back to try the duck but I prefer other shabu places. Service was a bit spotty and hard to get attention because it was busy but that's understandable.
author: Tiff C.

description: Pretty good, I must say! It's not all you can eat like some places, but you don't need that here. You pick and choose what you want and you can have up to two broths per pot. Service was really accommodating when I went it was with a large group. Also, I really love the "finisher." They make your broth that you have left into a porridge right in front of you.
author: Julie L.

description: Food was good. Space wise, it was a little tight. Other than that, the food was good and service was quick.
author: Billy G.

description: The Wagyu beef & pork belly is really good! They do offer high chairs but the place is kinda small so I don't recommend bringing small children here. FYI, I was cracking up because I thought the bathroom was a push/pull door but it's a sliding door. That fabric hanging as a decor for the bathroom door is very annoying. The sauce is very good but remember to ask for some hot sauce. Oh, they offer to cook you porridge with the left over soup so don't eat too much! Cute place overall!
author: Susan H.

description:
A pretty shabu shabu place that would be good for a date or group outing. The way food is served is suited to westernized sensibilities in that each person gets their own individual portion of meat/veggies according to whatever they order as their set. Broth can also be individualized. 

My table ordered: 
- The pork belly and kimchi set
- Shabu shabu beef set with both the regular seaweed broth and spicy miso broth

The kimchi set didn't come with noodles, but we ordered ramen noodles on the side, which went well with the spicy broth. The shabu shabu set was paired with udon noodles. 

At the end, the soup is used to make rice porridge, reminiscent of the way Korean restaurants will often make porridge at the end of their hotpot meal (different kinds of jungol). Add in a little spring onion, seaweed, and egg (I think sesame oil as well), and you've got a good end to the meal. I found the porridge a little too watery and salty but my dining companions enjoyed it. 

There were people lingering around the entrance, waiting for tables, by the time we were done. 

The place had good food and nice decor. I'm not sure what suggestions I would give to improve the experience or the food at the moment; I found it to be a solid choice but not an impressive one.

Rating would probably be a little over a 3.
author: Jay K.

description:
3.5 stars!

I believe I have been to Nabe 5+ times. It's one of my boyfriend's favorite restaurants. 

The last time we came there was a huge misunderstanding and we ended up waiting 1 hour outside in the mist and fog for a seat.. it was really disappointing actually! We were told no more than 20 minutes wait.

The restaurant itself is very cramped and small. There is also terrible ventilation, so be prepared to smell like daikon for the rest of the night! Free steam facials for everyone! 

I honestly don't believe that for the price of shabu, it's worth the cost. The beef is great, but is comparable to other hot pot places in the city, like mum's or shabu house.

The broth is very salty, if you ask they do offer spices like chili flakes, garlic, and siracha. I have had the miso and regular tsukiyaki broth. 
The veggie plate that comes with the shabu set is mainly cabbage, with a few mushrooms and noodles. Nothing very special.

The gyoza appetizer is great and so is the iced matcha green tea! The green tea cheesecake is great but the slice is super tiny.

What is weird is that whenever I eat at Nabe I wake up feeling so terrible and have a horrible headache, not sure if they use MSG, or if I consumed so much salt from the rice porridge and broth that I become dehydrated. 
Drink lots of water!
author: Alexandra C.

description: My favorite is sukiyaki. This is way better than One pot(best of south bay), trust me. I came here several times since i study at Sfsu. This place is the only place i know that serves pot-ridge. Also, the wagyu beef is sooo good.
author: Suzy V.

description: the food and service is truly lovely.  they expanded their menu and it is divine.  i tried the new octopus salad and it was incredible. the octopus was fresh, cooked to perfection and tender, not rubbery at all.  as always the servers were sweet despite the place being completely packed. highly recommend.
author: Samantha B.

description: I grew up eating hotpot pretty much all-you-can-eat at home, so hotpot restaurants with pre-set meals always seem a little lackluster. Nabe proved me wrong with better quality meats and heartier additions to the meal. The hotpot is split down the middle, allowing my boyfriend and I each to choose our own broth. I had the sukiyaki with kurobota pork belly, and he had the miso broth with beef. The meat is extremely thinly sliced, and relative to other restaurants, a lot less fatty. As expected, the sukiyaki was on the sweeter side, but the meat was still delicious to dip in the provided ponzu-like sauce. Each set comes with veggies and a small handful of noodles, but you can also order rice on the side. My favorite part of the meal was the porridge they make at the end with the dredges of the broth. They cook down the rice with egg, then garnish with scallions and nori. The end result is an amazing porridge that's been cooking with the natural meat and vegetable flavors. I'd go back just for this porridge, and they should definitely offer it as a standalone item on the menu!
author: Ashley T.

description:
I'm a huge fan of hotpot / shabu and this place has been on my list of places to eat around San Fran for a while now and the day I finally went was amazing. 
I went with my friend and we split the pot half and half. Sukiyaki and Traditional. 
The Sukiyaki was delicious. It gave the meat such a nice flavor to it along with everything else that was stuffed into half the pot , haha.
What amazes me the most , that other shabu places I've gone to has never done , was make Zosui porridge out of the broth with their rice ! And it was delicious ! I would come back so much if it weren't so hard to find parking during dinner time. Ahaha.
Anyway , I love this place. It's small and intimate , but it's something worth the try. The waitresses are very nice and informative as well.
The price and the wait is all worth it as well.
author: Alyssa B.

description:
Best Shabu in SF finally arrived! 5 Stars for good service, great food and great concept!
Will be back for sure!

Love the Sake Selection.

Free Veggies.

Delicious Beef! 

Parking is a little though so get there early.
author: Braden B.

description:
My husband and I split the shabu hot pot with the beef and regular miso broth. It was delicious!  I loved the rice finisher. It was a perfect ending. 

This was our first hotpot experience and I loved the communal feel of cooking the meal together. 

We went on a Tuesday night and had a reservation for 6:30pm but would have been just fine without one.
author: Ramsey M.

description:
Now let me start by saying I absolutely love Nabe and I think it's a great addition to the sunset neighborhood! One of the nice things they do is they allow neighbors (or I suppose anyone) call ahead and put their name down on the waiting list. Normally when my family and I do this, we only have to wait a few minutes for our table but this recent experience was not like that. I called and spoke to the hostess who told me that it would be no problem for a group of 4, at most we would wait 20 minutes. My grandma and I headed over to the restaurant only to find out that the restaurant had two reservations for 4 booked and therefore would be seated ahead of us. This would have been great to know before leaving the house... We would have happily come later if we had know about these reservations... So instead, my 85 year old grandmother and I waited outside in 50 degree weather for over an hour... The hostess kept telling me it would only be a bit longer... Just a bit longer... If I knew it was going to be an hour, I would have gone elsewhere!! 

When we finally got seated, the hostess dumped our menus on the table and rushed away... After waiting so long, I was just ready to order! When she finally came back we ordered 4 shabu shabu dinners. She asked if we wanted rice, and I asked if we could have udon instead. (Shabu House lets us do this all the time.) She shortly answered no and left us. When I mentioned that we had been waiting over an hour for our table, she wasn't apologetic at all. 

The only thing that turned this night around was the waitress who took over our table. Nancy is the best!! She has been my server before and is always so nice! If it weren't for her, this review would have been more like 2 stars for the horrendous service by the hostess. Nancy was so great! She promptly brought our food and was very attentive. Most Shabu places will dump your food and won't check in with you until the end of your meal. I want to personally thank Nancy for going above and beyond! You really turned our night around! Thank you! And we will be back soon!
author: Taylor W.

description: The worst customer service ever !! Had a reservation, they made us wait for 2 hours and let in the walk in customers. Seriously? The walk way is super tiny and the waitresses are rude. First time here and do not plan to come back!
author: Truc N.

description:
I'm half a year late on this review, so let me reach into the deepest depths of my ass and pull out what I can remember. First time trying shabu and it was amazing!

Found this spot on Yelp some time ago while building my list of hotspots to check out in the city and dragged a friend to eat here with me so I'm not one of those sad people that consciously eat alone. We came in right when they opened for dinner time, so there wasn't anybody else other than just the two of us.

We ordered the Shabu Shabu and split it between the both of us because we were still digesting our lunch and didn't think we had the room in our stomachs to order our own sets. Being a first-timer, I didn't have anything to compare it to, so I'd say that I was satisfied and enjoyed the meal! I wasn't particularly pleased with the portions of the noodle add-ons, but you get a lot of other things to compensate for it.

Whatever soup is left they use to make the rice porridge, which I wasn't a big fan of because I didn't feel too comfortable eating the soup that we just dipped a bunch of crap in and who knows what's stewing in alla that. It's like putting rice into the leftover soup from a packet of ramen, it just didn't click with me. The server said it was her favorite part of the meal, but if baby food was her forte, then I guess.
author: Peter L.

description:
I came here two times as the first time was for lunch and little did I know that they do not offer the post-shabu porridge(Zosui Finisher) during lunch and only for dinner.

Both times, we ordered the same, half kimchi broth w/kurobuta pork and Shabu Shabu with Wagyu Beef, both of which were excellent. The kimchi broth already comes with all the veggies within the broth whereas the Shabu Shabu provided you a platter of veggies for you to cook at your own pace. We also ordered a side of clams in case the food was not enough.

The portions were just right for 2 people and I enjoyed being able to try two different broths and two different styles of cooking but ultimately, we enjoyed the kimchi broth the most so when it came time for the Zosui Finisher, we chose the kimchi broth.

I wish all shabu places in the city provided a Zosui Finisher as it is the ultimate way to have a flavorful porridge in case you were still hungry. I will definitely be back here for more especially with their cool decor of empty customer sake bottles hung all over the walls.

Food Highlight: Zosui Finisher with the KimChi Broth

P.S. - The bathroom is hidden behind curtains in the middle of the room along the wall so make sure to ask before walking towards/into the kitchen lol
author: Rich L.

description: I am now addicted to Japanese shabu thanks to Nabe. The sukiyaki broth and raw egg dip is what I always order and is a must-try. The raw egg dip kinda caramelizes the meat and complements the broth flavor and beef very well. The side noodles and veggies give nice variety to the meal (they give you a fair amount of mushrooms too so thank you, Nabe!). My taste buds are in heaven!
author: Hedy W.

description:
I adore this place. I'm normally more of a hot pot (Chinese style) fan than shabu shabu (Japanese) as the options for broth and everything that goes into it is far more varied in hot pot, but Nabe is something special.

It is a little on the pricey side but the quality of meat, noodles, and vegetables are all high quality. I've tried most of the broth and my favorite would have to be the spicy miso. Konbu is a little bland while the kimchi one is a little sour for my tastes. I always get the medium spicy miso broth for size and order extra meat and noodles if there are more people. The udon noodles are fresh and delicious while the pork has just the right amount of marbling.

If it hasn't been raved about already, the best part of the meal is the zosui rice, aka THE FINISHER. I can never go back to other shabu places as most places do not do the zosui. After you've finished your meal and the broth is wonderfully flavored with the meat and vegetable, they take a little bit of rice and egg and let it simmer to a wonderful jook, congee, rice soup, whatever you would like to call it. Top it off with scallions and nori and it is a PERFECT cup of the most flavorful rice soup/stew you could possibly taste. I love it so much that I wish they would just sell this part. 

If you have room for dessert at this point they have a delicious housemade mochi cake with green tea that I highly recommend.

The wait during weekdays is minimal to none but on the weekends I would recommend calling ahead to be seated. The service is great, they're attentive and make the rice soup on the spot for you.
author: Kate M.

description:
PROS:
-meat and veggie plates are so fresh
-they aren't stingy with the sauces nor do they charge extra for them like some places do
-a variety of broths to choose from
-half and half option (pot has a divider so you can choose two different broths)
-very clean and modern, simple decor
-great service
-walking distance from the Academy of Sciences

CONS:
-if you don't get a table you may have to sit at the communal table, which may be a bit crowded depending on who is sitting next to you (we didn't experience this since we sat at a table...the restaurant was actually pretty empty)
-parking may be difficult but if you are willing to park further and walk then it should be fine

TIP:
If you are a tourist (or a local) going to the Academy of Sciences, I recommend that you go early to the museum, leave at lunchtime and walk over to either Kiki's (a casual Japanese restaurant) or Nabe for lunch, then go back to the Academy. You will enjoy Kiki's or Nabe's a lot more than the food at the Academy (the food at the Academy isn't bad but it's expensive).
author: Connie W.

description:
Nabe was pretty good, I had to knock off a star off because of the service.

Their set hot pot is the way too go. The sukiyaki, and the kimchi pork is probably the best. The seafood are good, but they came with everything in the pot already, so that takes away the cooking part.

At the end of the meal, they brought over some ice cream and sweets, we though they came with the set dinner, after looking at them for about 2 min, and right as we were going to dig our spoon in, they came back, and took it all way because they made a mistake. It was meant for another table. 

Well, I see two problems here, if it was your mistake, you should of just let them here.  It is 3 scoops of ice cream! Especially when our spoons were only inches away. Second, they took the ice cream that sat on our table, and served them to the other table! Ewwww, if I were at the other table, I would of ask them to give us the fresh ice cream. It is very un-sanitary. 

I am on the fence of being a return customer.
author: Alice C.

description:
Let me tell you first of all about this place. Originally, I was about to give this restaurant a 4 stars but after further review with my girlfriend this place deserves 5 stars and beyond. 

All the waiter and waitress were the BOMB. I felt like I was in Gary danko but for $$ signs. I mean their service was absolutely off the hook. My water and tea was never empty and that's how a restaurant service should be. They should be attentive with their customers at all time. They were engaging and I felt like I was eating at home. 

To be honest the food was alright, but the porridge in the end was simply amazing. Overall, you guys deserve a Michelin review because of the wonderful service you provide. NUFF SAID!!! Til next time.
author: Ronald G.

description:
First I'll say that I'm very glad Nabe graciously let us into the restaurant with Ocean Beach sand still wedged between our toes and sand dollars spilling out of my hoodie pocket. We probably looked like huge weirdos going into this but you know. Why not end a chilly day at the beach with hot pot!

The food was great! I don't get many chances to eat vegetarian hot but but the fact there are more than one option for me is always a draw to return. The shiitake broth with our hot pot was very flavorful and tasted great as leftovers in rice porridge form. There's also a great selection of Japanese booze, although I'm biased toward any menu with a Hitachino Nest brew on it. 

Also, the servers were insanely nice and put up with our minor confusion as to how hot pot worked (well, more my boyfriend's case but shhh don't let him hear that.) I'd like to try their dessert next time, since there will definitely be a next time!
author: Raven P.

description:
-Update

The Zosui rice is only provided after dinner, not during lunch!

-End of Update-

It was a dark and stormy night. 

The Husband and I were in the Inner Sunset looking for something warm and comforting to eat. What better than hot pot?

We made a reservation for 7:00 but needn't have bothered because there wasn't anyone in the restaurant. We were greeted by a friendly woman who walked us through the menu.

Nabe is great because they offer you the choice of one or two broths. They have a special pot divided in half so that you can have the traditional seaweed-only based broth as well as one of several other options. 

The place is clean, neat and the BEST part is how they bring out rice at the end to make a rice porridge (like jook for you other Korean/Chinese folks out there). The waitress explained that most hot pot places won't do this because it's more of a "home" thing to do but I'm so glad they do. You think you're full but you make room for this dish. 

Try Nabe!
author: Christine P.

description: We went there at a late cold night. Two people shared a sukiyaki pot and it was totally enough! The environment is pretty good, even the restroom.
author: Jane W.

description:
Nabe has a very tastefully decorated interior.  I like the sake bottles on the wall, and even the fogged up wall/door as diners steam up the place with their hot pots.  It looks chic and yet cozy. 

We shared the seafood broth and shabu shabu broth with konbu.  The ingredients didn't seem to come in large portions, but you can tell they are high quality stuff. And by the time we were ready for the porridge, we were actually really full.  

Like many reviews have mentioned, the porridge is almost the best part.  It's full of umami from the broth.  A great way to end a great meal.
author: Candice B.

description:
This place is just ok. It is very different than any other shabu places I have been to in SF.
First off the waiter, explained the different types of soup bases. Which was nice because there are about 6 different choices to choose from. Once we ordered we waited for our food to arrive. The pots took awhile to come out. When the pots finally came, all the veggies were already inside the pot which was different than any other shabu places. I didn't really like the fact that they put the veggies in the pot for you because you can't control what you want to eat first. It also sucks when you order the seafood option because the seafood is already in the pot when it arrives. The seafood is all done at the same time and you feel like you have to rush to eat the seafood.
The best soup base was the shabu shabu spicy miso. The sukiyaki base was a bit too sweet.
At the very end they take your left over soup base and make a porridge with it. This does take time so if you are in a rush to leave you should probably skip this. It takes time to cook the rice and soup together. We got spicy miso and sukiyaki base and the spicy miso base was the best! The sukiyaki was even more sweet than before. We were lucky the waiter allowed us to get both because he said normally they only do one soup base. 
Overall this place is just ok. Slightly different than any other shabu place I have been too.
Oh I forgot to mention, that the meat comes on the side. Once the meat is cooked, it shrinks up and looks like a brain! Please refer to the picture I posted! The meat looks really gross and creeps me out!
author: Shauna f.

description:
To my pleasant surprise, I was super excited to find that there was a restaurant that serves nabe in San Francisco, and Nabe did not disappoint. The waiter was very nice in explaining to my friends and I how the process of ordering works including the different types of broth and any extras we want to include into the hotpot. 

Each broth was excellent, but the kimchi and the miso broths being the favourites of our group.

Great place to bring friends and experience a type of eating most Americans haven't tried before.
author: Chris P.

description:
Honestly this is the closest I've come to authentic Japanese style Shabu in San Francisco. I've been raised on the traditional Konbu set and the choice of meat and veggies is great. The porridge at the end is also good with the sukiyaki broth, but be sure to dilute the broth or else it'll be extremely salty. Doesn't hurt that I live right nearby either.

But come during the day for lunch. It's cheaper and your wallet will thank you. Also, the place gets extremely hot and humid inside the store so be prepared to sweat bullets. Honestly, this place needs air-conditioning and a better fan system.
author: Cody M.

description:
You get what you pay for when it comes to quality. Everyone who is complaining about the quantity should remember this isn't Shabu way / shabu club. This is nabe, a whole different type of hot pot. 

Ingredients come already laid out in the pot waiting to be cooked. Sukiyaki and Kimchi's presentation are on point! I've tried the Shabu Shabu set in the past but the veggies and noodles come on the side. Meat is always tender and marbled. At the end of your meal, you choose one broth to turn into a rice soup. Super yummy as it holds all the flavor of your cooked ingredients. NOT for the germaphobes!! 

The price is worth it for the quality of the ingredients and the atmosphere. Will definitely be back.
author: Cray C.

description:
I've been here for lunch, and dinner. I'm surprised their lunch crowd was just as well as dinner time crowd. Good for them!

LUNCH consisted of a cheaper hotpot option compared to dinner. The quality of the food was still excellent though! Lunch does not come with the Zosui rice finisher, so don't expect it. Lunch time is suppose to be quick so I understand why they don't offer it. Their lunch menu had something new! They have this thing called HAMBAGU! No, not hamburger... HAMBAGU! Like a hamburger steak kinda thing. Two different sauces to choose from and both were DELICIOUS! Maybe they could add that to their diner menu, cause I would order it. 

DINNER is just as excellent as everyone says it is. Plus the Zosui rice finisher of course. This was when the servers really made the experience top notch! As they are standing there making the Zosui for my table, they talked to us and taught us quite a few things. The difference between Japanese hotpot and Chinese hotpot...(Japanese hotpot is way better!) The boxes on the walls (Great way to include the customers into their decorations, I will definitely purchase a bottle of sake just so I can be on the wall.) And of course, they explained what the Zosui actually was (It's not something that they just came up with themselves...though its delicious!) 

SERVICE is beyond excellent! Even though they get swamped, you can tell that they really care about your dining experience with them. I overheard the tables around me that it was their first time doing hotpot and the servers took their time to explain everything to them. If I were a first time hotpotter, I would greatly appreciate their help because they really did explain EVERYTHING. (The tables next to us, I guess never cooks? They asked ridiculous questions like "When is this cooked?" "How long do I leave it in the pot for?") Goodness!! But the servers were very kind and patient with them. I hope the customers tipped them well cause I do every time. 

I'm craving Nabe just thinking about it and typing this review. Ha!
author: Vee 2.

description:
I made reservations for Wednesday night and arrived 30 mins early. Luckily it was a weekday so it wasn't too busy. We were seated right away. 

The restaurant is extremely small and narrow.  I didn't even realize I was sitting in front of the restroom. The restroom was covered with a drape so it wasn't uncomfortable.  The restroom has a sliding door which makes sense because the restaurant is so small. 

My friend and I tried the sukiyaki and the shabu shabu with spicy miso.  We weren't too crazy for the broth that came with the sukiyaki. It was really sweet with a hint of tartness.  The spicy miso was great. All of the sets come with assorted veggies. The beef and pork was very flavorful and tender.  And at the end of the dinner they make porridge out of the leftover broth.  I thought it was pretty interesting but i wasn't too crazy for it either. 

The service was attentive. The only problem was that the servers came to us at least three times and ask us the same thing twice. I think that they should find a way to communicate with each other so that they don't ask the customers the same thing twice. 

Overall, it was a good experience.  I will definitely come back to try the kimchi base instead of the sukiyaki.
author: Tina D.

description: Love the shabu here. Small place with tight seating, but so good. The meat was great and the "porridge" they make at the end is totally worth it. I wouldn't recommend ordering rice beforehand as it's not needed. They also have a pretty decent sake menu to choose from.
author: Jessica R.

description:
You are always typically going to pay more for Shabu Shabu in the city, so why not go some place awesome. This is definitely one of those spots. I had a friend from LA come in last week, so my and my buddy though hey lets bring him here.

We called in for a wait time, but even then we still had to wait another 30. A testament to how popular this place can get. It not so bad though as a bar is right next door.

We had really nice and cute server (Nicole i think) and she was really friendly. We had the kimchi broth with pork and the miso broth with beef. Both excellent recommendations. At the end the congee stew to finish off pretty much put us over the top.

I would definitely come back here again.
author: Emmanuel B.

description: Okay okay, so I'm a shabu shabu snob. I don't think it's the best shabushabu, as the beef was sliced excessively-thin and wasn't greatly marbled. I think Shabuway still wins for the meat quality. Also, this is another one of those places that seems to use watered-down gomadare (sesame sauce) for some reason. Other than that, though, the meal was great. Service was surprisingly VERY good, and I like how they will make you porridge at the end of the meal -- something that I haven't found at any other Bay Area shabu places. I'll definitely be coming back.. but I hope they step up their meat quality game!
author: Kazu O.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for while.  The truth is that there is really only one reason I've been dying to try this place and it's because they turn their shabu broth into porridge at the end.  The broth is typically my favorite part since all the flavor goes into the broth.  The service is excellent.  Our order was a bit messed up (we got the wrong flavor broth) but they quickly replaced it and gave up new vegetables to replace the ones we tossed in.  The meat is good but sliced very, very thin.  Parking is awful, which is typical for restaurants in this area.  The porridge was good, but I don't think it's worth making a trip out here just for it.  Cool place to try if you're near by and you have time.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
One of the most over-rated new restaurants I've been to. 

1. It doesn't look like the photos. The place is very small. Too small. 

2. Bathroom is not really separate from eating area and separated by a curtain! Not fun to sit and smell the bathroom when eating. 

3. It's not nabe, and it's not Japanese. In fact, it's asian fusion nonsense. They basically created a bunch of asian inspired soups, and did it badly. A true Japanese would not recognize this as Nabe. 

4. They have a wall full of sake dispensers but only 1 of them had sake in it, the rest were empty - tacky and unpleasant to look at. 

5. Service was awful. In normal shabu style, you get hot broth then you cook veggies and meat in it. They provide broth with some veggies and some meat them some meat and some noodles on the side. Impossible to know what to do with it all. Waitress tells us to put them in, so we put them in. Then, other waitress comes by and says we should have dipped noodles and meat, not put them in, b/c they get soggy and meat gets over cooked. Since the food has no authenticity, neither of the staff actually knew what to do with it, and neither did we. 

6. After returning home, I had upset stomach with other symptoms that I don't want to mention here. Something bad was in the meat, I think. A day later, stomach still upset.

7. For all this, I paid $84. I don't mind paying for quality, but paying this much money for such a crappy experience makes it twice as bad.
author: Eater S.

description:
Some friends and I have made it a habit to come to Nabe once a month or so. Usually the windows are fogged up and it's really crowded, but yesterday (A Saturday night around 8:30pm) there were a few tables available and they had the door open for some air. We got the Kimchi broth with beef and pork. Everything was amazing. The broth was flavorful and the meat was very fresh. The sake was also a nice touch and wasn't too expensive. The service can be a little slow at times, but it's about 3-4 girls serving everyone, so be patient.

Very good for small groups and great food. Will definitely keep coming back here for sure.
author: Bella S.

description:
YES YES YES. 
Extraordinary quality food and very tasty too!! Service was exceptional, very friendly and eager to answer any questions. 

Since having shabu shabu in Japan, I have been craving it! This place filled that void in a big way. 

Come here. Frequently.
author: Seymour G.

description:
Prices are acceptable for the quality of meat, portions are small. I would go for a large order if you are hungry. I highly recommend the kimchi broth which is a slightly spicy, very enjoyable as soup as well. They wagyu is amazingly fresh when cooked medium rare in the broth. But the broth has an overpowering soy sauce flavor. It's worth a try, but don't except to be completely full after a regular or large size.                           
Service is exceptional and welcoming. Definitely don't mind coming again!
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
I've been to this place twice & can say that it's very good. The portions are good sizes, the prices are reasonable, & the service is very good. All the servers I've interacted with there knows everything about every dish which is excellent. Every one is very friendly & polite which everyone looks for in servers at a restaurant.
The food comes out promptly so there is never a long wait for anything. I've had the kimchee nabe, sukiyaki, & I've tried the duck. All three of those are very flavorful & tasty. I've also ordered the garlic soy edamame, which I would definitely recommend trying. 
For those green tea lovers, the green tea cheesecake is amazing here. Its not super thick cheesecake so it's easy to eat & you can taste the green tea flavor, mmm. The other choice of dessert is butter mochi which is also very good. 
 If I ever have a shabu shabu craving, I would come here.
author: Janey H.

description:
Why so salty? Also, I hate getting charged for rice!  

Nevertheless, this place is good.  If you navigate the menu right (e.g. share an entree and choose add-ons) you can save money- which is something you can't do at competing shabu restaurants.  The complimentary  Zosui (rice porridge) is great (save room for that!), and the hot steam that fogs the windows adds to the space- even if it's just unintentional design.  Altogether, Nabe makes the best use of a tiny space, and my service was great. 

Another tip:  don't forget the clams, shrimp, and scallops, in your Seafood Yosenable; they sink to the bottom and easily overcook!
author: Diane N.

description:
The family decided to give this place a try after reading the online reviews.  
Food quality and quantity for the price = 3.5 stars 
Service = 5 stars
Environment = 4 stars 
Porridge experience at the end of the meal = 4 stars
It was good to give this place a try but it wasn't very impressive.
author: S L.

description:
Steamy!

This place gets literally steamy inside, which was a nice welcome after running laps in the cold at Kezar. The "hot pot" is decidedly more Japanese than ones on Geary, with unique selections of broth, and Japanese cuts of beef and pork. 

The veggie selections are standard: spinach, cabbage, mushroom, carrot, tofu, and squash was the lone item I hadn't seen elsewhere. Also, udon (or other noodle depending on your broth) to finish off the meal. 

But just when you think you're done, they throw in some cooked rice, egg, scallions, and strips of seaweed to make a Japanese porridge, similar to chazuke if you have more broth than usual. 

Cool interior and a nice change of pace from the other places in town.
author: Derrick V.

description: Looking forward to going back!  One thing I would suggest to them, don't allow little children.  I was so concerned the table next to us was going to have a disaster!  Who would want to bring a baby to a restaurant with hot plates and bowls of soup everywhere?  Pizza is much safer.
author: nancy h.

description:
Date/Time:  Monday - 7pm
Occasion:   Dinner with friends
Party of:  Four
Ordered:  Shabu set + Pork Kurobata set

And the shabu monster is back!  Of course I was excited to try the latest and greatest shabu restaurant in SF.  Did it live up to it's hype?  Heck yes!  The food was delicious.  We tried the appetizers - sausage, edamame, and gyoza.  The sausages were a hit.  Paired with nice mustard aioli dipping sauce.  

I was eagered to try the shabu.  The broth was different with a nice sweet and spicy kick.  The beef was deliciously buttery and cut into perfect sized pieces so that it was easy to consume.  A nice generous portion of veggies were part of the dinner, including two types of mushrooms.  Score!  One of the best parts, the end of the meal congee the servers prepare for you.  Delicious and hearty way to end a delicious dinner.  The venue is smaller so it may get packed, especially on cold nights.  Make a reservation in advance, if you can.

Will I be returning?  Absolutely.  And I highly recommend you check it out as well.
author: Jess C.

description:
3.5 stars because of their food but an extra 1.5 for their excellent service and people skills!

Walked in on a Thursday night. Wasn't too sure what to expect since this place just opened and walking by, the whole window was steamy on the inside. The decor is really nice. A bit small and cramped-looking, but welcoming. I really like the different sake bottles aligned along the wall.

We were greeted and seated very quickly after arriving around 8pm. The waitress asked if it was our first time and it was, so she explained the menu to us. A bit confusing at first, but definitely different from other shabu/hot pot places which made me even more excited!

I wasn't that hungry but my friend was so we agreed to share. We ordered the large kimchi&pork belly option was was $22 for large. $18 for regular size. We also ordered the gyoza which comes with 6 pieces for $7. Our gyoza came out fairly quickly. We took a bite into it and noticed that it was still pink inside, so we told the waitress. She quickly took it to the back and sincerely apologized and asked if there was any other appetizer we would like on the house since they undercooked it. She then gave us a recommendation that she liked the sausages, so we agreed to get that. Our broth with all of the vegetables, kimchi, mushrooms, etc. came out shortly after and we waited for it to boil. The broth wasn't as tasteful as I hoped, but it was good.

The sausages came out shortly after that and I really enjoyed it! I also liked the sauce because it complimented it well.

Also, it was our mistake for not realizing the order we chose came with pork belly and not beef, so when we asked our waitress, she kindly took our plate back and served us beef instead of pork belly. Another plus! The beef was a soft and not too chewy texture, just the way I like it.

At the end when we're done, there is also a finishing rice dish that we thought was pretty cool. It was definitely original because I have never seen it before anywhere else. You have to see and taste it in order to know what I'm talking about! I don't normally like rice that much, but I really really enjoyed the end to this meal. It was like a sort of porridge texture, but with so much flavor! It amazed me how much I enjoyed it because I didn't enjoy the kimchi broth itself in the beginning.

Also, thinking that they would only give us complimentary sausages for the gyoza incident.. NOPE! They gave us the gyoza as well which surprised me. When we received our bill, we thought that they would've only given us the sausages for free but they also voided our gyoza! A simple apology and remaking the item would've satisfied me but their customer service skills really amazed me. I wish more experiences like this would happen more often!

I will definitely be back to try the other items on the menu!
author: Valerie T.

description:
This place makes me want to go out and make a hipster "I HEART Shabu!" T-Shirt. I'll keep it short. Go here with an empty stomach, the service will make you think "Awwwwww!" the whole darn time, the flavors are so rich (sukiyaki only like I've had in Asia), meat that tastes like meat, and the porridge finale? Brilliant. Too bad I'm not in SF often enough to stalk this place weekly. 

Oh yes, if you want to eat until you drop for $30, another place would be better. But you will be full, I promise.
author: Alameda L.

description:
Nabe is the newest restaurant to open up in the Inner Sunset, so of course my friends and I wanted to try it out.  We came in for an earlier dinner, around 5:45 p.m. and the place was empty, so we were seated immediately.  The waitress gave us the menus and our group of five decided to share a few items.  At first it was a bit confusing trying to figure out how much food to order, but it all worked out in the end.  Anyway, about the food.  The regular orders are $19 and large orders are $24.  Special items, like the duck, are $24 for a regular size and $29 for the large.

-Shabu (spicy miso): this was probably my favorite of the broths.  It was a nice amount of spice for me, but some others found it to be a little spicy.  
-Shabu (traditional): pretty average/good.
-Kimchi and pork belly: I have never actually had kimchi in broth, so this was a new experience for me.  It tasted pretty good.  Just make sure you like kimchi.
-Duck breast and dashi broth: this broth tasted pretty similar to the traditional shabu broth.  I enjoyed the duck breast and there were probably about 8-10 pieces.  This one also came with mochi, which I have never had in broth, so that was pretty good.

We didn't realize before, but after the meal, they make a rice porridge with the leftover broth.  You get to pick which broth you want and it's a nice way to fill up, if you haven't already.  They mix in rice, egg and green onions.  The whole thing is pretty good, though we were stuffed already.  Make sure that you try the broth out before they cook it down further- because it can get really salty.  We didn't and the whole thing was kind of a salty mess.

The whole dining experience lasted for about 1.5 hours.  The staff was pretty helpful overall, though at times they were hard to track down for utensils, water or tea refills.  Also, the staff did seem pretty new/inexperienced, so I'll cut them a break.  I have a feeling that this could go up to 4 stars if they work on training the staff a little better.    

Note: this is a place that will have you smelling like the food when you leave.
author: Samantha L.

description: So disappointed, meat quality has gone down and the broth isn't as flavorful as before :(
author: Christina L.

description: First time having Japanese hot pot. It was pricey and the food was ok. I like the porridge at the end and because you can bring it home it feels like the meal was a little more worth it. For a hotpot place, I'm not a fan of the enclosed dining area with glass windows/door. The whole glass fogged up.
author: Cindy H.

description:
Great place! Came here with a party of 14 to celebrate a party and took up half the restaurant.  There were two servers for all of us, who were very attentive.
They took time to answer all of our questions and helped us explain the menu. For 4 hungry people, I would recommend getting 3 larges and then ordering the add ons after.  The food and broth were great.  Although my favorite Shabu spot is still Shabu House, I would totally recommend this.
author: Brian C.

description: Went for lunch with the bf and loved it. He got the large beef with miso and I got the regular pork with miso. First of all, food aside, the interior and decoration of this place gives off a very good vibe. I'm very into the dining experience brought together by good design, so if you're looking for a comfy date night, I totally recommend this place. Now onto the food. The broth was really good and they give you a good portion of meat and veggies. I can't eat spicy so I didn't try the spicy miso but I overheard the table next to us saying it was good. The price was very reasonable for shabu, around $30 for the two of us. Next time I come here, I will try the sukiyaki.
author: Joey Y.

description: Good service, good food, I especially enjoyed the porridge at the end. I got the kimchi & pork belly hot pot and the serving was quite generous. My friend and I also got the introduction sake, which came with three different kinds of sake. Overall, it was a decently charming experience!
author: Becky M.

description: I'm excited! Nabe is now open for lunch!! That means Kimchi soup for me all day long!..But I saw a new item Hambagu yes not Hamburger but Hambagu! Wagyu beef and Kurobuta pork sounded so extravagant I had to try it. My favorite was Oroshi, the meat was really rich the daikon on top gave it great balance of flavors and texture.
author: Karen T.

description: Typical shabu place, but I like that they have a unique wall decoration of alcohol bottles. The place is a bit small, but my favorite part is the rice and soup mixture at the end! I think it's safest to share a large plate of your chosen meat, and saving your stomach for the rice porridge-like dish at the end. I ordered a large shabu-shabu and split it with a friend, and was super full when the waitress used the remaining soup base to create the rice dish with. It also comes with an egg and seaweed on the dish. Definitely the most unique shabu experience I have had, which gives it a 4/5 stars. The customer service is also amazing! The waitress was very attentive and refilled my water whenever she saw it lowered. Even got ice cream in the end :) Was a good first experience and will be back again!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Came here one weekday night with a few friends to try this somewhat new shabu spot in the sunset district. For a weekday night, we were glad we made reservations, because it got packed quick. 

We got seated right away, thanks to our reservations, and looked at the menu. It wasn't the easiest menu to understand, but the waitress explained it well enough for us to half spicy miso and half sukiyaki soup base. The dinner comes with a plate of veggies and your choice of beef, pork or lamb. I liked that the sukiyaki soup base came with loads of veggies already in the broth, but, it was little on the sweeter side. The spicy miso broth wasn't too spicy and tasted delicious. The beef plate was fresh and not too fatty. The pork was a little dry for my taste, but some of my friends liked it a lot. 

The atmosphere was very modern and had unique sake dispenser decor along the walls. It wasn't too noisy in there and I didn't feel too suffocated like I usually do in other shabu, hot pot places. Everything was very clean and organized.

Overall, I enjoyed the food and dining experience here and would definitely come back again to try different soup bases. If you don't want to ruin your favorite sweater or shirt, leave that at home. Like with all shabu/hot pot experiences, you and your outfit will smell like it until your next laundry day.
author: Christina T.

description: The best shabu-shabu place in town! The service was excelente. The food was delicioso. The quality of the meat was extraordinary! Try the sukiyaki broth, it was definitely my favorite.
author: Jimmy B.

description: Really enjoyable place and relatively affordable. Suits those familiar with Shabu and those who are not-- servers will explain how it works. Don't miss the rice porridge dish cooked in the reserved broth at the end. Delicious!
author: Matt K.

description:
SO yummy!! 

its a VERY small place but try to call in and reserve a table! I didn't think this tiny place accepted reservations but they do! (I saw there was a table reserved) 

My friend and I just tried the Sukiyaki broth. It's traditionally a cold soup so it'll take awhile to heat up.
It was VERY tasty, a deep flavor..it smells like typical udon soup but it taste very sweet (not in the candy way) and very savory at the same time. SO YUMMY!! It comes with an egg and thats it. But I've seen other people around me where they had ramen come with their order! The beef, no doubt, was very tasty. 

And like everyone else has said, the service is impeccable. The three waitresses rotationally came by every 3 mins or so .. I guess some people might not like it because they really came too often (probably because the restaurant is so small) but nevertheless, they were very attentive and patient in explaining their menu!

My favorite part was the RICE/porridge at the end! If you're not that hungry and you just want to try this place between you and your date, getting a large will fill you guys up. The rice at the end, where they put in another egg, seaweed bits and green onions is so good and filling. I think this broth was a PERFECT pairing with the rice at the end. ..and if you run out of broth, they'll gladly add more water for you and it won't dilute the flavor! 

Shabu shabu at its best, good pricing and delicious food. ($18 med broth and $22 for large broth) This is the hottest spot in town everyone, don't miss out!
author: Sandra L.

description:
I think I've grown accustomed to my typical "Shabu House" shabu so this place was a little different. 
My friend and I weren't super hungry so I thought we could split a large and I mentioned it to the waitress but I guess since we wanted to try two types she charged us for two separate orders. 
I like eating my shabu with rice during the meal, not the end. We didn't do the porridge thing, since I asked for the rice early. 
The sukiyaki broth was good and sweet. Kimchi was alright, nice spicy complement to the sweetness of sukiyaki. 
Cool interior, nice staff who explain everything, but I prob wouldn't return. We also came closer to closing time so with the low numbers customers, the waitresses were hanging around our table to explain how to do EVERYTHING. I felt like I was being watched and gonna get yelled at for eating it wrong. XP
author: Christine Y.

description:
Nabe is beautiful inside and out. Authentic flavors and presentation. 

It's very difficult to find authentic Japanese food in San Francisco. Nabe makes the grade.
