We ate the kimchi and kurobuta pork nabemono. Best I've had in the city. I won't be driving to San Mateo anymore for shabu shabu. Sake selection was unique and diverse.

Masa was our server, he was exceptionally attentive and caring during our meal. He made sure our glasses were always full and plates were removed.

Excellent Food, Service and Atmosphere. I'll certainly be back!
author: Sterling P.

description:
3 1/2 stars. I really wanted to like this place, but it was ok. 

Tried the spicy miso broth and the Kimichi broth. They were both pretty spicy and good. The meet was fresh, but they give too little veges. Also I didn't want rice, so I asked for more Udon and they charged me extra. All the Shabu places would not charge me extra. 

I didn't know they had a special rice soup thing at the end. If I did then I woudn't have asked for extra udon. The special rice soup was really good. That was my favorite part of the meal.

I also don't like how you have to sit with random people. They can hear your whole convo and take up your space.
author: Karen H.

description:
I've been to lots of different shabu houses, but Nabe is definitely the one :)
They aren't bringing you a plate of uncooked ingredients, although there is a dish named Shabu where you can take care of yourself :) 
Sliced meat was awesome! Very delicious!
Prices are also reasonable (18$ for medium and 22$ for large hot-pot).
Amazing staff :)
author: Olga B.

description:
if you love sukiyaki or shabu shabu or yosenabe or any Japanese stew dish then you'd love nabe!

my only gripe is that I stink afterwards.  I think the ventilation in there needs some help.

the service is attentive and friendly

the place is cute and clean

the food!  we went straight for half sukiyaki and half duck nabe and both were delicious.  the meat and veggies were super fresh and nicely presented.  afterwards they make a zosui or rice soup with the remaining broth at the table.  it was a tad salty but I could imagine it being really comforting.  because they take the broth after all the boiling, its super concentrated and flavorful, but salty.  I think the zosui from the yosenabe would be yummy.  or they should do a crab hot pot!  yum
author: claudia y.

description: make sure to save room at the end for the finisher! it is deeeellliiiciooouuusss!!!! I've eaten here numerous times and I come back mainly for the food and the service. DUH.  i think i've tried everything on the menu, but the shabu with spicy miso and the duck are still my favs.  I also LOVE the decor on the walls.  When I first went, the sake boxes were empty, and every time i go back, i see matching bottles in them.. SIGNED! (probably by the people tho purchased the bottles). SOOOO COOL!!  this review is making me hungry. I shall go back soon!
author: Natalie L.

description:
We were actually on our way to Naan N Curry and found Nabe by accident. We stumbled upon a well lit, glass paned and modern looking Japanese Hot Pot restaurant.

Nabe's take on Shabu Shabu is refreshing and fun. With a very trendy decor, comfortable seating and an excellent ventilation system, Nabe provided us a perfect evening for a date night hot pot! 

The Wagyu Beef is super fresh, as is the vegetables that come with our hot pot. Good tasting broth as well. Very clean and great service. Huge selection of Sake for the drinkers out there! Best part of the meal comes at the very end when you are done with your hot pot. The server comes with a bowl of rice and simmers it in the remaining soup broth adding an egg, green onions and dried seaweed turning your leftover soup broth into a delicious porridge!
author: Philip K.

description:
Overall we had an enjoyable shabu shabu experience, one of the best of his kind in San Francisco. We will likely come back for more.

Pros:
- Very good slices of Waygu beef and Kurobuta pork belly
- Good green tea cheesecake and black bean ice cream
- Attentive and friendly service 
- Good sake selection
- Unique touch with the rice porridge cooked at the table at the end of the meal (dinner only)
- Strong ventilation system which we wish other shabu shabu and hot pot restaurants had in place

Cons:
- Despite the strong ventilation, our clothes ended up smelling after the meal
- A few details missing: no chopstick holder, no place to put my cracked egg, paper napkins (simple cloth would fit better with the decor)
- The broths are quite intense (perhaps too much so: the miso that came with the pork was very spicy, the sukiyaki that came with the waygu was very sweet)
- The butter mochi and the red been ice cream are bland and not reccomended
author: Claudio B.

description:
my hands down favorite shabu shabu in san francisco. 
it's more elegant than the other shabu spots in the city. 
i love this as a date or double date night. 
don't forget to ask for the rice dish they create with the extra sauce, meat and veggies at the end of the night. i love that as breakfast the next day.
author: Erika D.

description:
Hot pot tends to leave me hungry, gassy, and broke by the end of the meal. I don't know why I'm such a fan.

Nabe, at least, doesn't leave me hungry. This restaurant has been my first "shabu shabu" experience, and I still don't even know what that means. The defining difference between this and standard hot pot, to me, is that they make a "porridge" at the end, using rice to soak up your remaining broth and ingredients. It's something I could do at home with a $2 bag of rice and a chicken bouillon cube, but I don't mind paying $30 for this restaurant to do it for me.

That's because this place has a sleek, minimalist ambiance, made even better because it's infrequently busy. I can come in here on a weeknight and actually enjoy talking to someone I brought. The servers, bless them, always note my fresh-off-the-boat expression and give my table lots of attention and pointers.

The food has not exactly been my preference on both my trips. I think I ordered the "shabu shabu" dish both times, and I still felt a bit hungry and gassy until the porridge. Not the biggest fan of raw egg. But that's my own bias. It's obviously top drawer in quality and taste, if this is what you're into.
author: David S.

description: ~* Great Shabu and Great Service...great for a cold winter day~! The Sukiyaki is perfect...not too sweet. Save some room for the Zosui at the end (they cook rice for you w/an egg, green onion, and seaweed flakes) *~
author: Wendy K.

description:
Although admittedly not a nabemono coinesseur, and as someone who is used to associating the practice of gathering around a boiling cauldron of food with drunken excursions to cheap hot pot dives after long nights of partying, I was awakened to the realization that hot pot could be elevated to an art form, without the required intoxication. 

The first thing I noticed and appreciate about Nabe is the decor, which is at the same time chic and cozy. The small space and long communal tables lend to the cozy aesthetic while the black walls, wooden sake dispensers and contrasting white tabletops give you the sense that these guys take their craft seriously.

The food is uber fresh, all organic and nicely presented. The sake selection, while on the pricier side, was respectable as every offering was a quality brew. The service was exceptionally friendly and helpful. The staff are all smiles and did their best to make us happy. After countless visits to sunset district noodle joints, this was a welcome change of pace.
author: Randy C.

description: Best hot pot I have tried yet in the city! A little on the pricey side, but the shabu was totally worth it! Highly recommended for an upscale date night. fun, yet pretty "safe" adventures in food
author: Ryan S.

description: It was ok
author: Sarah S.

description: Just loved the concept. The freshness and quality of the food.
author: Bertrand C.

description:
I've always brought different people here for dinner and they always ask me "When's the next time we're going to Nabe? It's so good!" 

I guess the thing that sets it apart is the end course where they take your leftover broth, put rice, and then add other ingredients to make it into a delicious porridge. So if you plan to come here anytime soon and it's your first time, remember to not get super full from the shabu shabu itself!

Some of my favorite broths include
- Kimchi + Kurobuta Pork Belly - I love how the kimchi spice isn't overpowering all the other flavors in the pot. Plus, I also love the included mochis. Don't put them in the pot for too long, or else it becomes a blob that is so mushy you won't be able to pick it up with any of the provided utensils. 
- Shabu Shabu with Wagyu beef in spicy miso broth - my bf and I love anything spicy. So we had to do a spicy option with something beefy. This was the perfect combination of the two. This one is always our go-to broth.
- Seafood Yosenabe - Seafood lover's pick. Not my favorite since I'd probably choose the above two over seafood, but not a bad choice - especially if you love seafood! 

You can pick additional items to add onto your original broth, so don't feel too limited on a certain choice just because it includes something you like. My advice? Pick your favorite broth, then add the items you like!

This place can get a little pricy since it's more expensive than your traditional hotpot, but trust me.. you'll never leave Nabe still feeling hungry.
author: Gelene V.

description: Tasteful interior, comfortable dining environment. Fresh ingredients, especially their beef I would say it's better than a lot of hot pot place in SF! Plus their broth is also rich (unlike some shabu place the broth is only salty) I would def come here again to dine!
author: Eza C.

description:
Boiling over.

The good.

-  Cool design. Small space with a minimalist Japanese design highlight by upside down sake bottle taps on the wall.

- Washugyu beef shabu shabu. Amazing how quickly it cooked in the boiling water. You were left with a succulent strip of meat that was a joy to consume.

The OK.

- Shrimp, scallops and clam medley in a dashi broth. Wished there was more of the former than the takes effort latter. Pleasantly light overall. Yam noodles were so so.

- Porridge made with leftover broth at the end was different and unique. Too sweet for my tastes by at least it helped justify the $19 - $29 dish price.

The underwhelming.

- Forgetting our shabu shabu accompaniments until we asked.

- Forgetting our check until we asked.

- Forgetting to put a reasonable amount of noodles in each dish. Or perhaps it was the proper quantity. Disappointing either way. Didn't ask.

Much promise but the misses left me boiling like the food. Too many service mistakes to overcome a not very impressive meal. Friendly and trying. But missing.

Walls were the highlight. Walls should never be the highlight.
author: Jason B.

description:
Nothing beat hotpot/shabu during butt freezing winter in SF.
I've been a shabu fan way before shabu house started popping up all over bay area. 
I've been to almost every shabu restaurant in S.F, and Nabe is definitely something something.

Nabe is a cozy little restaurent located in the area that i HATE the most(Juah & 9, Pain in the butt to find parking).
They offer various flavor broth which is  different from other places.
I had Sukiyaki and Spicy Miso, and they were both very flavorful. I liked Sukiyaki with vage and noodle, while Spicy Miso complimented the meat really well. Speaking of meat, their beef was probably one of the best in bay area. It had just right amount of fat so you won't feel so greasy afterward. Vegetables were okay, nothing outstanding, but they tasted really good with sukiyaki. I personally didn't like their porridge thingy because it was too spicy with spicy miso, i rather eat my rice instead. Oh did i mention all of their ingredients are organic and locally purchased! Well at least thats what they said.

Waitresses had really good service but food come out really slow, so give your self at least 2 hr to enjoy the meal.

**Warning** 
Sukiyaki comes with this raw egg as dipping sauce, but if you have weak stomach like me, you might wanna skip that. I don't wanna tell people what happen to me after i had that raw egg...but it wasn't pretty . 

All and all, i loved Nabe, and can't wait to go back there again if it wasn't located Judah&9....
author: elly l.

description: Favorite shabu place ! Love the sukiyaki broth . The best part is the rice soup after.
author: Dafo W.

description: The miso broth was absolutely amazing. A very satisfactory meal. I can't wait to come back again!
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Nabe is a pretty interesting place with the most misleading name. You would expect them to be serving nabe here, but it's actually more like hot pot/shabu shabu. There's no clay or iron pot in the middle and it's a split half half metal pot that you find in shabu shabu places. The place has one long community table, a six person table, and some four people tables. The community table is large enough to fit a party of 12-14. One problem with this place is it's not big enough to support all the demand it's getting. The wait time for this place around dinner can be over an hour long. Pop in before dinner time and there may be a table free.

== Food ==

Shabu Shabu set was good. The pork was pretty tasty. The broth for this one was kind of sweet which made it pretty nice.

Sukiyaki set was also good. The beef were really tasty, soft, and tender. The spicy miso broth was pretty spicy.

Good amount of veggies that come with the dishes. I like the beef more than the pork due to the texture. The pork was a bit chewy compared to the beef.

The rice finisher is amazing. They put rice into one of the soups and create a porridge from it. The soup soaked in all the beef and veggie flavor so it's pretty amazing. One thing you probably want to do is forget how fatty the soup is.

== Service ==

Service was great here. The waitress, Michelle (name escapes me), was really nice and helpful. Water was refilled once in a while. She came around to explain things and to ask if everything was good.

== Overall ==

4.5 Stars. Great place to go. Long wait times make it hard to grab a table here. The food is expensive, but it is good and the experience is amazing. Definitely a place worth going to, but it seems like a gamble since you might not get a table.
author: Steven B.

description:
I love hot pot and Nabe is the best place I've ever had it. The broths have so much depth of flavor which just enhances all the fresh and homemade elements added to the pot. The service is very efficient, fast and proper, but they can sometimes be too clinical and not personable enough. The last time I went our server was genuinely friendly and one thing that's always consistent is how much they know about their product. They always ask if its the first time we've been there and constantly give bits of information about their food and traditions throughout the night. 

The hot pot it located right in the center of the table which means your food is always piping hot. There are recommended combinations in the menu, but you can always deviate from that with tons of different combinations of ingredients. You can tell that everything from the noodles to the vegetables are great quality. 

One of the biggest things that sets this place apart is the "rice special." That's when they take any of your leftover broth, reduce it down to thicken it, add egg, rice, seaweed water, shallots and make a porridge that's phenomenal. I look forward to it every time; it really makes you feel like you're getting your money's worth and extra food. Its always a great end to dinner because of that. You can still get dessert too.
author: Dexter H.

description:
3.5 stars

Spicy Miso broth is LEGIT! Seriously. It was spicy. It was miso-ey. Get it. You won't regret it. :D And I would avoid the konbu broth unless you want just a very plain, clean flavor. The konbu is kind of nice because it adds a very subtle konbu taste to all your food, so what your tasting is just the food itself with no added flavors. It was nice with some of the meats in my opinion - I really got to taste the quality of the meat (which is good, btw).

There are a lot of shabu places in SF, and this one is pretty good. Not my fave, but I would come back. The service was really nice and I really liked the decor!
author: Jade R.

description: Definitely my favorite shabu shabu restaurant so far. The atmosphere is very nice, The food is delicious and fresh, and the restaurant and tables are very organized which is very important when it comes to hot pot I think. They also have a wonderfully wide selection of Sake.
author: Colin B.

description:
My friend raved about this place and since I love shabu so much, I decided to make a drive to the city and give it a try. Maybe my expectation was too high, but the food here tasted just like any regular shabu place (i.e., Shabuway) with maybe a few more choices of broth.

I ordered the large, which I told contained 11oz of waygu, but I still walked out unsatisfied. The beef just doesn't seem like a lot, especially since they were sliced so thin. Even though it's nice that they offer different types of broth, but honestly I can't really taste the difference in broth anyways when I'm eating the food. The rice porridge at the end is a nice touch but doesn't really add much value to a supposedly very meat based meal.
author: Sherry Y.

description:
one of the best hot pot/ shabu place in SF so far. 
came in after couple weeks of opening. 

Pro:
clean, and simple decor. 
Comfy sitting area
good quality of meat
quality of soup base (we had sukiyaki and spicy miso)
surprisingly good quality of egg (raw organic egg as dipping sauce for sukiyaki)
friendly service

Con: 
portion isn't big but isn't small either. hungry? you might need to spend a lot here. 
A/C system just alright. Why I get smelled after shabu? 
limited dipping sauce choices

I love the meat here. nice marbled, delicious, fresh so I do 100% enjoy whole experience. 
the best sukiyaki shabu in SF for sure. 
want some sweet savory dinner shabu? I will come here for sure~
author: JustinE Y.

description: If you have had hot pot before, nothing beats this place. Once you try this place, nothing else beats it. Great service, great food. Been here many times and am never disappointed from anything at all. Place also looks pretty unique  too.
author: Raymond T.

description: I chose the kimchi hotpot which comes with pork belly and it was satisfying though I wish they gave more meat even if there was less extra stuff in the stock itself. One huge plus is the mochi which is the best thing with hotpot. The cost is mid-range but for someone young as me, I wouldn't be able to have this too often. Even so, I brought company and they all loved it and I definitely think it's a nice place to bring a couple friends. Not too many though because the restaurant is really awkwardly long and small. Love that the window's get all steamy though, adds to the mood. The place also needs to be open for longer hours.
author: Valerie Z.

description:
That is the Shabu Shabu I looking for a long time!!!
Food size just is right! 
And feel happiness in the same time... 
Great job!!
author: Tung T.

description:
Originally we were supposed to eat at san tung but the wait was too long. We yelped this place and walked several blocks so we wouldn't lose our parking.

The restaurant is small but fancy looking from the outside with floor to ceiling glass. 

The servers were very nice and patient with us explaining the process of how to order since this was our first time. We decided on the kimchee with pork belly, and the seafood pot. The kimchee pot was flavorful (Korean soup), and the seafood pot's broth was more soy saucy/salty. At the end they use the leftover broth to make the rice porridge. The kimchee porridge was my favorite since it tasted like kimchee fried rice (porridge). The seafood broth porridge was way too salty almost to the point of being indelible. I took one bite and that's it.

Overall good food and fun experience.
author: Pammy L.

description: Dined here for the first time the other night. I love hot pot and this was just ok for me. The waitresses were pretty terrible at explaining the menu. The male waiter that helped us out was much better and more attentive. Edamame and dumpling apps were good. Quality of the meat was good. However, the spicy miso broth was basically tasteless which was disappointing. The kimchee was better, but still a little lacking. The only way I got any flavor was dipping in the ponzu sauce, which was good. The rice finisher was delicious and the best part of the meal. I would possibly come back for apps and the finisher. Otherwise, I would skip it.
author: Ashley F.

description:
I came here on a weekend night for dinner and was amazed. What a food adventure! I was a first-time hot potter so pretty much delighted by everything I had: the regular miso broth with veggies and beef, and the seafood in a split pot. It looks like some people had bad experiences with service, but the servers I had were all great. 

Beware, this place is very small so does get packed and busy and typically has a wait. Not ideal for someone who gets claustrophobic as the space is pretty tiny as some other reviewers mentioned and I would not come here with a big group. Food is beyond worth it, however.
author: Lauren C.

description:
This spot is really close to my house and I had been dying to see if it was any good.  Unfortunately they made ONE KEY mistake that makes them just a mehhhhh ok place.

We ordered the traditional shabu shabu and the duck.  The problem was that the duck was raw and came already in the pot with a divider for the shabu shabu on the other side.  You need to keep the temperature up so that you can have your shabu shabu, but within 5 minutes the duck was severely overcooked.

The waitress came over and apologized but did nothing.  I dont' see why they didn't give us two pots or give us the raw duck on a place like the other meat.

Anyway, at the end they make some type of rice soup thing which I enjoyed.  Probably would not come back.
author: Aly A.

description: The broth is very tasty. The duck and pork belly was good. But one of the waitress was not very professional. She forgot to bring our soba. She started the rice for the broth but she never came back to complete it. Too many of her friends were there.
author: Anna S.

description: really enjoyed the shabu! The meat was super fresh and their broth selection was great. I had the Spicy Miso with the beef and loved it! Also, i love that they don't waste the broth and turn it into a pouridge for you once you are done!
author: Larisa V.

description: Pretty good and modern place to get shabu shabu. The lunch prices are more reasonable than the dinner prices. The restaurant is a bit pricer than other shabu places that I've been. With that said, I've tired the beef shabu and sukiyaki here and both are good. In the shabu order, you get vegetables and meat on the side for cooking. In the sukiyaki order, the vegetables are already in the soup and you cook your beef in the broth as you do for shabu. You also get an egg with the sukiyaki.
author: Ali F.

description: One of the best Shabu places I've been in the city. Love what they do at the end when they cook the rice for you. Will definitely go back again!
author: Justin C.

description:
This place was a total rip; the food was not fresh and I felt really nauseous afterwards.
Do not get any seafood here; it was old and fishy, disgusting.  When I told the waiter he was very defensive, left our table, and came back saying he could give us dessert on the house.  I wasn't saying this to get dessert on the house; the food was not fresh and I asked for sparkling water to settle my stomach.  
Poor quality food, overpriced, NOT authentic; those of you who have gone to Japan and have shabu know this place is nowhere near authentic.
author: Candy M.

description: Fun experience, a bit pricey, but good for dates and lingering over a shared meal. This is an interactive meal and you will be doing the cooking. Your gratuity will be a flavorful broth, and a great bowl of okayu/porridge at meal's end. I had the sukiyaki - a bit too sweet, wifey had the shabu shabu, and that was great, and what we made the porridge from, per the waitress' reco. The environs are upscale and chic minimal. The Apple Store vibe (not a bad thing) is tempered by the jovial decor of orderly boxes of sake on the walls, each conveying a story of an enjoyable evening. While your story may not end up on the walls, you will have good memories.
author: E. W.

description:
mEh, nothing special. The service is great but I feel there are better places for shabu. The only thing different about this place is that they have several more soup bases and the porridge at the end, which is mixing rice and egg into your left over soup that you were cooking your meat in. 

Came here Fri night with my gf and didn't have to wait. We got lucky because other people after us had to wait a little. This place is pretty small and it gets really stuffy. Alcohol seems to be more expensive than other places. Try this place if you havn't. Not my cup of tea but maybe you'll like it.
author: Roger N.

description: One of the best shabu house! Love the service and food, esp the kimchi broth and turn it into porridge at the end. Reservation is recommended.
author: anita s.

description: Incredible! Organic and locally sourced ingredients. Yam noodles to substitute udon. Delicious spicy miso broth, high quality kobe, and a rice soup ending... so yummy. Highly recommend this place to everyone!!
author: Shaelyne J.

description:
This place is tiny. However, the decor is great (despite the lack of ventilation) and the service is fantastic.

The shabu itself, though, was mediocre and seemed somewhat expensive. We ended up getting the large "Shabu Shabu" (beef) with an extra side portion of pork belly. They definitely tried to upsell us to two entrees, but it was a good enough portion of food for two. I finished the meat and veggies feeling comfortably full but not entirely satisfied. As they started clearing the table, I had a twinge of regret - for just a normal dinner, maybe we should have just gone to Marnee Thai, or San Tung, for cheaper.

BUT THEN. Then, they came and made the Zosui rice soup. It's a rice porridge that's included with your meal, and is made from the leftovers of your hot pot. It took quite a long time (a bit of an art, it seems), and we had a nice conversation with our waitress as she stirred. She finally handed us two heaping bowls and I took a tentative bite... then downed the rest of the bowl in record time. It was AMAZING. We ended up with 3-4 extra servings for leftovers, too -- which makes the aforementioned high price suddenly reasonable.

And that, my friend, is why I will be back to Nabe. Because I need to try all the other flavors of porridge. I'm serious. It's only been a week and I already crave it.
author: Jackie L.

description:
I love Shabu, but hate msg.  I don't like the tired and sluggish affects after. Imagine my excitement when I discovered a new Shabu place that serves organic ingredients in an msg-free broth had opened. 

We arrived on a Saturday night and though we had a reservation, there were a few open seats. The restaurant is small, the decor is minimal but cute, and there is a row of communal tables down the center.

We tried three diff broths. Our favorite was definitely the spicy miso. It was very flavorful!  The meats and veggies tasted fresh. Overall, everything was great, including the service. They seemed short staffed, but everyone was friendly and helpful. We really enjoyed the rice soup they prepare for you at the end. 

The only drawback is that the place is poorly ventilated. It was very stuffy inside. Regardless, I'll definitely be back
author: K V.

description:
Nabe was delicious. Next time I'm in San Fransisco, I'm definitely making a trip back here for dinner.

I agree with Jackie H., there is limited spacing for their customers, but the decor is pretty.
author: Kristen L.

description:
Shabu with lots of options and a couple of new twists!

The food here is standard good 3 stars, but gave it 4 stars for selection and variety of soups, meat, noodles, etc.

The Duck breast in dashi broth was exciting to try.  It comes with greens, daikon, and noodles stewing in the broth.  It was tasty, but a note to the eater- take out the duck as soon as it cooks so it doesn't get tough.  We also had the standard spicy miso with beef, which was also good.  At the end of your meal you can have rice added to your broth to create an after meal porridge.

Pros:
- Selection
- Shabu pot can accommodate two separate broths
- The hot plate aligns flush with the table
- Service is excellent
- The decor is modern and simple

While I'm still totally fixed on eating at Shabu House, Nabe is a good destination if you live nearby or want to try something new.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
i'm a huge fan of soupy foods. pho, ramen, shabu, thai noodle soup, cioppino. i loves it all. no surprise that i was very interested in this new-ish hot pot place. 

i typically go to shabu shabu, which is a type of hot pot (i learned recently). we had to wait an hour and a half on a chilly, super foggy sunday evening. the staff was sweet though, and called us when our table was ready. 

our server gave us a nice breakdown of the menu, explaining that some items come with everything in the broth, only vegetables in the broth and meat on the side, or everything on the side. very helpful. 

for appetizers, we got the edamame as well as the korobuta sausage with mustard aioli. the edamame was yummy, and had a slightly smoky flavor that we liked. the sausage was delicious and the mustard aioli was a perfect creamy complement to the saltiness of the pork. 

for entrees, my roommate got sukiyaki and i got the kimchi + korobuta pork shoulder. the pork belly would have been a nice option, but i didn't feel like having such a fatty meat that night. our food came quickly, which is good because we were huuungry! i liked the sukiyaki broth much better than mine. the flavor was perfect and complex. also, the raw egg used as a dipping sauce after the meat was cooked, really kicks it up a notch. the kimchi broth wasn't salty enough for me, but after i cooked my pork slices, i dipped them in the accompanying ponzu sauce, which was delicious. ponzu saved the day. i also felt that the meat portion for the regular size was a bit small, considering the price. hmph.

i realized halfway through my meal that i didn't get my savory mochi. the server quickly grabbed it for me and apologized for forgetting. i forgot to mention that earlier, they brought me pork belly instead of shoulder. two small mistakes, but i understand they were really busy. didn't let that ruin my experience.

the end of the meal was, of course, finished off my preparing the rice porridge with the leftover broth. they actually ran out of rice, so he used udon noodles with the sukiyaki broth. heavennnn. by the time we finished, they had prepared more rice, and he made us the proper porridge out of the kimchi broth, too. i liked the kimchi broth a lot more after it had boiled down and became more salty. oh well. 

all in all, i had a great time and yummy food. nabe won't be my regular go-to, as the price point is a bit higher than my usual spot, but i'll be back for that sukiyaki broth!
author: Ashleigh R.

description:
Went here around 5:30pm on a Monday and it was not busy at all. By the time we finished around 7 there is still plenty of seats available. 

The menu can be slightly confusing so ask the waitress how it works if it's your first time there. Basically you can choose 2 broth in one pot (you pay for each broth; ex. if you have one pot with 2 broth you pay for the 2 broths separately) and you can choose size large or small. The size refers to the amount of meat they give you rather than the pot size.  Since the store is relatively new, most of the staff seem to still be in training so our ordering process was kind of chaotic because we had some difficulty figuring out how to order and the pricing. 

We had 5 girls sharing 4 broths (2 pots, each pot with 2 kinds of broth) and it was a good amount. We each ended up paying $22 dollars (including tax/tip).  We tried the seasonal duck, spicy miso shabu shabu, kimchi/pork belly, and the Sukiyaki. 

1. Spicy Miso- a little spicier than I'd like, came with udon noodles and veggies/meat.Broth is very flavorful.
 
2. Duck- broth tasted like sukiyaki, came with soba noodles and mochi chunks. The duck is very soft and tasty even after boiling for 20 minutes.

3. Kimchi/pork belly: not too spicy or salty, pork belly meat was really good and thinly sliced

4. Sukiyaki- sweat/salty broth, goes well with beef and has jelly noodles in it. 

Quality of the meats are pretty good. Overall broth are pretty heavily flavored.

In the end the staff will add rice/egg, green onion and roasted seaweed to one broth per pot of your choice. They make a congee out of the left over broth. If they ask you how the broth taste, ask them to dilute your broth if you feel like it was on the salty side. We did not know this so we told them broth tasted fine and our congee turned out to be super salty and inedible with the sukiyaki broth. The congee with the kimchi broth was delicious however.

I think there are definitely room for improvement, but given the quality of the food and considering the fact that they just opened, I think they can (and hopefully will)  get better with time.
author: Whitney W.

description: I live nearby and I've always been wanting to try this restaurant because I knew it was a Japanese restaurant and it always looked steamy inside. So, one cold night, I walked in not knowing it was a hot pot place. I haven't had the chance to read any of the Yelp reviews so I didn't know what the expect. I sat down and was worried that there would be too much food for a solo diner, being a hot pot place. Boy, was I wrong!  I ordered the small sukiyaki with the waygu beef and it was just the right amount of deliciousness. The broth was a little salty, but I figured I didn't need to drink the broth, just the stuff inside. When I thought my meal had ended, I asked for my check and was pleasantly surprise to learn that my meal wasn't quite over yet.  I was informed that rice was going to be added to my left over broth for a delicious porridge! MIND...BLOWN. It was perfect, because I was still hungry. The waitress did her thing with the rice and asked me if it was too salty. So, I said yes and she fixed it right away by adding hot water. In the end, the porridge with egg was very tasty. I'm just knocking off a star because I thought the broth was too salty and I would've like a little more contents in my soup. Such as more vegetable and noodles. Overall it was a delicious experience, service was great, and I would totally go back.
author: Aimey T.

description:
3.5 STARS My parents and I were brought here today by my aunt and uncle who are both locals of the bay area. We had originally been planning on going to Mum's across the street from our hotel in Japantown. But, after hearing where we were planning on eating, my uncle insisted we try here because it's just a million times better than Mum's. 

Walked in and first thing we noticed was that the decor is super nice. Very sleek and classy looking (and apparently the guy who designed the place is the same guy who designed my aunt's lounge/club). Waitress is really nice and was very attentive. Probably helped that we got there pretty early for dinner, around 5:30, and the place was still empty. 

Menu: Smaller selection, but they do have different broths including a spicy miso broth, plain seaweed broth, and other soy based broths. We went with the traditional broth, just because we prefer getting the flavor from the ponzu sauce, garlic and green onions. No all you can eat, which is kind of a bummer but the food was still pretty on point.

Food: the quality of the meat was obviously way better than Mum's all-you-can-eat. The Wagyu beef was mouth wateringly tender and the selection of seafood was great (coming with salmon, clams, shrimp, etc.) Veggie were pretty standard: 3 different types of mushrooms, napa cabbage, carrots, tofu, spinach, and udon and clear noodles. One interesting thing was the squash. Never tried that, but it was really good as well. They give you the 2 standard sauces, but one thing I didn't like was that they give you the ponzu sauce already made. I like adding as much garlic, radish, and green onions as I like to my sauce. Also, the portions are not that big. I ordered a regular, and still ate half my mom's plate of beef as well as all the veggies on my plate (I also had just come from an oyster happy hour that included 6 dozen oysters, 2 dungeness crab cocktails, and many cocktails between the 5 of us). For the price, I wasn't about to order more. At the end, they make a porridge out of the broth. Isn't really anything special as much as my uncle tries to hype it up. Just rice, egg, and seaweed, made in the broth from our meat. Was pretty plain, so I mixed the ponzu sauce into it to make it taste better. 

Overall, I still prefer Mum's all-you-can-eat. Even though the meat quality isn't as good, Shabu Shabu is not that filling so I need much more than the servings they give us. Also, I like eating more veggies and making my own sauce. For the price I paid, I don't think I would've been very happy if I had come here on a completely empty stomach.
author: Tiara T.

description: Very nice and accommodating staff especially for a big man like myself. Food was great. High quality meats. Fresh vegetables. The spicy miso of course was good but also excellent was the mushroom vegetarian broth. The rice porridge was delicious. A must return restaurant.
author: Gregory F.

description:
We got kimichee kurobuta bacon and sukiyaki. The sukiyaki was infinitely better. Cooked meat dipped in raw egg=holy moly. 

The rice porridge at the end was too salty and sweet even after our waitress offered to dilute it. BTW, I appreciate the side table service a lot. 

I could really taste the sugar and the mirin from the sukiyaki. I didn't really enjoy it. Bummer~ 

If I were to come here again, I would definitely get shabu shabu. Kombu, cabbage + beef make a much tastier porridge than sukiyaki.
author: Margaret S.

description:
This place is pretty much a weekly stop for me now, and I always bring friends and family from out of town here because of the whole experience. I like a place that keeps things basic and doing everything well, and that's what you get here. I've had every broth on the menu and virtually every side item listed. I'm particularly fond of the duck -- I actually find myself craving it. The broths have a wide variety of flavors, though I gravitate mostly to the spicy shabu shabu and the sukiyaki. The zosui rice finish is AWESOME. A real highlight and fills you up just right. 

Excellent sake menu. Try the one that looks like it's in an oil can. Seriously. I don't remember what it's called. Probably because I barely remember that night. Powerful stuff! 

I'm also a big fan of the staff. Friendly and attentive. My Mum and Dad loved this place -- remarkable considering this definitely isn't their style of food. That puts this place over the top for me. Go and enjoy.
author: Pete H.

description: Healthy and refreshing meal. Delicious soup, meat, and veggie. Friendly staff and great service! Highly recommended!
author: An V.

description:
I ate here once with a group of friends, and it was one of the best dinners I have ever eaten. The food here is absolutely amazing.

My friend and I had the sukiyaki and kimchi kurobuta pork belly sets (both in regular), and it was enough to feed 2.5 people (I say .5 because my friend was eating from the sukiyaki/kimchi kurobuta set and our other friends' set which was shabu shabu and seafood). It was extremely filling and tasted amazing. Both sukiyaki and kimchi broths were full of flavor and plentiful in assorted veggies (the mushrooms in the sukiyaki broth absorbed all the flavors in the broth which made it even tastier). The ponzu dipping sauce for the beef made the beef taste even better. At the end of the meal, the servers make a rice porridge from the broth of your choice (we chose the shabu  shabu broth which was a miso broth). I usually don't like rice porridge but this was super delicious porridge, probably because the miso broth was so flavorful.

I most definitely recommend this place and will be coming back soon. So worth every penny.
author: J L.

description: I absolutely love the atmosphere they provide. Every time that I come here, our experience is amazing! Not only are the soups delicious, but the service is great too! The waiters/waitresses are very attentive to each customer, and even make conversation. Tonight, I totally forgot my bag, and one of the waitresses was kind enough to flag us down as we were walking away- such lovely and sweet people! I think this is going to be my new go-to date night spot with my boyfriend!
author: Nicole A.

description:
The kimchi pork belly shabu was delicious. It's great to have a shabu shabu place in the Inner Sunset. I was stuffed by the time they made the rice porridge. However, it made for an excellent lunch the next day!

It's a little bit on the expensive side. It's also weird that the front windows get all fogged up.
author: Jang K.

description: I really enjoyed eating at this restaurant. It's fun and delicious at the same time. The broth (kimchi) was perfect and the portion is generous. They also have great black sesame ice cream and red bean ice cream. Yummy!
author: Emily Y.

description: Came here for a friend's bday, had about 9 people. The place is a bit awkward. we sat in the middle of a long table, sorta like a cafeteria style seating. Waitress was a bit not on the friendly side, maybe cuz she got confused with our orders and kinda messed up. Not our fault! No all you can eat...so not really worth come again.
author: Alyce l.

description: We ate here tonight for the first time.  Reservation is a must.  Great food awesome service and the food pleased the adults and picky ten year olds.  We will be back!!
author: Molly M.

description:
We enjoyed a great meal here.  Had Wagyu beef for the first time, and it was wonderful and so tender in the Sukiyaki.  The Seafood Yosenabe was ordered and enjoyed by our party too, nice variety of seafood. They bring this to the table already sitting in the pot, where you don't have to dip and cook the seafood yourself.  

Come here for "quality, not quantity", because when I asked if we could have more vegetables for the hot pot, waitress offered to sell me a platter of them.  

Parking is tough as stated by others; and reservations should be made in advance if you don't want to wait for a table, especially on the weekends.  I was told that weekdays this place isn't nearly as busy.
author: Julie S.

description: I've travelled around the world twice, my wife is Japanese.  I can clearly say not only is this a wonderfully unique restaurant serving an authentic Japanese cuisine, it's one of the best in California.  They serve Nabe, soup style yummy Japanese food, with thinly sliced, high quality beef that you cook on your table.   This is real, not stupid Benihana, nor the normal fare that passes for Japanese food at most Japanese restaurants, tempura, sushi, etc.  Try it.  You'll love it.
author: Adam s.

description:
I normally don't eat Hot pot but my friends took me here and ever since then I began to really like it!!! I love how they made porridge from the soup after wards it really cleanses the system and the food was delicious!!! WOW

I got a vegetarian option and it was worth it! it is a bit pricey for the food here!
author: Sophia W.

description: I LOVE this place!!!!! Me and my bf love coming here we've basically become regulars lol we always get the shabu shabu with beef and it's soooooo good! It's hilarious how someone said that it was "too hot", um hello how else are you supposed to cook your meat??? It's like me going to a club and complaining about how loud the music is. And yes this isn't the type of restaurant where your done in 30 minutes, were usually here for about an hour which is fine with me.
author: Militza N.

description:
One of my favorite Shabu places in SF. At one point, I literally came here 3 times a week! So let's break down what makes this place so successful:

1. The food -- flavorful broth, organic vegetables, grass fed beef
2. The service -- attentive, gives great recommendations, graceful
3. The ambiance -- love the glass wall facing the street. When the place is full and the steam fogs up the glass, the cozy feeling of having eating in front of a simmering pot of goodness is priceless

I usually get the shabu shabu with spicy miso brother and wagyu beef. Don't forget to ask for the sesame sauce to compliment the meat. One order doesn't look like a lot of food compared to all those all the you can shabu places out there but with the rice finisher, it gets quite filling. The rice finisher is like a porridge. Rice is added to broth to thicken. An egg is added to the concoction when the stove is turned off. It is then garnished with green onions and seaweed. If you can't finish it there, it makes a great breakfast for the next day.  

I've also tried the sukiyaki. The broth is slightly sweeter and it comes with the calorie free shirataki noodles. This is a slightly healthier option and equally as delicious.
author: Foodi C.

description:
This is an excellent hot pot restaurant. Stylish, small, attentive service, fresh ingredients, and you cook it for yourself. The rice porridge that finishes the meal is terrific. There is only one note. It's not as cheap as you might think it will be. That's all. Casual but pricey.

Will be going back.
author: Frank W.

description: Cute little restaurant that happily accept reservation. The food was nicely set up and the food was actually quite decent. The portion can be kind of small but i liked it
author: Jenny N.

description: Great place! pretty modern a bit small. Came here for a party of 12 they were very accommodating. Service was attentive. The bathroom has a sliding door.. i was confused for a bit! The meat quality in key for me. I'm very picky with my meat.. One amazing treat at the end is the rice porridge, they don't waste your broth with the flavorful meat you put in there! The spicy Kim chee and Shabu Shabu is the way to go!
author: Sandra T.

description:
After hearing many things about Nabe through my friend, I was excited to try it last night for my friend's birthday. Luckily we had a small dinner party because this place was probably one of the tiniest dine-in restaurant I've ever been to!! A long communal table that stretched from the front to the back was placed in the midde, and there were about 3 or 4 separate tables of four to the side. When I first got there I felt like I was walking into the steam room. All the steam from everybody's broth was circulating the air and there seemed to be no ventilation - the only way I felt that air was escaping was through the open front door. The thought of my face/makeup melting off was a little worrying but that wasn't going to keep me from dipping my meats into any pots!

I ordered the Shabu Shabu - with beef and spicy miso broth. I've had a few different spicy miso at other shabu places but this was probably the most flavorful! Unlike other shabu places, the spices such as chili oil, garlic, radish, and pepper flakes weren't laid out on the table as condiments -but you had to ask for it yourself. Im guessing it's because the place is so small they didn't want to add more clutter. Also, the sesame goma sauce did not come as a standard so you had to ask for it to get it. I like adding extra garlic to my sauces and to my broth as well. I was a little disappointed when I asked for the hot drop and was told that they didn't offer it here. I looove hot drops - I feel like it gives my sauce a little kick and makes everything that much more delicious. Oh well, the meal goes on. I got a regular and it came with about 12 slices of beef. The slices are pretty thin but it will fill you up. Veggie platter consists of the usual: napa cabbage, spinach, enoki and shitaki mushrooms, carrots, tofu, and udon noodles. Overall everything tasted great. The broth was delicious, fresh veggies and the meat was tender! I had a chance to dip some of my meat in my friend's sukiyaki broth and it was good as well! I don't know if I'm the sweet type to be able to have a whole meal of it - but if I was sharing with someone I wouldn't mind having both sauces at my mercy. After the meal you can ask the servers to prepare a porridge for you! They basically just pour a bowl of rice into your broth, add an egg and green onions, mix it around and throw some seaweed on top ... but it's delicious! So simple but tasty :) I feel like adopting this tradition at other shabu places! I'd just have to save my rice to mix into the broth at the end. I've been to places where they offer to make you udon/noodles at the end of the meal but I guess this is a little reversed. Either way, it was a great experience. The servers are attentive and especially nice. Definitely a place I would recommend.
author: Ngan T.

description:
over rated food / broth
small and crowded seating / borderline claustrophobia inducing
steamy
bad service
over priced
tacky decor with sake dispensers
author: Yeeman N.

description: I was really excited to try this place, since I love hot pot. However, it was not very good overall. The Food - I order the large Spicy Miso Shabu Shabu with Wagyu Beef. The spicy miso had very little flavor. I had to request more spice in order to get it taste like any thing. The portion of meat was not a lot for a large but it was okay. The meal came with a brown sauce with onions and maybe garlic. This was my saving grace to  make a bland meal taste like anything. I will say that my friend, who order the duck, tasted much better. Well at least the duck did, I was not a fan of her soup base. On to The Service - We had reservation, so we were seated right away. However, the reservation was not needed since the place was pretty empty. The serve the soup and meat right away. The meal we order was a set, which also comes with rice and the normal shabu vegetables. Yet, this was not served right away. We had to ask twice for the rice. The first time we ask for the rice, they bring out the vegetables. After waiting a few minutes we asked again for the rice. I found this a little weird since the place wasn't busy and I would think bringing the rice and vegetable would be standard practice. The staff was pleasant enough, but not a lot of interaction (I am fine with this).  Lastly The Price - This place is expensive for what you get. You could go to an all you can eat Shabu House for the same price and better food. I would not recommend this place at all.
author: Yaya H.

description: This is my second time trying shabu (first time at Shabu Shabu on Geary) and this place was also very good, but pretty different. Nabe looks super modern and cool, and has great service. I got the Beef plate and it was big and the spicy miso broth was delicious. I liked that at Shabu House they gave some like kimchi and stuff on the side, but they didn't give anything other than the meat and vegetables here. But the food was fresh and fantastic. The best part, which I have never seen before, is the rice porridge they made at the end ( rice, spicy miso broth, raw egg, and onion); it was so good and creamy, something very new to me. The only thing I was disappointed with was the dessert, all these reviews said how good the mochi and sesame ice cream is, and I just was not impressed what-so-ever. But regardless, I will be coming back here for sure! Try it out!
author: Nikita K.

description: It's expensive for what you get. For $71 before tip, we got the split pot Seafood Yosenabe, Kamonaban (Duck), 1 Glass of Sake, & plate of Beef.  Really little seafood for $24. The duck is probably the better order of these 2. Probably should have read the reviews before hitting this place. If you really want to try this place, probably smarter to order 1 entree to share and add beef. The soup base is on the salty side and there is nothing special to it. The soup base are similar to the ready made soup base you can get at the Japanese Market. However, the interior design is quite nice. Make sure you make reservation If you want to sit at the table and not share the communal table with strangers. This small restaurant fills up fast.
author: Erica B.

description: As a local who has been to this location numerous times. I will NEVER be back. I called at 6:15 and was told that I couldn't get a reservation until 7. However if I came in right away my name would be on the walk in list and be 1st. We got there @ 6:25. Yet the couple who was NOT on the list and had NO reservation got seated instead of me. That's the 2nd time it's happened to me there. Can't help but feel like they are Extremely Racist. So if your NOTCaucasian or Asian expect to get treated horribly
author: Kelenia O.

description:
Nabe has a very small menu, but they focus on high quality ingredients.  They do shabu a bit different here, they call it Nabemono but its practically the same thing.  Most shabu restaurants I've been to usually bring out the soup and the uncooked ingredients on a plate.  At Nabe they already put everything in the pot, with the flavored broth.  They do have one dish, called Shabu, where you do put the ingredients in yourself.  The food was excellent, the thinly sliced washugyu beef was very tender and flavorful.  We also had an order of the seafood mix which had a great variety of seafood options which included salmon, clams, shrimp and scallops.  The seasonal special was a duck breast which was very good but be sure not to cook the duck too long, the water can boil quick and the duck can get over cooked.  It comes crusted on the skin side but the rest of the duck is rare until they turn on the electric burner on.  The broth is came with was very good, wasn't too salty.  It also came with a small dish of cold soba noodles which compliment the salt form the broth and duck very nicely.  My favorite was the kimchee pork belly, the pork belly was cut very thin and had great flavor and tenderness.  The kimchee wasn't overpowering and added a nice flavor and seasoning to the vegetables and meat.  The most interesting item that came with the pork belly was the mochi.  It comes in a separate dish and it really hard but once its cooked in the broth, it becomes very chewy.  All the dishes come with vegetables by the way.  

BE SURE TO SAVE ROOM AT THE END...when you're finished eating all the meat and vegetables, they use the leftover broth, pour some cooked rice to create this awesome porridge.  They take out whatever left over ingredients in the broth (if you are too full to eat them), pour the cooked rice in the broth, let it come to a boil until it thickens a little bit.  Then they pour a raw egg, seaweed and green onions as it all comes together to create a very flavorful porridge, a nice way to end a meal on.  If it's too salty for you, they can add more rice or water to balance it out for you.  If you're too full to eat the porridge, you can also take it home and it will taste just as good the following day.  Great way to make use of all the leftover food and ingredients when most shabu places tend to waste a lot of leftover food and some even charge when there is an all you can eat option. Since you get this porridge at the end, the meals don't come with rice.  You will have to order it on the side but I was fine without it.  

Staff was extremely friendly and helpful, they were very prompt on refilling my teacup.  Decor was very nice but this is a very small place.  I think they could use a better ventilation system, the windows got all foggy and it was a little steamy inside. It is on the pricier side of Shabu/Hot Pot places, but the menu is different and more unique in my opinion.  I also feel the quality is top notch and above the rest of the shabu places I've been to.  This has become one of my favorite places to eat shabu/hot pot and I'm positive I'll be back soon.
author: Darren W.

description: Yay another hot pot place I like besides Shabu House. I came here on a super cold day in SF, so it was perfect for hot pot! This restaurant is pretty small (probably fits around 50 people or less?). The owner who was also our server said it gets pretty packed on the weekends, but you can call ahead of time to put your name on the waiting list. She was super friendly btw! I love restaurants with good service. Anyway, we decided to order the sukiyaki with beef and pork. I wasn't a huge fan of their pork (still good though, just not my fav), but their beef was delicious. Especially dipped in the raw egg, yumm. Also, all the veggies and tofu were already in our soup. We weren't super full by the time we finished our meat and veggies, but when you're finished with your meal they come and serve "The Finisher". Basically, they add rice to your remaining soup to make a porridge out of it! So awesome. They also had scallions and seaweed for the finishing touch. The server will ask you if you want to dilute it and I advise you to do so because heating the soup up again makes it too sweet! At least with the sukiyaki. I will definitely come back here again to try their shabu shabu next!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Nabe is basically a shabu/hot pot-type restaurant whose main appeal is their organic ingredients and no MSG. However, they failed on almost every other front.

1. The dishes here have enough salt in them to fill the Dead Sea. I get the "organic, no MSG" part, and that's why we went, but everything was so salty I was drinking water all night to the point where I felt bloated before bed. Every restaurant needs their food to taste good, and Nabe does this by excessively salting up their broth. On the other hand, given the organic nature of this place, it was probably organic sea salt...

2. Ridiculously high prices. A large nabe or shabu here will set you back $24, or $29 if you want the seafood. Compare that to about $17 at your typical shabu place in SF, and you're paying a 50% premium for the organic ingredients and no MSG broth. You're also paying with your health, because all that salt can't possibly be good for you.

3. So-so service. We had a well-meaning server who tried hard to make us happy, but she was inexperienced and slow. It was clear that most of the servers were relatively new to the business and didn't have much experience, so even though they had a relatively good ratio of servers to customers, everything took a long time - from getting our food served to receiving the check.

The porridge they make at the end - basically dumping a bowl of rice, a beaten egg, and green onions into the leftover broth - is interesting, but it also has the effect of further concentrating the already salty broth. We felt bad not eating it after the server spent 5 minutes stirring it, but we also weren't sure that her solution of adding even more broth was going to solve the underlying problem.

Our total check for 2 entrees (no appetizers, no drinks) came to $66 with tax and tip. We had to try this new nabe/shabu place because my boyfriend doesn't like MSG and that was a big selling point, but we almost certainly won't be going back.
author: Bing W.

description: So glad Nabe is in my hood! I dine at Nabe about once a month and it never disappoints. I always order the reg Shabu for dinner (7oz of beef) and am satisfied everytime. The servers make zosui (rice soup) at the end of the meal and its amazing! Since Nabe is now open for lunch I had to stop by. Had lunch on Sat and ordered a large beef Shabu (7oz of beef). The lunch portions are smaller, reg Shabu is 5oz and large is 7oz. The 7oz for dinner and lunch look the same and I walk out feeling the same, satisfied. Thank you Nabe for being open for lunch, finally!
author: Matthew o.

description: I really enjoyed my experience at this restaurant. Modern fresh food, conteporary decor. Server was very helpful and took the time to explain every dish and recommended great things to try. Embarrassed to say that i don't remember the names of the dishes we had, i only remember that they were delicious.  i am glad we have such restaurant in our neighbourhood now.
author: Diana K.

description: The rice porridge at the end was delicious! It's what I look forward to the most when I come here. When I first discovered Nabe, I ate at the restaurant 3x in under 2 weeks. It's SO good! Great for shabu shabu. I also took my parents here to celebrate their bdays and the employees were great at surprising them with dessert and making the evening very special. Very great staff and delicious food too. Keep it up, Nabe!!
author: Louise C.

description: Great service and great food. My favorite part is the zosui rice porridge they make out of your soup at the end of your meal. Everything was very fresh! Not a very big place but a great place to bring your date. :)
author: Mimi C.

description: Excellent food, great service and engaging atmosphere. If you are in the inner sunset I would highly recommend stopping in.
author: Tim D.

description: On the first step in, my armpits began to perspire. Located in the sleepy little town of San Francisco, Nabe, which in Japanese means "unadulterated flower", is not only a restaurant, but an experience. Not only do you eat your food, but you cook it to! I was a little surprised when they sent me back into the kitchen and told me to "get to it" - a little unusual for a hostess to say! After four hours I was exhausted, and began to slow down - only to be reprimanded! "Gèngjiā nlì dì gōngzuò, n tā mā de jinsù!" Ah, beautiful, traditional Chinese, elegantly dictated across a bustling kitchen! "Duìbùq, w huì nlì," I replied, a smile plastered on my face. By the end of my shift (10 hours later) I was so tired I couldn't even eat, let alone have a sit down dinner - and I began to walk home feeling satisfied. A day of hard work was always rewarding. A unique experience that could only be found here, at Nabe, has changed my life for the better, and I'm sure would do the same for any other. Highly recommended, enjoy Nabe.
author: Ryan M.

description: I had really high hopes for this place. What can I say, high end hot pot with a twist!?! Yes, please! So this is not your typical all you can eat hot pot place. You sit down, order a style and protein and they bring it out. At the end, you pick one of your soups and they make a porridge for you. The only problem is that everything is really bland, especially the seafood one. I was left utterly disappointed and to make matters worse, when I ate the porridge, it was sooooo salty that I could only take 2 bites. Overall, I really wanted to love this place but unfortunately I won't be returning.
author: Diane M.

description: We had the sukiyaki, shabu shabu, and kamonanban. The food was excellent; the broths were extremely flavorful and the meat/veggies were super fresh. Service was fantastic; my water was constantly being refilled. Cozy, intimate atmosphere. Food is easy to share; the 3 different dishes fed four of us. The rice porridge at the end of dinner is really yummy and flavorful as well. It gets a little steamy in the restaurant, so dress accordingly!
author: Ashlee C.

description:
not too many things that i crave outside of a Round Tables King Arthurs Supreme pizza every once in a while...that is except SHABU!

a hot pot of salty, spicy miso broth boiling away in front of you...

steam hitting your face, covering it with umami condensation...

so good. so good.

the thing that separates Nabe from other shabu spots is the quality of ingredients that they serve up there...

thinly sliced, marbled, tender pieces of quality beef.
super fresh seafood, that has been painstakingly prepped before being plated.
fresh cut veggies and quality noodles.

these are all things that most shabu places GET WRONG.  not here at Nabe tho...in a short amount of time...clearly they have the upper hand on the SHABU GAME.

in all honesty, Nabe is on the pricier side, compared to other shabu spots, BUT i promise you that after you try it, you will not be thinking of the few extra dollars you spend here...service, quality, and even their sake list are all definitely worth shelling out some more coin.

highly recommend this spot...easily the best Shabu ive had, period.
author: Kyu L.

description: this is such a fun place to go I can't believe I'd never been, living down the street. it was very clean waitress was so nice and  to have the boiling pot of broth and cooking the meat yourself added a little something extra to the meal. at the end they use the broth to make this rice pudding thing, so good. it's a little pricey but it's awesome place so I'll definitely go back
author: B G.

description: This is our go to place for shabu shabu in the city.  The wifey and I frequently make the trip from Nob Hill over to Sunset for this place.  You can't go wrong ordering the shabu shabu with waygu beef and spicy miso.  Their sake selection is solid as well.  Enjoy!
author: Dave H.

description: My friend brought me here to try shabu shabu. This is fantastic! I don't really have anything to compare it to but I was impressed! The services is fantastic, its right off of muni and its reasonably priced. The best part was the massive amount of leftovers that were only better when I ate them for lunch the next day.
author: Amber M.

description:
Interesting new take on the classic hotpot meal and more delicious than ever!

My girlfriends and I were visiting all the way from Canada and drove past this place after a tiring, and not to mention, cold day of shopping. The windows were all steamy which instantly told us that it must be a hotpot place. Hotpot is definitely one of our favourites back home and given the ultra cold weather we thought it would be a perfect way to end off the night! We were all very glad we spotted this place because it did not disappoint! 

Portions were very generous. We ordered the edamame beans and gyozas for appies. The edamame was not like your average edamame beans. My girlfriend was obsessed with them! My favourite was definitely the gyozas. The soups were really different from the typical soups I've tried at other hotpot places (we had half spicy miso and half sukiyaki). They were so much more flavourful as opposed to being either the usual just plain salty or watery. And instead of the usual dipping sauce, it came with a ponzu sauce, which we all agreed complemented the meats so well. All the servers were really attentive and refilled our pots with water without being asked (big brownie points for this!)

All in all, the next time i'm in SF, Nabe will definitely be on the top of the list of restaurants to revisit.
author: Nina P.

description: This is now one of my favorite restaurants in SF. I love the Kimchi with Pork Belly.  It's simply delicious.  But I would recommend replacing the mochi with ramen. :)
author: George L.

description: It's great shabu shabu. The staff is very helpful though may be short staffed.  We had two large pots for 3 people and it was plenty.  We tried the Shabu Shabu spicy miso and the Sukiyaki.  Both with Waygu beef which was the best beef for shabu shabu I have had.  I have been to the Henry the VIII, Shabuzen and Shabuway and this ranks as the best.  The prices are pretty good and we loved the porridge at the end.  It was definitely a neat and tasty experience!
author: Amy C.

description:
Some friends who live in the Sunset recommended this place so me and my cuz decided to try it out. Got here around 5:30P on a Friday night and we were lucky enough to get a table but the place got crowded quickly. I should really say a part of the table because the center of the restaurant is essentially one really long table with hot pot burners inset .

We started off with the edamame appetizers and they give you a ton a edamame (perfect for me)! As for the shabu shabu, we ordered the pork belly in kimchi broth and the Washugyu beef in traditional konbu broth. Apparently these are traditional Japanese pairings but it seemed weird to me that they don't let you choose meats and broths separately because when it comes out you can cook the meat in whichever broth you want. This was key because even though they told us upfront that the konbu is just water and seaweed, I soon realized that it makes your meat and veges taste exactly like...water and seaweed. So very quickly I was pretty much cooking everything in the kimchi broth, which I must say was amazingly delicious. Spicy but flavorful-spicy not just spicy-for-the-sake-of-burning-your-tastebuds. Meat quality was excellent as well and veges were fresh.

Definitely a nice place to eat on a cold night. Prices are on the higher end but not unreasonable. Missed out on the Zozui rice porridge when we went so guess we'll have to come back!
author: Aaron G.

description: Went here recently after they first opened and was pleased by the meat quality and broth - great first start for this young restaurant.  Service was attentive and polite and was actively seeking feedback on how to improve - always a good sign for an up and coming place.  The place was a bit noisy when we went due to the large communal table in the middle but overall had a good vibe and decor.
author: Matt F.

description:
don't order extra rice ... they got this great porridge thing at the end of the meal...

we ordered the kurobuto pork and the beef with one seaweed broth and one spicy broth.   both were very tasty but i prefer the beef.   excellant quality beef with incredible marbling, partically melts in the mouth.   They also have an excellent selection of sake.  We asked the waitress to recommend a few glasses a she picked us a winner. sorry i forgot the name but im sure the waitresses there will recommend a winner for you.

Overall great service and a nice way to take the chill off a cold night
author: Warren A.

description: I came here to meet with a friend and catch up during lunch (12:30). I went with my husband and daughter as well. My daughter is 3 months so she's in a stroller, and we only have a jogging stroller which is pretty big. Luckily we arrived when there weren't many people so we were seated immediately and were able to snag a seat where the stroller could go next to us. (I don't recommend going here if you have a baby in a stroller as there just isn't much room.) when the place started getting busy and packed (15 mins later), I felt as if the stroller was a nuisance to other customers. I ordered the kimchi broth and it was amazing! If I didn't have a stroller and lived closer to San Fran I would go here again! My husband had the shabu shabu with miso broth in a large and was fully satisfied. (he's a big guy--6'1) There is only one restroom in the restaurant which is unisex. The one waitress was VERY busy waiting the tables and she never refilled our waters until we asked. I wish she refilled the water more so I deducted a star. I left the restaurant feeling thirsty... For my first time having shabu shabu this restaurant is amazing! I would recommend this restaurant to a friend! There is a small metered parking lot across from the restaurant which was very convenient. I should add that I did not have to wait at all to be seated and didn't have a reservation.
author: Susie L.

description: Second time here and it was an awesome experience. The servers are super friendly and very helpful! That's the first thing I noticed about this place! The owner, Hilwin (I hope I'm spelling it right, girlie!) is sooo funny and so friendly! Last time I came here, I got the Sukiyaki & Kimchi. The sukiyaki was a bit too sweet, but the kimchi was really good! Second time here, got the kimchi + pork belly and it was better than last time! Perfect, in my opinion. And the porridge thing they do in the end, omg it can not get any better. Spent about like 50 bucks for two people and it was well worth it. I will definitely come back here for that porridge thing the next time I crave it. :)
author: cadence p.

description:
The food was awesome.  And at the end the owner came to the table and used the left-over broth to make a rice porridge kind of thing.  Unbelievable! The service over all was fantastic, very attentive, kind and helpful.  

Over all, I would recommend it for a family dinner out.  My only recommendation is to make a reservation before hand.
author: Abe S.

description: This place was a little cramped and very expensive. Their sauce was not that great. I should have gotten something other than the traditional soup, which tasted just like boiled water.  I feel like its just a standard Shabu place.
author: Charles Z.

description: This place is great! The food is wonderful. We had the spicy miso soup with the beef and pork belly! Both were very fresh and tasted just right. The reason that I could not give five stars is the soup lacked a little in flavor. I wanted something a little more but it was still very good.
author: Greg B.

description: I yelped "sukiyaki" in San Francisco, and this is what popped up. I was excited because my normal shabu place in San Jose that has sukiyaki is sooooooooooooooooooooooo busy these days. What a bummer. Anyway went here after work and was not pleased. I only give it two stars because our waitress was fab and the bathroom was clean. I mean other than that, the food was two thumbs down for me. I didn't like the sukiyaki. I don't like how they already have the vegetables with the broth versus the customers being able to dip it themselves. The sukiyaki didn't taste like sukiyaki to me. It tasted like suki-yucky. The meat portion is small and very very thinly sliced. The restaurant is cute but so small. So small that not only do the windows fog up real quick...the customers who are wearing glasses ALSO can't see because their glasses are fogged up!!! Which is pretty hilar. Anyway, this place is a no return for me.
author: Candice L.

description: The decor and ambiance, 5 stars, service-one of the waitress had to come back 4 times to ask additional questions to confirm our simple orders of Shabu Shabu, however, she was cute and personable; therefore, the service was 3 stars, and the food quality was very good but the portion is small,even for the large order. for $29, I would expect more. The soup was average. 3 stars-- average 3.5 stars.
author: SJ L.

description: I absolutely LOVE nabe!!!! Hands down the best beef and kurabuta pork ever!  The best deal is to go with a "set" (all their broths are soooo good).... It's so filling you'd wish u could eat more!  Great selection of sake too!  And when u finish ur bottle, u can sign it and put it up on their wall... Pretty cool!!!  Staff is also extremely nice and very attentive!
author: Yukio W.

description:
one of the best hot pots in san francisco !!!

the place is really cozy and a great place for hot pot

the broth the noodles the meat are so gooooooooood
 
the small snacks were soooo goooddddddd 

will definitely come back again !!!!!
author: Benjamin L.

description: Small Place, but it's right on the busy spot on 9Ave. We had Sukiyaki and Spicy Kimchi Broths, They were great. Dinner portion was kind of small, but you can always order somewhat an over priced add on plates. My wife said the custom made porrige by the waitress was good.  .... Not sure why they don't do all you can eat hotpot.  I give this place a 4 out of 5 based just only on the food quality and the environment.
author: Ben B.

description: I dined here with my roommates and a few friends last night and wow am I excited that this place is so close to my house. For 17 dollars a head we had two big hot pots, two plates of meat and gyoza. The whole cooked in front of you thing is really exciting and being able to dip the raw meat into the boiling pots was really innovative and fun. The best part was definitely the porridge at the end. Once all of the big chunks of veggies and meat are gone, the servers being out rice, eggs, scallions, and seaweed and create this porridge right in front of you. It was beyond delicious.  The servers were so nice and attentive as well, guiding us through the hot pot journey. The only down side was that it just gets so hot in there with all the boiling pots but the servers knew when to open the door to cool us off. Overall, great experience.
author: Lauren K.

description:
This Hotpot/Shabu Shabu restaurant was offering a huge variety of broths and flavor combinations, but I've mostly stuck to the traditional fare of spicy miso and beef. Their ingredients are very fresh, the hotpot burners are convenient, and they can even split flavors in a single pot. I'd really recommend it as a place to go and catch up with friends- there's a lot of potential for communal sharing and its easy to chat over the food. 

The variety of sides offered with your generic shabu shabu is generous and one of their selling points (tofu, enoki, noodles, pumpkin, spinach, cabbage, carrot). Their meat is a nice quality and stays buttery soft. 

But lets talk about the best thing- the rice porridge that is made after the meal with the rich broth leftover, egg, and rice. Whipped until its milky- I almost always take home this portion and have it for breakfast. 

The food is a little high-priced for my usual budget- but it comes with the second portion of rice porridge and more sides than your usual shabu shabu course. 

The staff is usually very attentive and informative, very lovely. Sometimes it seems as though they may need one extra person on hand to just help with getting water and helping patrons get their check in a timely manner.
author: Viva W.

description: Nabe is an awesome hotpot place if you are looking for a reasonably charged place which also feed you well. Very fresh meat, seafood, and a diverse amount of flavors of broths. It gets crowded later and it's not a roomy place, but definitely a fan of it!
author: Aijia Y.

description:
I really wanted to give 5 stars. The decor and atmosphere are quite impressive. Top of the line, in fact, for a small place like this. The service is also very good. The only problem I had with this place is the reason people go here: the food. We got the pork belly and duck breast. The pork belly was delicious. The duck breast was cut too thick and it was very tough. 

The first mistake was already having the duck breast inside of the pot when it comes out. In my opinion, it should be served on a separate plate. I understand that the presentation looks nice, but if it all cooks together at the same time, the meat will be over-cooked unless you try to eat only the duck breast very fast. No one wants to do that because you want to enjoy the whole hot pot, not try and get rid of the meat as soon as possible. Needless to say, the duck was extremely tough and rubbery.

The second mistake was already having all of the ingredients in the pot when it comes out. Again, the presentation looked fantastic, but we literally sat there for 15 minutes waiting for the pot to come to a boil. We were already really hungry coming in.
