We ordered, waited 15 minutes to get our food, then had to wait another 15 minutes just watching the bowl while it got hot. I was very disappointed in the wait time. Either preheat the pot back in the kitchen so it will come out with little wait time, or don't fill the pot with all the ingredients so it takes extra long to heat everything up. Plus, it would increase the customer turnover time significantly. A restaurant is in the business to make money. Having a higher turnover would be more profitable. We spent 2 hours in there from start to finish. I like to enjoy my meals, but that was way too long to spend in a restaurant with just two people.

If you only order one hotpot, they will try to up-sell you to two (we were two people). Trust me, one order is plenty of food for two people.

This is a great place to take a date, but be aware of wait times. Also, the price point was a little too high for what you get. I'd go back more often if it wasn't so expensive.
author: Michael S.

description: This is a long overdue review. When I first tried this place, I was immediately impressed with their beef quality. If you shabu a lot like me, you'll remember that other places have beef that seemed to fall apart when cooked or turned into a weird gray color. But nabe beef is amazing. It's tender, juicy, and never falls apart even after over cooking. I was hooked with their shabu shabu set but it was their duck set that was life changing. This stuff is like crack. The skin is seared nicely and the breast is cut into perfect slices. It's cooked in a dashi broth (savory soy based) and it simply taste like heaven. And when things can possibly get better, they make you a rice porridge with your left over broth that'll blow your mind all over again. Save room for desert though! The new panna cotta is super creamy and their mochi cake which is served warm with ice cream is delicious. I usually get the duck breast and my BF gets the spicy miso shabu. I think it's one of the best combos ever. Best part is, they take rsvp despite party size! Super plus. Give nabe a try, you won't regret it!
author: Anna Z.

description: I really love this place.  The food is clean & delicious.  The service is excellent and it is a sweet place to go.  It is very small & cramped - I wish it was bigger so I can get a table without a long wait.
author: N A.

description: My fiancé and I come here on the regular. This is the best shabu around if you're looking for high quality. We love their spicy miso broth because it's not oily and it's actually spicy. Their Kobe is perfect and their garlic edamame is the best I've had. This place rocks.
author: Caitlin S.

description: Nabe is the best Shabu Shabu place I have been to in the entire bay area. Their service is amazing, and their food is even better. I definitely recommend it if you are craving good Shabu Shabu.
author: Gerardo A.

description: Got the sukiyaki and shabu shabu. More upscale ambiance than some of the other hot pot places, but I thought it was pricier and not as tasty as some of the other hot pot/shabu shabu places. I'd go to hot pot garden over this place.
author: Caroline D.

description:
One great thing about Nabe as you sit down is the decor. You know the owners paid great attention to detail when they created this place - not just a restaurant with raw uncooked meat and veggies and a boiling pot.

Great place for dates or friends. Of course if you know hot pot, you'll know of the smell that comes with the territory.

Service is excellent.

The marbling on the beef is top notch. One thing Nabe has that other a shabu's in the city dont have is that pork belly - very delicious.

I had a great dinning experience and will be back and try the sukiyaki.
author: Eddy L.

description: Delicious and very filling. High quality broth and the rice finish is great. Only wish it was cheaper and I would go more often.
author: Sally S.

description: Food was delicious and fresh! The staff was so nice and helpful since it was our first time going. Will definitely be coming back very soon!
author: Militza N.

description: My first time getting hot pot. So amazing. Service was great. Food was great. You can ask them for leaner meat if you'd like, or more fatty meat. The meat and veggies are so fresh.
author: Niloofar F.

description:
Although I am no expert in nabemono, I thought that this new Inner Sunset restaurant that opened the day before we tried it (12/21/12) was very good indeed.
Starting with the look of the restaurant, the modern Japanese decor is elegantly done, with wooden sake dispensing containers lining one wall, and a wood grid ceiling. The floor to ceiling wall faces 9th Avenue, so you can watch the neighborhood pass by.
For a nabemono neophyte like myself, the menu needs some explanation, but the wait staff were very friendly and patient about explaining how best to cook the various meats in the broths, and what dipping sauces or raw egg go with which item. Of the food we tried the Kimchi and kurobuta pork belly, sukiyaki and the seafood yosenabe were my favorites. After you eaten your fill by cooking the meat and vegetables in the broth, the waitstaff will then ask which broth you would like to have rice, green onions, egg and seaweed cooked in (you can pick more than one of your broths); this is a delicious way to end the nabemono.
The food was excellent, fresh and healthy. And the prices were reasonable; this is a great addition to the neighborhood restaurant scene.
author: paul g.

description: Very yummy shabu ! Both times i was here we has very friendly, interactive servers who explained the whole shabu process and went out of their way to make us feel welcome. The food itself is very fresh and tasty, my favorite part is the rice soup they make for u at the end. Definitely will return
author: Aisha F.

description: Came here last night for a business get-together with a party of 9 people. I've been in search of a shabu place and immediately bookmarked Nabe when I heard it opened. A few people in my party lived in Japan for a number of years, so I figured it would be the perfect opportunity to try it out. Needless to say, everyone loved Nabe! The service was very pleasant (something I'm finding to be more and more rare on every eating adventure). The food came out shortly after ordering and heated up quickly on the table top stoves. The veggies were standard (cabbage, tofu, mushrooms, pumpkin, spinach, carrots, etc) and were very fresh and crispy. The meat was incredibly fresh, tender, and sliced super thin. All the broths we had were amazing. At most places, I'm never really inclined to sip on the broth because it's relatively flavorless and has that weird film from the not-so-high-quality meats. Not at Nabe! The particular standout was the seasonal kamonanban with duck breast in a dashi broth. They kept having to come by and refill the broth for us. At the end, they make a congee rice porridge with the leftover broth, rice, egg and chopped green onions. It was a great way to round out the meal! Prices are definitely reasonable, service is wonderful, sakes are great, space was cute. We'll definitely be back!
author: Heather U.

description: This place is delicious! Good price, fresh ingredients. Went here with my girlfriend for lunch. Like the vibe too. Will try to go back again...
author: Rob C.

description: I came here around 2:30 in the afternoon last week. It was not too packed, but when i walked in the vibes blew me away. They have sake bottles on the wall in a very clean looking restaurant. Me and my friend ended up ordering the Sukiyaki and Kimchi broth. Both soups were delicious while the meat and vegetable plates were fresh. This restaurant was in a great location and easy to navigate around the city after you eat. The waitress was also very attentive. The bad thing about the lunch menu is not being able to have to porridge which is only served during dinner. I will definitely be returning to this restaurant.
author: Matthew H.

description: Came with a big group of 16 people yesterday afternoon. I gave the lady a half hour heads up and everything was all set up and pretty when we got there which was great. My standard for shabu is Shabu House on Geary (and Sloat) - I love everything about it and it never disappoints. This place, although the service was awesome, was meh. I ordered a Large Shabu Shabu for $16. She said the different between small and large ($13 vs. $16) was 5 oz or 7 oz of meat. No. Freaking. Way was it 7 oz. I got 8 paper thin slices of beef that shredded every time I tried to pick it up with my chopsticks. I know they're supposed to be thin, but I doubt it was weighed before giving to us. The cold tofu w/ kim chee was good, but didn't arrive until half the table was already eating their shabu and my end of the table hadn't gotten anything (I ordered first, and don't want to sound like a diva but somehow got my food last when we all ordered the same thing). We were all still hungry afterward so we went to Sheng Kee around the corner. I feel mean giving 2 stars but if I pay $20 something bucks and am still hungry after...nope.
author: Lauren Q.

description: over prize     Other all u can eat are only $30 and I can eat way more    $29for a plate of meat and vag is too much
author: Ali Y.

description: I made a reservation for 7:30 and we got there at 7:35. A waiter told us that we had to wait 20 minutes, so we went next door to have a drink. 20 minutes later, the waiter called me and said that a table is ready for us to seat right away. So we left the bar and walked over. Another waiter came and told us that we had to wait 10 more minutes. What's the point making a reservation? Food was alright. Zosui was really good tho. But I'm not going back there again.
author: K S.

description: A MUST GO and TRY!  Oh my goodness...a friend gave this place a thumbs up on Sat and several of us immediately went! Great service from the hardworking ladies and also just amazing spices and flavors! This was my first visit and we had the classic beef shabu shabu, wonderful DUCK(yep, there's duck) with shitake mushrooms, and kim chee pork belly (with mochi)! Everything just melts in your mouth! I have cut out beef and pork from my diet and eating more greens, but this meal was my one-time pass card!  There are a ton of veggies too!  All the dishes come packed with good protein, fresh healthy greens, and then you finish with OMG...rice porridge!  Who does that?  This place does!  I did not have the sake yet...but I'm sure it's a must as well.  Delish! I'm coming back and trying the rest of the items on the menu.
author: Diane N.

description: NABE is the BEST!! hands down!!I I've been here about 5 times now and I gotta admit, many places are not consistent but NABE is always fresh and yummy and hits the spot for me. This is not your regular "shabu" spot because it it NOT a "shabu" place. Its NABEMONO and and I would advise everyone not to get too full from what comes out of your cast iron pot or steel pot. The end is the best.. the ZOSUI!!  If you dont know what it is, GOOGLE IT so you wont miss out. They take the broth which is rich and full of flavor from everything that was cooking in the pot and they add rice, egg and green onions topped off with seaweed creating a decadent delight of goodness in your mouth. OMG!! I'm drooling already. My personal favorites is the kimchee kabuto pork belly and the duck pots. My personal favorite appetizers are the sausages and the gyoza. The GYOZA  are freshly made daily. They also have a great selection of Sakes which accommodate the dishes well. The staff is cute and super sweet. Quick tip.... you can always order a plate of beef on the side to go with your nabemono. Ok, I think I'll be heading there tonight again!! Booya! Thanks NABE for feeding my belly!! I LOVE NABE!!! Finally we have a different style of a true japanese traditional way of eating! Thank you NABE for opening in San Francisco. Truly an experience you won't want to miss!!
author: Moesha N.

description: Nabe is a true gem -- great/unusual food, hip/comfortable setting, warm/welcoming staff.  I love traveling to Japan because of the restaurants, rather than catch-all Japanese food, eateries concentrate on and specialize in singular delicacies.  Nabe is born from this tradition.  The brother/sister team that runs the place noticed that SF lacked a traditional nabemono shop, where patrons choose a broth and fixings and finish the dish at the table.  The result is fresh, tasty comfort food.  One warning, don't stuff yourself: at the end of the meal the waitress uses your leftover broth to make the most delicious rice porridge at the table. MMMMmmmm!
author: Jon S.
